SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 7 October 1987 the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) announced that the Government would establish a Civil Aviation Authority (CAA). This Bill gives effect to that announcement. It is apparent, of course, that this Government generally governs by Press release. The CAA will have operational responsibility for air traffic control, flight advisory services, communications, navigation and surveillance systems, rescue and firefighting; and will provide an aeronautical information service and offer consultancy and management services in its fields of expertise. It will also be responsible for organising aviation search and rescue services. The stated rationale for the CAA, similar bodies to which are in operation in other Western countries, is that it will be more commercial and flexible in its operation, it will have increased productivity, it will be better able to organise its own finances, and it will be more responsive to industry needs.

SPEECH.PARA: The transfer of the CAA from the Department will permit more efficient cost recovery, and will allow the appointment of a nine- member board of people with commercial backgrounds. It will also allow the appointment of advisory committees. Because significant investment in communications and other areas is needed, the CAA will, it is claimed, have more flexibility in organising its budgetary and charging arrangements in the interests of the aviation industry. Safety responsibility will also be transferred to the CAA, although the Minister will retain the power to make directions on safety, and in the operations of the new Authority primacy will be given to safety over commercial considerations. An augmented bureau of air safety investigations will remain with the Department and perform a safety audit function.

The proposal put forward by the Government is badly thought out and has been developed in a hasty fashion, with minimal consultation with industry. It will result in less efficiency, less accountability, more expensive airway systems and-most important-the divorce of safety from the direct oversight of the Minister. Insufficient detail has been provided for the Opposition and for the aviation industry to determine exactly what the impact of the CAA will be. The establishment of the CAA is one of the worst examples of the Government's paying no more than lip-service to the critical issue of consultation with the appropriate industry bodies. That is one of the hallmarks of the Government. It issues a Press release, waits to see how it runs and, if it bounces well, the Government goes down that track but, if it does not bounce well, the Government dismisses the issue and lets it go. There are many examples of the Government doing that, and the establishment of the CAA is but one.

We should consider what happened in the media area. Press releases were issued, people rushed out and bought television stations and then the rules were changed. Consider what is happening in relation to company law at present. About one year ago we said that company law should have a national basis. A Press statement was issued, but there is not consultation with the commercial world of Australia on that matter. A small group of 35 people handpicked by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) is going around plotting. If one is a member of the Committee one cannot tell others. That is exactly what has happened in this industry. There has been no consultation, or limited consultation, with the industry which is concerned about the establishment of the CAA. This situation bears out what is happening elsewhere.

The Minister for Transport and Communication Support (Mr Peter Morris) in his brief Press release of September 1986 indicated that work would be undertaken `to identify and address the full range of administrative, legislative, financial and operational issues involved'. What has happened in that regard? I have not seen too much action. I will deal with each of those issues in turn. Despite rumours of an internal working report on the matters, no information has been released either to the industry or to the Opposition. There is more of the mushroom cloud. The Government says, `If the report is not too hot, let us vary it. The last thing we want to do is consult with the industry, which will be massively affected by the legislation'. Despite a briefing from officers of the Department, who have been most cooperative, little light has been shed on the matter.

It is interesting to note the way in which the fundamental issues surrounding the establishment of the CAA are still wrapped in secrecy. Perhaps that is because the Minister and the Government are simply playing the whole show by ear and have as little idea of the direction and the ultimate shape of the CAA as have the rest of us. The creation of any new Government authority must give cause for concern. Good management should be able to achieve the stated aviation objectives without the need for a separate CAA, although undoubtedly there are existing difficulties in dealing with the Department of Finance. The CAA would have its headquarters in Canberra, and most of the administrative work is done here in any case.

As I stated previously, the 7,000 employees will remain under the Public Service Act, so consequently there will be no change in the management. The industry is concerned that this will preclude the commercial operation of the CAA and it is also concerned about the lack of consultation and the possibility of decreased accountability and accessibility. Quite clearly, if we move a group of people from a department into a hived off authority and say that that will be more commercial and that there will be outside directors, if the 7,000 employees remain under the Public Service Act, we will go only half way. Indeed, as the honourable member for Griffith, the Minister for Veterans Affairs (Mr Humphreys), would know, if he employed 7,000 people he would not want them to be directed under the Public Service Act at all. There would be duplication of functions between the CAA and the emasculated Department in such areas as safety, security and financial direction involving charges for services rendered by the CAA. There would not be a reduction in the issuing of regulations, because the Government has failed to implement its promised regulation review before the creation of the CAA. Such a review is an integral part of the coalition's aviation policy. Furthermore, government authorities develop a bureaucratic nature of their own. Given the model of the now money hungry Federal Airports Corporation, one must wonder what the Civil Aviation Authority will be capable of if it is left to its own devices or, worse, directed by the Minister to pay an arbitrary dividend to a greedy Minister for Finance.

A key issue is whether the role of setting and implementing safety standards should reside with the Government or be hived off to a statutory authority. The Government has decided to distance itself from safety matters. No rationale has been provided for this decision. Results of an internal departmental inquiry, the Willoughby inquiry-and there are plenty of inquiries with this Government; there need to be-into the proposed CAA structure, has never been made public. The honourable member for Griffith would know that this is one of those government inquiries that are never made public. The Government sits on the hot ones and releases the good ones. What is the Government trying to hide in this case?

Many sectors of the industry, including the pilot organisations, are unhappy with the proposed arrangements to include the safety standard setting function in the new Authority, arguing that this will reduce safety standards. There is a real need for more public discussion on why the Government has chosen this option and on what are the pros and cons. Why is the Government almost breaking its neck to get the legislation through without any consultation or time for discussion in the broader community?

The former Department of Aviation, which had responsibility for managing the airways system and flight standards division, was a national disgrace. This situation continues with the new Department of Transport and Communications, which is unresponsive, inefficient, unaccountable, bureaucratic, unsympathetic and, by any standards, a high cost operator. There have been numerous complaints and inquiries into the Department's operations, the most notable being the Dick Smith inquiry. I recommend his book Two Years In the Aviation Hall of Doom to all those interested in this area because not only is it light reading but also it is very incisive in its comments.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Department has never adequately responded.

—As the honourable member for Farrer says, the Department has never responded. All those who actively participate in the aviation industry and who have read the book will be concerned at its contents. Dick Smith is not a man who makes these comments lightly, and people should address themselves to what he says. I shall give a little excerpt from the book:

SPEECH.PARA: Over the past two years I have spoken to many people from both the Department and the industry and have copies of the hundreds of documents sent to me. Even though in many cases I have left the comments anonymous, I would be happy to supply an independent committee of review with full confirmation after checking with the people concerned. I have included this section to show the broad spread of dissatisfaction that exists.
The first quote I shall give from the book is from a commercial pilot. He says:

The Department of Aviation are champions of procrastination, buck passing and consistently playing one interest group off against the other, through their ongoing policy of keeping the industry fragmented, so that there is never any unity in lobbying for improvement.
Another quotation is from a retired examiner with over 25 years of experience. He says:

One of the reasons I took early retirement was sheer frustration. When Anderson was in charge everything fired, he would not stand any incompetence. When he went it became a complacent retirement area, a cancerous disease set in, all initiative was lost and the Department lost touch with the industry.

They selected people from the military, who had grown up in the peace time forces where they were protected. However, they think they know all about the world. I would go home and look at myself. I'd say, `Is there something wrong with me?' I put up lots of ideas to Central Office, but I didn't even get an answer to my letter; they just didn't want to know.

Those comments are from a commercial pilot and a retired examiner of 25 years experience, and they show the sort of inertia that existed in the Department when Dick Smith wrote that book. They are but two examples.

What has happened as a result of the book? The Government's response is nil. In essence, this proposal-the CAA-vests greater responsibility in those very public servants who in the past have shown no effort to improve efficiency, reduce costs or provide a reasonable level of service to their clients-the aviation industry.

This proposal will result in less accountability, higher charges and a less responsive organisation. The Opposition believes that the CAA will do nothing but distance the Minister from the real working of his responsibilities and will enable him to hide from criticisms of the Government. The very real problems which confront the Department need to be addressed logically rather than by a gut reaction to this Government's failure by attempting to sweep the old Department of Aviation under the mat.

No information was provided in the second reading speech on costs of the proposal and the intentions for charging. The proposal will result in increased costs; it will not reduce them. There are a number of pertinent questions, and the Government is silent on all of them. Fuel excise is currently charged for the purpose of aviation cost recovery. Will it continue to be so under the CAA regime? Departure tax is currently contributable for the purpose of cost recovery. Will it continue to be so under the new regime? Assets will be revalued, despite the fact that industry has been paying for them for years. What will be the basis of the new valuations and how will it affect costs? The impact will be enormous.

Over the years very considerable assets in this area have been written off and paid for. It is proposed under this scheme to rewrite the value of those assets and charge them once again to the current costs of the business. Even the Minister would know, if he has driven a car around the block for 10 years and wants to write it up to current costs, that that is not the way in which any accounting ought to be done. But that is what is proposed. Any responsible person who wants to run an organisation on that basis knows that the consumer will be diddled. The real costs are not there.

The CAA will be a monopoly supplier. There will be no incentive to reduce costs and it will be easy to increase charges. I am sure that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) are rubbing their hands together and have dollar signs in their eyes. The Board will pay a ministerially approved dividend. This will increase costs. Costs of implementing standards-which is a nice way of saying policing-are to be met by the industry. Currently, as is the case in the rest of the world, like all other policing costs, they come from Consolidated Revenue. So any charge will result in an increase in costs. Staff are to be employed under the inflexible, restrictive, high cost Public Service Act. If the Government were genuine about reducing costs in this area it would employ staff under a more commercial regime.

Additional costs arising from the implementation of this proposal-new investment, the requirement for the Authority to provide a reasonable rate of return and from the revaluation of assets-will mean higher charges for the aviation industry. If the revaluation of assets is similar to the quadrupling that occurred, to over $1 billion, with the Federal Airports Corporation, these charges might be significantly higher over time.

In regard to asset valuation, one of the users, a prominent industry spokesman, in consultations and submissions on the CAA, expressed concern at the prospect of CAA assets being valued on other than an historical cost basis. The Bill remains silent on the Government's intentions, other than the provision that the Minister for Transport and Communications and the Minister for Finance are to make such determinations. As the value of assets transferred to the CAA will represent loans to the CAA with capital repayment and debt servicing implications, the industry spokesman remains concerned about the level of debt the CAA will be confronted with because of the transfer of increased values and the ultimate impact that such costs will have on charges levied on users.

Quite clearly, if the Government is going to make the revaluation of assets that occurred in the airports situation, where the value of the assets was written up, the debt was incurred on the Authority, the Department of Finance took the cop and wrote off the losses in the Department of Aviation, then the users will have to pay the extra bill. The debts are there, the interest has to be paid, and on top of that a dividend has to be paid. This all points straight down the road to increased cost to the aviation industry. There can be very little doubt about that.

For the last two years the Government has been talking about the integration and modernisation of the airway system-IMAS-but it has done nothing but talk. IMAS involves a major integration of flight service officers and air traffic controllers. Before CAA is established it is essential that this integration take place to ensure that a cost-effective operation is transferred to the CAA. Likewise, the Department, under very strong pressure from the industry, has undertaken to review the myriad air navigation regulations and orders which are presently suffocating the aviation industry. These go back to the Air Navigation Act of the 1920s and have been built on every year. They must almost be a challenge to the Income Tax Assessment Act, which is up to 1700 pages. The present Minister for Transport and Communications Support, in his announcement of the proposed establishment of the CAA on 22 October 1986, assured the industry that a thorough review of these regulations would take place. Here we are, some 18 months later, still waiting for that review to commence, even though it has been announced and positions have been filled. After 18 months the Minister is yet to achieve one single change as a result of the establishment of that regulatory review group. It has been looking at the regulations for 18 months and it has not moved one. Even the Minister for Veterans' Affairs could do better than that in moving regulations. It has been 18 months and the Government has not moved one regulation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am busy looking after the veterans at the moment.
—How many regulations have been moved there?
—Not too many.

—There we are; they probably go slower still. The effectiveness of that regulatory review group, I am afraid, does not bode well for the aviation industry, which is now to be lumbered with another quango. There are plenty of them around. While on the subject of what the industry sees as essential for the success of any modernisation of the regulations surrounding the Australian aviation scene, the Minister also indicated in his October 1986 statement that consultation with industry would certainly take place because of the numbers of issues to be resolved. That is an admission that there are problems there. So we have at least got that far. We set up a committee of inquiry-another one of these Government inquiries. The Government either issues a Press release or has an inquiry. That is the way it governs Australia these days. When in doubt, trot out a Press release. If it does not work, deny it. If it does work, set up an inquiry and leave it at that.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting that one of the major players in Australia's aviation industry, along with the rest of the industry, is yet to have a real input into this phantom consultation process. For months the Minister and the Department have said, `Of course there will be consultation. We wouldn't think of introducing legislation without at least telling you what is in it'. Yet the legislation has been introduced into the House with very little warning to the industry and it has been given little more than a week to make a response. Many people in the industry saw this legislation for the first time when the Opposition mailed copies of it to them. That is a very familiar scene with this Government. That is also what is going on in the company law area. If that is the Minister's idea of genuine consultation with the industry, then I say it is little wonder that the industry is always very wary of anything this Government has to offer in the area of aviation. The Opposition will be opposing the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In supporting the Civil Aviation Bill, I must say that the Opposition has adopted a totally negative attitude. I do not believe that the changes that the Government is proposing necessarily have any cost implications. In fact, it could be quite the other way. There could be substantial savings. The Government's decision to establish the Civil Aviation Authority was born of the Government's desire to make the aviation section of the Department of Transport and Communications more cost-effective and more receptive to the needs of the industry. Here is the nub of the matter, for I believe that we must look at the philosophy of civil aviation. It is my belief that it has become moribund and that this initiative could represent a breakaway from the present mentality of the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The new Authority is to ensure a degree of cost recovery, and I support this. If we are to recover costs from industry for services provided, it is essential that the industry be consulted about the nature of those services. Concern has been expressed that air safety matters should perhaps not be left to a commercially oriented cost recovery based organisation. I certainly do not think this is true. While I have no doubt that the Department's regulations have contributed to our world famous safety record, I suspect that the generally high standard of pilot training, coupled with probably the best flying weather in the world, our generally flat terrain and the absence of fog, have played an even more important part. In any case, the United Kingdom has successfully combined the operations of its airway system with safety regulations and I have absolute confidence that the same can be achieved here.

I would like to express some concern about cost recovery, which relates to the philosophy that I mentioned earlier. I think that general aviation is generally poorly treated. I suspect that 70 per cent of all general aviation flights take place in areas where no navigation aids exist and that often they use privately owned and maintained airstrips. A cost penalty has been endured by general aviation, as it in part funds facilities utilised by regular airlines.

Let us take, for instance, the fire services. The reality is that general aviation never calls on these services. Indeed, for the most part such services do not exist on general aviation routes. In any case, I suspect that, in the case of unpredicted disaster, even where fire services are situated at airports, by the time they were mobilised it would be too late. If, on the other hand, prior knowledge of potential trouble were available, there would be time to get fire vehicles from the fire brigades to attend. I do not know what the services cost, but the costs must be enormous. They may be of some psychological benefit to Ansett Airlines of Australia, Qantas Airways Ltd, Australian Airlines and overseas operators, but they are irrelevant to general aviation, which should not have to bear any part of the costs.

I want to sound a warning about what I see as empire building by departments. Empire building has cost this country dearly in terms of productivity. I refer to a move by the Department to insist that all pilot transfers between a harbour and ships at sea presently undertaken by helicopters be done by twin engine helicopters during night transfers. This is very relevant to my electorate-and, indeed, to Australia's export earnings-at the Pilbara ports of Hedland, Dampier and Cape Lambert. It was at Port Hedland that this system of transfer was pioneered, and it has worked very safely and economically indeed.

I want to go into this in some detail, as it is important, and I want to make sure that the new Authority does not embrace this crazy notion. Presently the cost of charter of a single engine helicopter is about a quarter of a million dollars a year. Even if the smallest twin were used the cost would double. Given that engine failure can statistically be expected to occur every 10,000 flight hours and that the port authority utilises about 111 night hours per year, statistically a helicopter will come down in the sea every 90 years-assuming, of course, that there is no improvement whatsoever in engine reliability. The cost of preventing just one false landing is therefore of the order of $22.5m. Furthermore, since the water in this area is usually calm and warm, the probability of a safe rescue in very high seas is, I am told by experts, better than 10:1. The cost of eliminating a fatality has now risen to $225m. In a recent accident in the area where a helicopter was forced to ditch-incidentally a twin-engine helicopter-all nine passengers and pilot were rescued.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is Rolls-Royce standards; it is unjustified.

—Frankly, this sort of notion put forward by the Department is quite ridiculous and I cannot see why a passenger in a plane is any more important than a passenger in a bus, and no-one would suggest we go to these lengths in respect of more humble forms of transport. As the honourable member for Farrer said, these are Rolls-Royce standards which are really irrelevant to the industry. I am hoping that the new Authority, with a new start, can take a more realistic look at such situations. To extrapolate the statistics, we could expect a fatality to occur every 810 years at the present rate of use. Incidentally, these costs are based on using the cheapest possible option, a Bolkow B0105D, a helicopter presently 15 years old, and a replacement would cost infinitely more. I certainly hope the Authority abandons this nonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: I also hope that the new Authority looks closely at the present policy of closing down flight service units. I recognise that there are big savings to be made and that the advent of the satellite has provided the technology to phase out these flight service units from country areas. Reluctantly I accept this. I say `reluctantly' because I see across the length and breadth of this nation today a greater centralisation of people in the cities. I have said in this place often before that Australia is probably the most urban country in the world and I do not think it is in our interests to encourage the draining of the centre of this great nation to the cities around the perimeter of the country. However, I accept that the advent of technology will make this inevitable in this area.

I draw to the attention of the Authority the special conditions that prevail in Kalgoorlie. There we have a very isolated area surrounded on three sides by sparse or desert country, country with no or very little in the way of navigation aids and very little in the way of landmarks. In this country probably a greater proportion of aeroplanes are forced down and a great degree of local knowledge is essential. Under the new system, searchers would be based in Perth, the State capital, and I think we would lose a lot of the local knowledge. It is also interesting that Kalgoorlie is the busiest airport outside the major capital city airports in Australia. I would like to run through a few figures here.

TALK.START.PARA: —Passengers or movements?

—In terms of movements. These figures are of aircraft movements at staffed and unstaffed aerodromes within aerodrome flight information zones during 1986-87. Dubbo, in New South Wales, had just over 15,000 movements, which was the largest number in rural New South Wales. Devonport, in Tasmania, had just over 20,000 and Mildura, in Victoria, had 23,755. Bundaberg, in Queensland, had 22,617. Gladstone had 24,206. Mount Gambier, in South Australia, had nearly 21,000.
—Albury?
—Unfortunately, Albury does not even rate a mention.
—It is not as important as Kalgoorlie.

—Obviously not. Kalgoorlie had over 30,000 movements and I think that is significant. As I said, it is substantially the busiest airport and if flight services is to be phased out I would ask the Department to ensure that it is phased out last from Kalgoorlie to give a greater transition time.

SPEECH.PARA: I also want to dwell on something else that has come to my notice and which I hope the Authority will look at and that is the alteration to Air Navigation Orders 95.10, which deals with the airworthiness of ultralight aircraft. Ultralight aircraft are inventions which one could almost say are Australian. Certainly Australia was at the forefront of their development. In the early days we were producing the best craft, and certainly the most spectacular performances. Unfortunately, we have been left by the wayside. That has been because of the philosophy inherent in the Department that the air was for the Ansetts and the Qantases of this world. There was a disdain for the rights of ordinary people.

The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport Safety studied ultralights and noted that there had been some accidents. It is significant, however, that no member of the public has ever been killed in an ultralight. People have always participated in sport. I do not know the figures, but I suspect that gymkhanas are far more dangerous than ultralights in terms of the absolute number of people injured. No-one would think of banning gymkhanas in this country. We ought to be looking very closely at this industry. The ultralight has the potential to contribute to the economy. The pastoral industry will use ultralights over the next 15 years, if it has the opportunity to do so, in the same way as motorbikes have been used by-and have made an enormous contribution to raising productivity in-the pastoral industry.

In my view the fault has been that the Department has never enforced the regulations it has had in place. It has allowed people to build unsafe or underpowered planes, often with structural faults. The fatalities that have occurred in ultralight aircraft have most often occurred in homemade designs. To go ahead with the draconian proposals that I believe are in the pipeline, to insist that every plane be subject to exhaustive tests, instead of allowing a manufacturer to submit a design and build to those specifications, is a very retrograde step which will, in an authoritarian way, interfere with the pastime-almost a passion-of some people and inhibit potential advantages to this country.

I have had some limited experience with ultralights. I find them fascinating. I look forward to the day when they can go a lot faster than they can now. Their limitation now is speed. In terms of manoeuvrabiltiy and handling, they are unique and quite magnificent.

I am told by people in the industry that one of the great dangers is people who go from general aviation, flying standard aeroplanes, to ultralights. The techniques are different. It may well be worth while insisting that people who wish to fly ultralights are given some training at clubs before they are allowed to fly them. Legislation to that effect would be worth while. But to put serious limitations on the development of these craft is a very retrograde step and, as I said before, will cut us off from the mainstream development of what could be and should be an Australian export industry. If one looks at the history of Australia one sees that we have been at the forefront of flight. The great South Australian Hargrave who experimented with kites and other great Australian aviators have made us world leaders in this area. It would be a great shame to see the industry inhibited in any way by draconian legislation.

I return to the Bill, Mr Deputy Speaker, and thank you for your tolerance in this regard. The Government is moving in the right direction. Establishing the new Authority gives us the ability to take a fresh look at aviation. We can avoid some of the pitfalls of the past. The new Authority will give us the opportunity to look at the myriad of regulations that now completely bind and constipate the industry. It is in line with the Government's general philosophy to make departments more receptive to the needs of users and more accountable. I find the complaints of the Opposition to be without substance. It is lamentable that the Opposition cannot show a little more vision and support some of the Government's initiatives, which are clearly designed for the benefit of the industry and society generally.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On this ninth last day ever of sitting in this chamber, under the currently circulated schedule, I am delighted to address the House on the Civil Aviation Bill, which is a quite wide-ranging Bill when one examines some of its provisions. For example, clause 24 deals with interference with crew or aircraft. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: A person shall not, while in an aircraft:
(a) interfere with a crew member; or
(b) do any act that threatens the safety of the aircraft or of persons on board the aircraft.
This covers hijacking. In clause 25, non- scheduled flights by foreign aircraft into this country are dealt with at some length. I will return to those dimensions of the Bill shortly.

The honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) has just addressed the House and, in his own way, launched a withering attack on his Government and the Department of Transport and Communications with regard to yet another example of clumsy regulation and administration by the Department, on this occasion concerning the Pilbara ports and the helicopter transfer of pilots to ships in the Pilbara region. I accept that the honourable member for Kalgoorlie has detailed knowledge of this matter, I also accept that he has quite properly expressed concern about the loss of income from the massive amount of iron ore exports from that area as a consequence of the Department producing a rule that insists on twin engined helicopter operations for the night transfer of pilots to ships.

This points to the fact that the Department lays down quite often unjustified Rolls Royce standard regulations which place in jeopardy the viability of a total operation without really enhancing the safety dimensions involved. If there were genuine safety considerations, neither the honourable member for Kalgoorlie nor I or my colleagues in the Opposition would quibble for one moment. But, as the honourable member said, there is a very tenuous connection with safety when we examine properly the operating conditions for the night transfer of pilots. Obviously if there are cyclonic conditions threatening at the time, all the operation would cease anyhow. We are talking about non-cyclonic operations-smooth seas, clear nights and so forth-when effecting the transfer of these pilots.

Ironically, this same Department, as detailed in Two Years in the Aviation Hall of Doom by Dick Smith-not to be confused with the Stockman's Hall of Fame-on 26 August 1982 prevented the operation of a twin engined helicopter to Heron Island, insisting that a single engine operation should continue in the circumstances. It would not allow the operator to go to a twin-engine operation because the operator dared to propose this particular change in his operation without going through the minutiae of approvals 12 or even 18 months ahead. As my colleague pointed out, these are the delays caused by the Department. So on the one hand we had in the Heron Island situation the Department saying, in effect, no to a twin engine operation, that operation being introduced under a developmental charter, and then in the case raised by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie saying yes, there will be a twin engined helicopter operation for the transfer of pilots to or from ships. This is just another classic example of the actions of this bureaucratic Department which is now the subject of the attention of the Parliament as we deal with a Bill to set up Civil Aviation Authority to deal with a wide range of safety issues, which I wish to address in some detail.

In so doing, I want to contend that the Bill does not really pave the way for overcoming the problems which have been developing in civil aviation in this country. I know that traditionally it is argued that Australia has an excellent record in air safety, and to some extent that is true. To take that statement at face value one must really accept that our weather conditions are so much better on average than weather conditions in the Northern Hemisphere where the great densities of population and flight movements are. Here there are no cyclonic influences. There are no chronic icing conditions, which can so bedevil the safe operation of airlines. There is no poor visibility to the extent that exists in many busy European and north American airports for much of the year. We are operating on a basically flat terrain, by international standards, in much better weather conditions than exist in the Northern Hemisphere for most of the year and, as such, we ought to be at the top of the ladder in air safety.

Notwithstanding that, very sadly, in the last month we have seen a commuter aviation level operator crash near Coffs Harbour. We have seen general aviation accidents out of Cairns and elsewhere. We have seen a situation which one does not like to dwell on because, acting responsibly, one does not want to introduce into this debate anything that might in some way end up being a self-fulfilling prophecy. What I do say is that germane to all of this in the performance of the Department, which is now being subjected to these changes in the introduction of the Civil Aviation Authority. Let me just canvass for a moment the situation with regard to radar, which is central to airline safety. In Sydney there is old equipment, crying out for replacement, and the Department has never been able to find the priority thus far to complete its replacement by the year 1988.

In Perth, the area of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), I bring good news, to be fair. There, the new radar system is in place. It has been there for years. But do honourable members know what the score is with that particular radar? It is so modern that we have actually reached the minimum European standard of being able to show the height of aircraft and the call sign of aircraft on the radar screen. People might think that that is tremendous, that that is progress: but do they know what the Department has said with regard to that operation for year after year, if not up until this point in time? It has said, `You will ignore that call sign. You will ignore that height on the screen, because it would upset the uniformity of operation to allude to that height, to allude to that call sign, to use the enhanced safety conferred by that call sign'. I am correct in saying this because, along with other members, I went as a member of the committee on aircraft noise to the radar facility and we examined this in great detail. So we have a situation in Perth where people have the new radar but they are not allowed to use the extra information conferred.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ask the Minister about Brisbane's radar.

—Let us look at the Brisbane radar-the surface movement control radar at Brisbane. Would honourable members believe that in the process of the design of that Brisbane Airport-albeit commenced by the previous Government but completed over the last five years in detail by this Government-we have a situation where the consoles in the brand new control tower, commissioned last month, are so old as to be incompatible with the surface movement radar system that has been installed at Brisbane Airport? The public servants responsible for that little mishap are potentially placing at risk the lives of people who travel by aircraft in and out of Brisbane. They have a lot to answer for in terms of the risk factor and in terms of the additional costs which are now going to be required to sort out that particular matter.
—And the big delays.

—And the delays are massive at the new Brisbane Airport. We have also seen in recent times-and I do not point the bone entirely at this Government with regard to the layout at Brisbane Airport-in accordance with the advice of pilots who warned that the main runway would not be suitable for many of the operations at Brisbane Airport, on Monday 11 April 1988 the first of the major diversions due to cross-wind component. A Qantas flight had to divert, along with other flights, because it could not land on Australia's newest, longest by degrees, main runway-the new main runway at Brisbane Airport-because of the cross-wind component, within the first four weeks of operation of this very expensive new airport. I do not entirely blame this Government for that particular decision. I think it is fair to say--

—Order! I ask the honourable member for Farrer to come back within the terms of the Bill. I realise that the Bill allows for a fairly wide-ranging discussion, but I think he is going beyond the terms of the Bill.

—Therefore I will not dwell on that but I do accept that air safety is very much central to the Bill and diverting aircraft in high wind conditions where they would be much safer on the ground is relevant. I just make the point that the Department has a very big responsibility to bear with regard to the detailed end situation which has been reached with the new Brisbane Airport, as my colleague the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) and other members have pointed out at length and will point out in the course of this debate. Might I just add on the radar question, which is central to the legislation, that we have reached the stage where the new equipment in Melbourne I understand is already outdated.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me move on to deal with clauses 25 and 26 of this legislation and non-scheduled flights by foreign aircraft into this country. The Bill lays down some comprehensive provisions for this. It is as well that it does because in the prevailing situation we hear of some comprehensive reports with regard to flights into Australia by unscheduled aircraft, particularly at night time, possibly bringing drugs into Australia, planes as big as DC3s being reported as travelling into old airstrips in northern Queensland and possibly the northern part of the Northern Territory. This has caused concern to the Government and to the nation. It is my hope that under the provisions of clauses 25 and 26 we will not only have in place the right rules to deal with these unscheduled flights into the northern parts of this country, but also the Government will follow up in practice the interception of the quite significant aircraft movement that is obviously going on for illegal purposes of one kind or another, with particular reference to the bringing of drugs into Australia.

I believe it is very important that the Minister address this area. It will be recalled that the Government broke down in relation to the Amman Aviation Pty Ltd saga in terms of maintaining northern surveillance. It is essential not only that the rule is right in terms of this Bill but that in practice the Government has the capability to intercept these flights and to take the legal action necessary and apprehend those who are participating in these flights.

I want to say finally with regard to this legislation, which is rather hasty, which the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) has indicated is wanting in so many other jurisdictions, and which the Opposition is opposing, that under this legislation there are specific clauses dealing with interference with crew or aircraft and that of course relates to the matter of hijacking. I will not dwell on the present situation but I believe I am duty bound to raise it on the floor of this House, that Mr Michael Mansell, by his proposed Libyan visit, is paving the way for hijacking of aircraft within Australia. Mansell's associations with the likes of the Libyan Leader, Colonel Gadaffi, will only pinpoint Australia for Gadaffi's terrorist activities. I do not happen to believe that Michael Mansell is representative of the Aboriginal community, although he has obviously got public funding by degrees from the Australian Government for his modus operandi. Therefore the Australian Government does have some involvement in this matter.

I just want to say that Libya has sponsored conferences on terrorism, conferences on hijacking methodology, and to establish some form of increased linkage with the Libyan regime with its methodology is directly to place in jeopardy Australians and others using aircraft across Australia by the type of horrific terrorism that is implemented in the hijacking of aircraft.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask the honourable member not to proceed along those lines. They are outside the terms of the Bill.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, clause 24 states quite clearly that a person shall not interfere with a crew member. I conclude in regard to this dimension of the legislation by saying that no-one wants to see an outbreak of hijacking in the Southern Hemisphere, least of all in Australia. The Government has important responsibilities in ensuring that everything humanly possible is done to prevent the hijacking of aircraft, and the provisions of this Bill address that question. I sound a note of warning to the Government and the nation that, if the visit of Michael Mansell to Libya takes place-and I will not further refer to that matter-the prospects for the safe movement of aircraft in this country will be jeopardised.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, let me say that since the Government introduced a ban on smoking on domestic flights there has been the odd incident where people have actually tampered with the smoke detectors in the toilets on aircraft. I understand that that has been a minor occurrence, but on at least one flight about which I know, in the week following the introduction of the ban on smoking, a person was found to be smoking in the toilet and, furthermore, the alarm was tampered with so that it would not register in the cockpit and so that the flight attendants would not be aware of the occurrence. However, once the door was opened the smell was noted by many other passengers travelling on the aircraft. Those who would go down that very dangerous path should be aware that they face a penalty of $5,000 or imprisonment for two years, or both, under the provisions of this legislation. I must say that I support that heavy penalty, because such action places in jeopardy the lives of everyone on the aircraft. Let those who smoke in the confines of toilets on domestic flights be aware that anyone who interferes with the smoking alarms that have been installed in virtually all toilets to detect smoking are placing in danger their lives and the lives of other passengers.
The Opposition views this Bill as a hasty legislative approach to the massive problems faced by civil aviation, and for that reason the Opposition opposes it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, regarding the note on which the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) concluded his remarks, I would like to point out that you were responsible for the decision in the Caucus to ban smoking on commercial flights in this country. Indeed, one of the remarkable things about that decision is the degree of compliance and acceptance exhibited by air travellers in this country. For those of us who travel a great deal, it has been a step forward, and one which we appreciate. I am sure it is a landmark decision for those who oppose smoking in public places. I believe it will have beneficial effect for the whole of our community. I endorse the comments of the honourable member for Farrer on that issue. However, I must say that I take exception to one or two of the other things he said.

SPEECH.PARA: In considering this legislation, I was under the impression that it related to the establishment of a Civil Aviation Authority by the Government and that this enabling legislation gave the Authority operational responsibility for air traffic control, flight advisory services, communications, navigation and surveillance systems, and rescue and fire fighting services at airports. In addition, it provides for an aeronautical information service and the organisation of aviation search and rescue services. Indeed, those aspects of the Authority were outlined by the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) in his contribution. The Board of the Authority will consist of nine members and there will be a number of advisory committees consisting of members of the industry. Interested parties will also be part of the structure.

Unfortunately, the honourable member for Ryan, in what was a typically negative and visionless contribution, indeed a very inflexible one, said that this Bill was badly thought out, that the Authority would be less efficient and less accountable than the previous structure, that there would be a more expensive structure, and that the Minister was reneging on his responsibility for oversight of safety. As usual, honourable members opposite complained that there had been no consultation. They complained that, while this issue was raised in September 1986, there had been no consultation, but at the same time they said that the Government had been too hasty. Indeed, as always seems to be the case in these issues, the Opposition cannot get its act together. Honourable members opposite complained that there would be a decrease in accessibility to the Department yet at the same time they complained that previously the Department had been inaccessible. It seems that whatever structure we determine, whatever way we decide to go in managing aviation in this country, the Opposition is not satisfied with what will happen.

Concerns were expressed about the costs of the new Civil Aviation Authority. Indeed, I suppose they are reasonable concerns, but that is all they are. If honourable members understood what is happening within the Department at present they would also understand that there is almost 100 per cent cost recovery in all those areas in which the Department will levy costs on the industry. Indeed, those areas relate particularly to the setting and provision of services-air traffic control, flight crew testing and other services. The setting and monitoring of safety standards will be paid for by an allocation under the Budget. The Civil Aviation Authority will undertake those activities under government contract. There will not be a significant change and, therefore, there should not be a significant change in the cost structure.

Indeed, the Authority will be accountable for its actions. It will be necessary for the Authority to establish a financial and corporate plan, and financial targets and performance indicators will be taken into account. The financial plan may have to be varied according to circumstances, but it will not be an open-ended runaway authority. It will be possible for the Minister to vary or disapprove charges. Indeed, the Prices Surveillance Authority will scrutinise those charges. On top of that the Authority is establishing advisory committees and in its extensive consultations will be talking with those in the industry and with consumer organisations, and I doubt very much whether many of the concerns raised by the honourable member for Ryan have any substance at all.

Indeed, it is likely that there will be significant changes in technology in this area. That is already occurring. The honourable member for Farrer raised one or two questions that I believe deserve a satisfactory response from the Minister. It is likely that there will be significant technological changes that will bring about cost savings and substantial improvements in the efficiency and effectiveness of the existing surveillance and air traffic control measures.

That brings me to what is perhaps for those who travel on aeroplanes or any sort of public transport one of the most important issues, and that is safety. Indeed, as a number of speakers have said, Australia has an outstanding air safety record. While we can pat ouselves on the back for that, I believe that the points that have been made are valid. We have very good weather in Australia, the terrain is perhaps much less forbidding than that in many other countries, we have lower population densities and our pilot training is of a high standard. For all those reasons, we should have a very good safety record. It is important that we continue to maintain that record. Concern has been expressed in all sorts of areas that the deregulation that the Government proposes will in some way operate to the detriment of our safety record.

It is salutary to look at the results of some experience overseas. In the United States, in the nine years since deregulation occurred in 1978 there have been 26 significant crashes, with a total of 960 deaths. It is interesting that in the eight years before 1978-a shorter period-there were 38 crashes and 1,455 deaths. So in the United States it seems that there has been no increase in the number of fatalities since deregulation, although I am not saying that that situation is necessarily a result of deregulation. However, when one considers that 60 per cent more people are flying now than flew in 1978, the figures are even more compelling in suggesting that there need not be any falling away in safety standards because of deregulation.

I remember, when I was a student, one of my teachers continually talking to us about survival. A phrase he used was: `The price of life is eternal vigilance', and when it comes to safety in the air that is clearly the case. It is necessary for us to ensure that the operation of air traffic control and flight advisory services and regulation of the aircraft and its crew come under the same roof, because those two areas of function are complementary to each other. Indeed, overseas experience shows that the body that sets the standards and the one that is responsible day to day for the operation and for regulating that control are most efficient and effective if they come under the one roof. So it is appropriate that those functions be transferred to the CAA and that the Authority be responsible for them.

In the second reading speech the point is made clearly that the primacy of safety over commercial considerations must be observed by the Authority at all times. The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation will remain within the Department and be directly responsible to the Minister and therefore to this Parliament. It will not thus be necessary for the Authority to judge its own performance, and that is entirely appropriate.

It is also important that aviation security be under the control of the Department. Indeed, presently a report of the task force is pending on the future of aviation security. The honourable member for Farrer has mentioned the threat of hijacks. The risk of interference with aeroplanes is a matter we would all like to see eliminated. Of course, it is hoped that this legislation will provide a more efficient and effective functioning for civil aviation in this country. We intend to establish this Authority bearing in mind the cost considerations and, most importantly, the safety considerations involved with civil aviation in this country. I have pleasure in supporting the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am somewhat concerned about just where this Civil Aviation Bill and the establishment of the Civil Aviation Authority in this manner will take us. Unfortunately, the previous speaker, the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth), did not allay too many of my fears as to the direction in which the Bill will take us. I extend my sincere congratulations to the honourable member for Perth on his comments about safety standards in the United States following deregulation. When I have raised this issue in the House previously, I have been howled down by members of the Government saying that deregulation equalled unsafe air practices and that the United States was the great example. The honourable member for Perth is right: there has been no reduction in safety standards in the United States. In terms of the figures he quoted-and they are correct-it would seem that the situation has improved. I hope that in future other members of the Government will take these facts on board when they enter some of the debates on aviation we have from time to time.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Government first decided to set about establishing a Civil Aviation Authority, quite frankly I was pleased with that decision. It seemed to me that that was probably the logical way to go. Civil aviation authorities existed in most Western countries and had worked quite successfully. One of the great difficulties I have with this legislation is my inability to find out just how far it will go and just what are the real implications. I join the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) in saying that some of the information available to the Opposition and the industry has been scant, to say the least. We should press the Government to let us know more about this matter, especially in light of the fact that the establishment of the Civil Aviation Authority is already taking place and is expected to be completed by 1 May. It is only a few days to 1 May, yet we do not have answers to our questions.

The Opposition has some real areas of concern, one being just what the new aviation authority will deliver us if it is set up in this form. What worries me is that it appears that we will get the same people in the same jobs with the same terms and conditions of employment as we have had previously. We really have no answer to the question of exactly where the cost savings will be made. From reading the legislation and the Minister's Press releases, it would appear to me that it will emerge after the establishment of the CAA that air transport will cost the Australian travelling public a great deal more than it does today.

It would not be unfair to highlight in terms of staffing what has happened with the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC). One thing that distressed me was that a staff ceiling limit was placed on the Corporation of, I think, 1,200. Already staffing of the Corporation is up to 1,600-400 over. What sorts of control will apply to the number of staff members associated with the new CAA? In areas such as air traffic control, what benefits will really accrue? Are we really convinced that establishing the CAA in its present guise will make air traffic control handling at, say, Sydney's Kingsford-Smith Airport any better than it is now? Is there any real indication that there is a dedication from the people going over to the CAA from the old Department to carry out a major investigation of procedures, and will the staff adopt them?

What will be the nature of the Board of the CAA? It would seem to me that it will be pretty top heavy with members of the Public Service. Why are airline representatives not involved with the Board and management of the new CAA? Although we have heard from the Minister that there has been consultation with the industry, I have found from speaking to representatives of the industry that the biggest criticism they have is that they have not really been consulted and do not really know what is going on. It is also fair to say that there is a real fear in the industry about how the cost recovery program will operate.

The matter of revaluation of the assets has already been mentioned in the debate. It is true that some of those assets-and we have very valuable pieces of property and facilities-have been there for a long time and have been written down and paid for. Will we go through the whole procedure whereby they are revalued to the extent that assets were revalued by the Federal Airports Corporation? As I understand it, when that initial transfer came about, the assets were valued at about $250m. I understand that there has been a revaluation and the assets of the FAC now stand at $1 billion, and some sort of cost recovery program is being considered to cover almost $800m. That translates into further costs to the industry of about $100m per year. Will that also exist in regard to the revaluation of the CAA assets? What does that mean? Very few people on this side of the House would argue against the principle of `user pays'. For how much longer can the consumers of Australia continue to pay for this very expensive operation that has been gone through by the FAC and, quite possibly, will be gone through by the newly established CAA?

What other areas will be looked at in terms of savings? There is a great deal of concern, for example, within the industry regarding the cost of providing the fire fighting services. Will that really be looked at or does this direct transfer of the same personnel mean that the present situation will prevail? These are truly the areas about which we on this side of the House must continue to express our concern. I think that the principle of the CAA is probably right. The structure of the CAA as presented by the Government in this legislation leaves a lot to be desired. As I say, I think the real problem that I face is that I understand it to be a much more costly operation for the airlines and the users of these systems. Obviously, that will be passed down to the consumers. This is occurring at a time when, more than ever before, we should be looking at trying to get those costs into true perspective and trying to provide the cheapest possible air services, not only for the development of air travel within Australia but also as an added inducement for the continuing growth of tourism, especially international tourism to this country. If we continue along this line the path could be fraught with danger and with the prospect of even greater costs for the consumers of Australia.

Therefore, reluctantly, I will have to vote against this legislation. I am sorry that this has happened because I thought that there was some real potential for the establishment of the Civil Aviation Authority as an independent body. But that independence does not appear to be there. Quite frankly, we seem to be stuck with the same personnel in the same positions under the same Public Service contracts, run by a board that is dominated by the Public Service. I really wonder what the Government is hoping to achieve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was disappointed to hear the final comments of the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) who usually makes a very considered contribution to debates in this Parliament on tourism and air travel. I am disappointed that the Opposition apparently has decided to oppose the Civil Aviation Bill 1988 because in many ways it is the sort of legislation which should receive bipartisan support from all members of this House. The reason I say that is I believe this Bill is simply a mechanism for improving the efficiency of Australia's airline industry. It seeks to establish a new Civil Aviation Authority (CAA), an independent statutory authority which will have responsibility for areas such as air traffic control, flight advisory services, communication and navigation, and the rescue and fire fighting services which were mentioned by the honourable member for Fadden.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) is correct in seeking to place these responsibilities in the hands of an independent statutory authority rather than leaving these day to day decisions in the hands of a department of state. There is evidence that statutory authorities have in the past been more efficient in operating in areas such as this. I am disappointed that members of the Opposition have had to seek to find some reason to oppose this Bill. I really do not think their hearts are in it. I hope that before this debate is over they will reconsider their position.

In regard to the criticisms by members of the Opposition, so far they have said that there has not been enough consultation with the industry about the establishment of the Civil Aviation Authority. The Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Evans, publicly announced on 7 October last year that the Civil Aviation Authority would be established. Yet the Opposition claims that there has not been enough time for the industry to be involved in consultation. The fact that the announcement was made last October demonstrates that that is incorrect.

In addition, the Opposition has said that the industry is concerned about the extent of cost recovery. I suppose it is quite natural for anyone involved in the commercial side of the aviation industry to be concerned about any cost implications. The last figures that I saw show that only 15 per cent of Australians had ever flown, which is a surprisingly low figure. Because only a small percentage of Australians use the airline industry I think that we should not be placing an economic burden on the taxpayers of Australia as a whole to subsidise the air travel of that small number, 15 per cent or less, who fly regularly.

It is important that we make sure that our airline industry has the highest safety standards and yet is run efficiently, in a lean and cost-effective manner, because the tourist industry is greatly dependent on the cost structure of the airline industry. Given that the number of overseas tourists visiting Australia is expanding rapidly-to a large extent due to the efforts of the former tourism Minister, the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown), and other people such as Mr Paul Hogan and the fact that the excellent campaigns run by this Government overseas have had a great deal of success-it is important that we make sure that our airline industry, and in particular our airports, can handle the massive expansion which is continuing to take place.

Every time overseas tourists come to Australia they spend money and help to create jobs in Australia. I read somewhere that the average Japanese tourist earns Australia approximately as much export revenue as would 60 tonnes of black coal. I am not sure how accurate that figure is, but given the number of Japanese tourists who appear to be landing in Sydney these days, I am sure that that is certainly helping our balance of payments situation. It is not fair to expect the ordinary taxpayer to subsidise the cost of our airline industry. It is not fair to expect the overwhelming majority of Australian taxpayers, who do not fly, to subsidise the cost of air traffic control and the fire fighting services at airports.

A great deal of time has been spent in discussing the question of safety. Of course, the new Civil Aviation Authority will have responsibility not only for setting the standards which will apply to our Australian industry but also for policing them. As the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) rightly said, it is commendable that the body which sets the standards will also police them, because it is more likely that the Civil Aviation Authority will do a tighter job in policing those standards.

Australia has an enviable record as far as air safety is concerned. This is not only due to the Australian Government over many years setting very high standards but to a large extent it is also due to the fact that Qantas Airways Ltd, Ansett Airlines of Australia, Australian Airlines and most of the smaller general aviation airlines have maintained very high standards of maintenance. I recall hearing that whenever Ansett or Australian Airlines decide that a particular plane has come to the end of its economic life and they wish to sell it overseas or to another company, they always receive very high prices because other airlines know that Australia has very high maintenance standards. They are prepared to pay a premium if they know that a plane has been flown exclusively in Australia and has been maintained to those very high safety standards. The airlines should be commended for maintaining high safety standards over many years. They should realise that all of us on both sides of this House expect those very high safety and maintenance standards to be maintained in the years ahead.

The honourable member for Fadden again made a point which he has made previously in debates in this House. He said that in his opinion deregulation in the United Stated of America has not resulted in any decrease in the safety standards in that country. The honourable member for Perth quoted some figures demonstrating that the number of people who have died as a result of aircraft accidents has fallen since deregulation occurred. I question the validity of using that as a fair measure of the safety standards in the United States. Given the number of passenger trips in the United States, simply to pluck out the number of people who died over a nine-year period is statistically not a fair measure of the safety standards in the United States. I am aware that there has been a massive increase in the number of fines which the United States domestic aviation authority has levied on United States airlines because they have been found to be not carrying out the proper maintenance of their aircraft. I believe that that is the direct result of deregulation of the United States airline industry. As a result of price wars airlines have been placed under great financial pressure and have had to shave their margins. Some US airlines made the decision that they would cut back their maintenance. A small number of airlines also made the decision that they would not carry out the essential maintenance which is recommended by the manufacturers of those aircraft. I believe that any comparison of the number of fines which have been levied on United States airlines since deregulation, compared with before deregulation, will demonstrate that there has been a reduction in the safety standards in the United States since deregulation occurred. That is why it is so important that this Bill is before the House today.

Our Labor Government has taken the decision to abolish the two-airline policy. This Parliament carried a resolution last year to give notice of the termination of the two-airline agreement. So it is very important that we establish a body such as the Civil Aviation Authority to control independently the safety standards which are enforced in the Australian airline industry. We must ensure that while Australia's airlines are forced to provide air travel at the cheapest possible price, that they do not cut the safety standards which they should apply both in maintaining their aircraft and in the operational procedures which are followed by those aircraft.

The honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) made a few remarks about the threat of hijacking in Australia. I endorse his comments and make the further remark that I believe that the Government has increased the number of baggage inspections and the use of metal detectors for passengers boarding aircraft. I hope that the Government will continue to expand the numbers of items of equipment which have been installed in airports so that within a short period we can ensure that every Australian who boards an aircraft at one of Australia's major airports does go through a metal detector and have his baggage inspected. I think in that way we can ensure that Australia is not some sort of a weak link for those people who wish to use terrorism to extract some sort of blackmail.

Finally, I commend the Government for the work it is doing at Sydney international airport. Many people say that Sydney Airport-to use that hackneyed expression-is a weak link in Australia's current system of airports because of the fact that its capacity is close to the maximum traffic which can be handled at Sydney. I commend the Government for deciding to spend over $10m on improving the taxiways at Mascot Airport which allows aircraft to enter and exit the taxiways more quickly without having to come to a complete halt. This enables more aircraft per hour to use the main runways. In addition, $20m has been allocated to upgrading the radar services at Sydney international airport. At the moment there are three operational radars and two are to be commissioned during this year, including a surface movement control radar which is currently being handed over at Mascot. Again, that will help to ensure that we can use Sydney International Airport as efficiently as possible. But we should not forget that whilst Sydney International Airport certainly comes under a lot of pressure, it is usually under pressure for only a very small period each day. The largest number of jumbo jets and Boeing 747s take off and land at Sydney International Airport early in the morning and late at night. As a result the facilities at Mascot are not fully utilised most of the day. That is why I commend the Government's decision to introduce over time a pricing policy which encourages general aviation aircraft to use Sydney International Airport during the off-peak periods.

In the long term this Government has taken the historic decision to build Sydney's second international airport at Badgerys Creek. That will be the long term answer to Sydney's airport needs. For some reason overseas tourists wish to travel to Sydney to see one of the greatest cities of the world. They are not that keen on visiting places such as Melbourne, although I notice that an increasing number of overseas tourists appear to be visiting Queensland. I am sure that that is very helpful to the Queensland tourist industry, but I believe that the Government has a responsibility to ensure that funds are allocated at Badgerys Creek so that by the turn of the century we have a modern, international airport at Badgerys Creek which can handle the massive numbers of tourists who are already seeking to spend their tourist dollars in Sydney.

TALK.START.PARA: —They want to go to Sydney, not Badgerys Creek.

—As the honourable member suggests, they wish to go to Sydney, not Badgerys Creek. Given the fact that it takes two hours to travel from Narita International Airport to central Tokyo, I am sure that they will be quite happy to spend less than an hour travelling from Badgerys Creek to the centre of Sydney. Given the fact also that many of the major ring roads in the Sydney arterial road network pass near Badgerys Creek, I am sure that our decision to build the second international airport at Badgerys Creek will prove to be one of the best decisions that this Government has taken. I am happy to support the legislation before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Millar Mr P.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing the Civil Aviation Bill which is designed to establish a Civil Aviation Authority, I firstly take up the comment made by the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) which is quite accurate. He alluded to the premium track to aircraft on the Australian register, regular public transport aircraft in particular, on disposal to foreign interests. That premium is attracted by the extremely high level of maintenance required under the Air Navigation Orders and the Air Navigation Regulations or, in short, the Department which has been responsible for these activities over a long time. If we have achieved that happy circumstance, if we enjoy, without dwelling on the extraneous reasons for so doing, the highest safety record in the world, one could fairly ask, `Why the need for change? Why move things sideways, establish a quango to achieve that which demonstrably thus far has been achieved with outstanding success?'.

SPEECH.PARA: Is this just another instance of shuffling to and fro, reaching for unattainable heights, something which, in the end, might be described as an exercise in horizontal arabesque, much activity and no demonstrable benefit in the ultimate? The Opposition is not instantly attracted to this particular proposal which brings with it the risk of further empire building- a pernicious characteristic of bureaucracy. I say that without any antagonistic overtones, having been a proud Federal public servant for quite a number of years further back than I care to remember, but I have a feeling for the job the airlines have to do. They have achieved all that which the Australian public and the industry would have expected in terms of aircraft safety.

There is a continuing disenchantment as to the sharing of the costs attaching to the provision of this infrastructure. It is a very costly business. Again, as the honourable member for Dobell said, there is nothing more useless than a very costly airport facility if it is not being used by aircraft at any given time. It links somewhat with the airman's understanding that any runway behind him, whether he is taking off or landing, is of no further use to him. The same could perhaps be said of an airport which is not at any given time being used for its purpose. Aviation facilities are a very costly asset to this country and it is understandable that there might be an inclination to establish a cost recovery system which would mitigate to some extent the heavy imposition on the taxpayer, borne cheerfully or with a varying degree of enthusiasm, in respect of a whole lot of activities which governments, in the order of events, seek to provide.

I am concerned that, in metaphoric terms, we are charging into this proposal-we are renowned, of course, for never charging in any meaningful way into anything; it seems to take an inordinate time from the germ of the idea to its implementation-while we are not yet satisfied that the proposal is well based. The Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans), in announcing the Government's intention to set up the Authority, said:

The operation of air traffic control and the flight advisory service is as much a part of safety regulation as the regulation of the aircraft and its crew. The two areas complement each other. I am certain that the departmental officers who have made such a splendid contribution to our aviation safety in the context of integrated safety and operational functions within the Department will continue to do so in the new Authority.

Again, the question arises: Why? We just cannot move 7,000 people out of an established department and put them into a new authority, a quango, without attracting a very substantial cost for its establishment in simple physical terms. Those people are being exorcised, if you like, and there must by some shelter to accommodate them, with restructuring at various levels. On the Minister's own proud statement, the doubt as to the essential merits of the proposal again come into stark focus. It is quite possible-I am not presuming the outcome of the Bill's consideration in the Senate-that the Civil Aviation Authority will come into existence, notwithstanding arguments advanced as to why that should not be so. As I say, we are charging into this. Quite often we find that measures embarked upon with great enthusiasm prove in hindsight to be of less merit than was imagined in prospect. I rather thought that the Minister for Transport and Communications Support (Mr Peter Morris), with some flying experience to his credit, would be aware --

TALK.START.PARA: —A short take-off.

—A short take-off, as the honourable member for Dawson says. Honourable members can place their own constructions on that remark. The Minister should be fully aware that, if one seeks to attain heights beyond the capacity of one's aircraft, the angle of attack becomes too great and the aircraft will inevitably stall. I wonder whether the Minister is not embarking now on such a flight into fantasy. If that is the case the Authority will have matters to consider.

SPEECH.PARA: In this fairly wide-ranging debate this morning I have heard a number of worthwhile contributions and comments about various facets of the aviation industry. I heard comments about passenger security and airport security. Sadly, in this world today, that is becoming an increasingly important requirement. As a regular passenger transport user, I am a little mystified to discover that there is a significant variable in the security checks at respective airports. I wonder why, in the same configuration-for want of a more precise term-I can walk through a detector at one airport without raising a beep and at the next airport raise more than a beep, almost a scream of protest.
