The officer in attendance will subject one to an examination with a hand detector to the point where one becomes increasingly overwhelmed with embarrassment as everybody in the airport terminal concentrates his gaze, convinced that at last a security threat has been found. Apart from the matter of personal embarrassment, the question arises: Why is there quite clearly a disparity in performance between what, notionally at least, should be identical security check facilities? The Authority will have to look at that.

The Authority is to assume responsibility for air traffic control. Again, this is something which has notional difficulties but which, certainly on the statement of the Minister, has been managed effectively by the Department hitherto. Yet one finds at different airports at different times a lack of consistency in the handling of air traffic by duty controllers. One cannot sit at an airport for 24 hours to see whether the pattern is constant throughout the 24 hours of the day or whatever period in which the airport is operating, but it is quite clear that in some situations, in the view of seasoned travellers and those who have first hand experience in the handling of aircraft, the sequencing of flights should not be as much of a variable as it proves to be at times.

There seems to be scant regard on occasions for different aircraft types and their movements. The essential sequencing for safety reasons between departures to accommodate wake turbulence varies according to the conditions prevailing-wind factors and so forth. It is frustrating in the extreme to be sitting in an Airbus, holding at a taxi point awaiting clearance to line up, and see in the distance the lights of an approaching aircraft at an estimated 10 miles on long final and to find out a considerable time later that one has been waiting for a twin engined commuter aircraft-a Navajo or something of the sort-which has a negligible wake turbulence factor, that there are not other movements on cross runways and there is nothing taxiing. To the conditioned observer, let alone the trained or skilled observer, it is quite clear that air traffic controllers at a given time will maintain a degree of separation which is altogether different from that which may be maintained in another place or at the same place at a different time. There must be some consistency. If that sort of anomaly or phenomenon is attributable to the lack of experience of an air traffic controller at a given time and he is factoring movements to ensure that he does not err, that would give rise to considerable concern.

The question of air safety, of course, is possessed of the elements of motherhood. We believe in it; yet, as the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell)-a member of the Government-pointed out this morning, there is arguably an incredible sum of money directed towards avoiding accidents or attending accidents in the aircraft movement area. He put the point quite reasonably and persuasively that we seem to have a different philosophy towards those who travel in aircraft and those who travel by other modes of transport, particularly on the road. Day after day we are confronted with horrendous statistics of people who have suffered injury or death on the roads. We become, sadly, almost blase about them; yet we seem subject to a compulsion to spend millions of dollars on maintaining a service, both in safety and rescue, including fire fighting facilities, which sit year after year at considerable cost when they are rarely utilised in a situation for which they are intended. I am not suggesting for one moment that we vacate that area, but one must make a judgment-a philosophical judgment if you like: a subjective judgment-as to how far along the road we can go in terms of expenditure to accommodate that which might be regarded as desirable but which by any pragmatic measurement is not really attainable. It is a misallocation of resources.

The honourable member for Dobell also touched upon deregulation. Statements were made to the effect that deregulation has not resulted in any abuse of standards of air safety, aircraft maintenance and the like. I think the statistics extrapolated from that circumstance as to the number of accidents that have occurred post-deregulation as opposed to those that occurred pre-deregulation are totally unreliable. I must say that I am totally unattracted to the suggestion implicit in giving the figures that in deregulation we have no reason whatsoever to feel a concern about abuses that might arise under economic pressure where airlines are struggling to survive. An airline does not go out of business at 5 p.m. on a Thursday. It will go out of business over a protracted period, several months, while it struggles to remain viable before it is, usually, bankrupted.

I read a report from the United States of America which stated that a 727, I think it was-an aircraft of similar type-had made 19 regular public transport flights beyond the mandatory period for maintenance. They were illegal flights. I have a passing sympathy for operators of the airline. They were trying to stay afloat, and human nature is such that there is an almost irresistible tendency to cut corners or take a chance. This is quite intolerable in this area. To my knowledge, this has not been the case in Australia-under the tutelage of the Department, not some abstruse quango which may or may not do the job; that remains to be seen.

I think we have to address ourselves to maintaining our record. I cannot accept that the Department as presently structured lacks the talent or the will to do that which must be done. It may be possible to energise it to a greater extent. I do not wish to be peremptory in my judgments on that score but I would be surprised indeed if the Department were climbing at full throttle in this area. I think the matter should stay with the Department and it should address itself urgently to maintaining Australia's proud history in the aviation world. We are pioneers of flight. The records of international flights feature very largely the names of Australians whom we remember very proudly.

I think general aviation should be the Department's first priority in terms of relief from cost recovery. We should do all we can in a country of this character to ensure that general aviation is a burgeoning activity. There is a spin-off benefit for defence. We could relate it to the predicament we are now confronted with with the defence forces being seriously depleted by transfers to Qantas Airways Ltd and other airlines for reasons that are self-evident. I think general aviation should be based on a cost structure which means that very few Australians who are minded to take to the skies are denied that privilege and that benefit. As I said in the first place, the Civil Aviation Authority may well be implemented but there is little reason for the Opposition being enthused about that prospect on the evidence presently before it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DUNCAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Education Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank honourable members for their involvement in this debate. I heard quite an amount of it and I appreciate the concerns that have been expressed. I think they were expressed genuinely and sincerely. Particularly in the case of the contribution of the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar), I do not think he was in any way being political about this matter. In fact, the Civil Aviation Bill is not a Bill which might be said to divide us on ideological or any other grounds of that sort. These are matters for judgment. The Government believes that we have made the correct judgments in relation to the decision to set up the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA), with which I had some involvement, of course, a little while ago.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to go through the main issues that have been raised by honourable members. Of course, I am as concerned as other members about safety in particular. This matter has been considered at great length within both the Department of Transport and Communications and the Government to ensure that in moving towards the establishment of the Authority we get it right, that we make the best decisions in relation to safety. The Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Gareth Evans, made it quite clear in his October statement that safety regulation would continue to be of paramount importance and the Authority will be required to give primacy to safety considerations over commercial ones. That was made clear also in the second reading speech. The Government is committed to seeing that the bodies responsible for standard setting, operational control and safety investigation will be able to ensure that safety regulation and surveillance are in no way diminished, and to the extent that the industry has been calling for some time for the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation to be separated from the regulatory agency, that is being achieved in this Bill. That is an example of the Government responding to concerns in the industry.

Additionally, in considering appointments to the board of the Authority, the Government will be looking to ensure that an appropriate range of expertise is included. Senior operational and technical experts of the Authority will be eligible for appointment and in making those appointments the necessary safety considerations will be taken into account. The Authority is empowered to establish advisory bodies, and should the board decide to establish one or more bodies there would be scope for industry representation, thereby ensuring that it has a direct input into discussions of the nature and extent of services which the Authority might provide. Considerations such as safety particularly could be taken into account in setting up those bodies.

Some honourable members raised the issue of whether there was a need to establish such an authority, and I should like to make a couple of points in relation to that. As was outlined in the second reading speech, it has been the policy of successive governments that costs should be recovered from the industry and, given this policy, the body providing the services should be so structured as to make it what could be described as adequately responsible to industry's requirements and to industry's capacity and willingness to meet associated costs.

Departments of state are of necessity bound by government processes which reduce their capacity to perform with the responsiveness and flexibility of an authority operating along commercial lines. The penalty for this constraint has generally impacted upon the level and timing of investment in infrastructure and upon costs both to the industry and to taxpayers. I am sure honourable members who have airports in their electorates would know the sort of thing I am talking about. Advances in technology, particularly in the communications field, offer the potential to develop a more cost-efficient airways system through a major program of investment. The Authority will have far greater freedom and control over financing of and expenditures on such investment programs than is possible within a department of state funded entirely from the Commonwealth Budget. A greater flexibility in the operations of the Authority will enable it to be more responsive to industry requirements, particularly in the planning for future infrastructure needs. We believe they are the fundamental reasons why we should have an authority rather than continue with the existing arrangements.

Specifically, I think some honourable members raised the issue of why safety regulatory functions were being transferred to the Authority. They could have been left in the Department. That was an option that obviously was available. The Australian experience to date indicates that there is a strong logic in the view that the task of regulating aviation safety must be regarded as one requiring an integrated system in which all elements are coordinated to achieve maximum reliability and effectiveness. The operation of air traffic control and the flight advisory service are as much a part of the safety regulations as the regulation of aircraft and their crews. The two areas complement each other.

It is noteworthy that in the United Kingdom the CAA has very successfully combined safety regulation with the operation of the airways system. This arrangement was adopted after a formal review on the basis that the setting of standards, regulatory control and the day to day operation of the airways system should be under single control in the interests of efficiency and effectiveness because of the close interrelationships involved. In contrast, the Bureau of Air Safety, as I have mentioned, will be separate from the Authority and will remain with the Department, being directly responsible to the Minister.

No decision has been taken at this stage as to the composition of the board of the Authority. The legislation provides for a nine-member board, as honourable members will know. This will give the Government flexibility to ensure that appointees bring a broad cross-section of skills to the Authority. The Government will be looking to the business sector for people with expertise in financial matters and in general management. Given the Government's commitment to the primacy of the safety of civil aviation operations over commercial considerations, it has been left open for experts of the Authority to be appointed to the board also. Every effort will be made to ensure that there is a proper mix of skills at board level in the light of the particular requirements of the Authority and that adequate attention is paid to consumer interests and industrial relations aspects, which in this area are particularly important.

Consistent with its policies for Commonwealth statutory authorities and government business enterprises, the board appointments will be undertaken at ministerial level. The Authority will be expected to operate in a businesslike way and to perform its role in a cost-effective manner. It is the Government's belief that this method of board appointment will lead to greater accountability, thereby ensuring that these objectives are met.
Some honourable members, I understand, expressed their concern that the staffing of the new Authority is to be under the Public Service Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —A lot of these issues you were raising were not raised. They are in the briefing notes.

—I understand that this is a matter of some concern to people. Therefore, it needs to be dealt with. In the introduction of the Public Service reform legislation in 1984 and the Public Service streamlining legislation in 1986 provision was made to give senior management a much greater degree of flexibility in the management of their staff than had been the case previously. The authority to move staff and to create and abolish positions was increased considerably. The Public Service Act as it now stands is considered to provide a sufficient degree of management flexibility for the Civil Aviation Authority. Given this, there are advantages in continuing to employ staff of the Authority under the Public Service Act, as present terms and conditions of employment of staff will continue to apply. This will facilitate the transfer of staff to the Authority and diminish the administrative task of the Authority in the establishment phase. This will allow management effort to be devoted to the Authority's primary tasks. The expertise that exists within the airways section of the Department exists nowhere else in the nation at present. It would be hard to gather together a body of expertise of that nature. Quite clearly, we should look to those people to provide the basis for the staff of the new Authority when it is formed.

SPEECH.PARA: Matters of concern about costs to industry were raised. A number of controls and related matters are relevant to the question of cost containment. An important element, which was mentioned in the second reading speech, is that this legislation reflects the Government's guidelines which seek to ensure a proper balance between the need to remove detailed controls over the operations of statutory authorities, on the one hand, and the need to ensure that these authorities remain accountable for their actions, on the other hand. The Authority will be required to provide the Minister with detailed projections of its finances over a rolling three-year period, which is covered in its corporate plan, including estimates of receipts and expenditures for each year. The Minister is empowered to direct the Authority to vary its financial plan in respect of financial targets and performance indicators.

The Minister also has the power to disapprove charges which the Authority might wish to levy. The impact of the charges on operators may feature in any examination made by the Prices Surveillance Authority, which is a further scrutiny adding to the discipline of cost containment. The Government will require the Authority to be responsive to the needs of industry. Indeed, the legislation stipulates that in the performance of its functions it shall consult with commercial, industrial and consumer organisations.

The Bill deserves the support of the Parliament. It has been brought before the Parliament after a great deal of scrutiny and work within the Public Service and within the Government. I commend the Bill to the House.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Motion (by Mr Duncan) proposed:
That the Bill be now read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address briefly, under standing order 238, the third reading stage of the Civil Aviation Bill. I refer to the reply of the Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan) to the second reading debate. I want to place on record that that reply was in abstract. It did not reflect the debate which took place on the Bill this morning. For example, it did not pick up any of the excellent points made by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell), or the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar), on the variations in levels of security, and it did not refer to my comments on hijacking and variations in radar standards right around Australia. It was clearly prepared prior to this debate even taking place on the floor of the House, and as such it was a wrong approach.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I reiterate that the reply was prepared in abstract to the real debate that took place on the floor of the House. It did, by accident, happen to touch on some of the aspects raised by honourable members but by and large it ignored the contents of contributions to the debate from both sides of the House. As such it tampered with the will of this House. It undermined the procedures of this Parliament, and the Minister for Employment and Education Services, who has served in two Parliaments in Australia and who is a parliamentarian of some experience, ought to be ashamed of himself for picking up a brief in the closing stages of a debate and not in any way making any effort to relate to the debate on the floor of the House on this important piece of legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: SUPERANNUATION BENEFIT (INTERIM ARRANGEMENT) BILL 1988[COGNATE BILL:DEFENCE (SUPERANNUATION INTERIM ARRANGEMENT) AMENDMENT BILL 1988]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 April, on motion by Mr Duncan:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand it is the wish of the House to debate the Superannuation Benefit (Interim Arrangement) Bill concurrently with the Defence (Superannuation Interim Arrangement) Amendment Bill. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Superannuation Benefit (Interim Arrangement) Bill and the Defence (Superannuation Interim Arrangement) Amendment Bill puts into effect decisions made by the Government to provide for an increase in superannuation, ostensibly under the guise of an increase in productivity. Honourable members will recall that, in September 1985, as part of the accord mark 2, the Government agreed to support the claims of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) for superannuation benefits, at that time equivalent to 3 per cent of ordinary time earnings, which would be granted to all wage and salary earners on the basis of increased national productivity. The Opposition, while supporting the extension of superannuation at that time, condemned the 3 per cent productivity agreement as yet another example of the ACTU being able to dominate Government wages policy. We said then and we have repeated since that that approach ignored the capacity of industry to pay because there is a tendency to presume that by some extraordinary accounting methodology it is possible to isolate superannuation costs from overall employment costs.

SPEECH.PARA: The simple fact of the matter is that whether one gives improvements in terms and conditions in the form of superannuation or in the form of wages there is an additional cost to employers. At that particular time, when Australia was fighting to compete on world markets, when it was being argued that our productivity remained too low, as it still is today, we were concerned that what was effectively an obligatory 3 per cent superannuation arrangement-although the word `compulsion' was not used by the Government, and wisely so-in the real world of the interrelationships between trade unions and employers this was seen as a fait accompli virtually across the full spectrum of the Australian industrial relations scene. In addition to that there was no requirement for a demonstrable increase in productivity as the basis for the payment and we believe it denied employers the right to enter voluntarily into superannuation agreements with their employees.

Subsequently, in June 1986, the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in the national wage case decided to reject the ACTU's productivity claim. However, it decided that it would ratify agreements negotiated by employers and employees for additional superannuation benefits as long as they were consistent with the Commission's own guidelines.

In March 1987, in the national wage case decision, the Commission reconsidered its earlier position and decided that where the parties were unable to negotiate an agreement the Commission would arbitrate. It would award no more than 1.5 per cent of ordinary time earnings, to operate no earlier than 1 January 1988, and no more than a further 1.5 per cent, bringing it to a total of 3 per cent, to operate no earlier than 1 January 1989.

With regard to the extension of the 3 per cent increase to the public sector, we said that the additional costs could not be justified, because most Commonwealth employees already had access to superannuation schemes or arrangements which were generally seen as being generous when compared with most areas of the private sector. Nevertheless the Government claims it entered into negotiations with the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the postal and telecommunications unions and the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association, which were concluded on 22 December 1987. One wonders, since we were not privy to the actual basis of these negotiations, to what extent they took into account the need to increase productivity.

I think one could be forgiven for drawing the conclusion, because it was certainly consistent with Government policy, that the real objective was to provide the 3 per cent superannuation increase to all public servants, irrespective of whether there was any prior condition-namely, increased productivity-in place. Consequently, we now have before us an interim Bill. We are told that the arrangement providing for the 3 per cent is going to affect advantageously, some 75,000 public servants who, not being permanent public servants, have not in the past qualified for superannuation under the Commonwealth's Superannuation Fund Investment Trust arrangements.

It is precisely for that reason that the Opposition is not opposing this Bill. It is fundamental to our approach to superannuation that the sooner we can reach the situation where all people in the work force have at least the opportunity to make provision for their retirement income, the better. The fact is that for a long time some 75,000 public servants-which covers a very wide range of services, including, for example, people who may have been on the payroll for many years but who, for various reasons, were never taken on as permanent public servants-have up till now been denied access to superannuation. We believe the fundamental issue has to be addressed, not just the question of providing 3 per cent, which is an impossibly small amount of money, which will provide no significant benefits in retirement.

In fact, an analysis done of this on the basis of anticipated average weekly earnings would suggest that the benefits accruing from 3 per cent over, say, a 30- to 40-year period would total the grand sum of $18 or $19 a week. Quite clearly, in terms of the size of the current pension which is close to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings, that is not a satisfactory basis on which superannuation should be seen in the future.

However, if the obverse of that argument is that we are only seeing the beginning of the 3 per cent issue and that in due course it is going to go up from 3 per cent to 4 per cent and to 5 per cent, et cetera until it finally gets to somewhere between 9 per cent and 12 1/2 per cent-which I hasten to advise the House is the sort of contribution rate one needs if one is talking about a decent superannuation scheme which will ensure that the beneficiaries have an income in retirement which will either keep them out of the pension arrangement or reduce the level of pension to which they are entitled and at the same time give them an adequate standard of living in retirement-clearly we have a long way to go.

If we are seeing, as I suspect we are, only the beginning of this trend and Australian employers-irrespective of their capacity to pay, irrespective of whether or not they already have a suitable superannuation scheme in place-are still going to be required to fund a further significant increase in superannuation, without any contribution whatever from their employees, I simply put to the Government that the approach it is taking is going to ensure once again that Australia's level of productivity will not necessarily increase to the extent that it should and, worst of all, we will remain uncompetitive in world markets because of the impact that this will have on overall costs of labour.

The issues are very complex and it is precisely because we are concerned at the way in which the Government has handled these issues that the Opposition wishes to move an appropriate second reading amendment. I therefore move:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House deplores the Government's failure to develop consistent superannuation policies without imposing additional taxes and its reliance for over 3 years on ``legislation'' by press release causing confusion and lack of confidence in superannuation for those planning their retirement'.

Members of the House and certainly people involved in the superannuation industry are only too well aware of the fact that in May 1983 Treasurer Keating introduced a White Paper into this House and between then and late last year, when we finally had the legislation establishing the framework for superannuation management, the effective administration of occupational superannuation was on the basis of Press releases. Month after month, often conflicting Press releases appeared which caused very real consternation to those whose responsibility it is to administer superannuation in Australia. Let us look at the figures, because they tell their own story.

Some 3.2 million Australians are currently in superannuation schemes and those who support the 3 per cent productivity schemes make the point that there has been a further increase of some 300,000 people under that arrangement. As I said initially, the Opposition welcomes the fact that there has been at least a notional growth in the coverage of superannuation. But let us not be beguiled by the figures, because only a few weeks ago the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) came out with the figures for superannuation coverage over recent years and they contained ample reason for concern. They simply say that the growth of superannuation is now less than 3 per cent. If one accepts that there has been a substantial growth of new people coming in under the 3 per cent schemes, one can only conclude that the stability of the industry has been significantly marred by the events since May 1983, when the changes in the tax rates, anticipating increases in taxation, and general changes in the administration of superannuation have turned what was previously seen as a most stable area of policy, which had had the general support of both Government and Opposition for many years, had suddenly-like health policy, regrettably-been pushed into the front rank of political division and conflict.

In that environment the Government is still claiming that superannuation is a worthwhile investment and that people should be encouraged to put their investments and their savings in that direction. Those ABS figures demonstrate quite clearly that what we are seeing is that many people are dropping out of schemes-and I am not talking about the 3 per cent schemes: I am talking about the more substantial schemes which make a contribution to ultimate retirement income. The question has to be asked, therefore: What can be done to make superannuation once again economically palatable and reliable and an attractive form of investment, so that people who go into it know, or have every reason to expect what is going to be there at the end? We simply cannot ask people in their twenties or early thirties to plan for their sixties and seventies, unless they have that fundamental stability. The sad fact is that since May 1983 that stability has simply not been there.

The Opposition is not opposing all the changes that the Government has introduced in terms of superannuation administration. What we are saying is that the Government has missed some very important opportunities. In the areas of vesting, preservation and portability, for example, we find the key to why superannuation has not met and is not meeting the fundamental objectives for which tax support is provided. The level of tax support provided for superannuation is considerable. We are told by the Department of Finance that in terms of tax forgone as a result of deductabilities the annual cost is about $3.2 billion. The superannuation industry contests that figure and states that it is more like $1.6 billion. It argues, quite rightly, that that bland figure cited by the Department of Finance does not take account of the fact that, while superannuation schemes may make investments that are at that stage tax free, nevertheless the profits gained from those investments and the multiplier effect that results are subject to tax. Unless we are prepared to take into account that multiplier, the industry argues, we are taking a very short term approach.

There are many other areas of government fiscal transfer arrangements where the multiplier effect is presumed to be to the advantage of the nation. That is why tax support is provided in the first place. One could therefore ask: `Why should superannuation be the exception to the rule?'. Notwithstanding that, there has been significant leakage from superannuation for far too long. This is generally referred to as double dipping whereby people can obtain tax support which works out at approximately 50c in the dollar, because the funds put into superannuation by employers attract a tax free status in exactly the same way as do wages and salaries. Therefore, notionally, a person who at retirement obtains a lump sum of, say, $100,000 will find that $50,000 is subject to significant public tax support that would not have been available had those funds been invested elsewhere. Therefore, the issue of double dipping is of profound importance in its effect on tax and equity, which are so fundamental to this issue.

The Opposition remains perplexed that, when the Government had the opportunity to negotiate with the industry, as I understand it did, regarding the changes that should be made to the administration of funds, it failed to make the appropriate references. For example, it avoided the issue of existing schemes by simply saying that any changes will relate only to new schemes or to amended old schemes. The fact is that more than two million Australians are members of old schemes, under which they have the capacity to take at least their contributions plus interest every time they change jobs. While those contributions do not attract the same degree of support in terms of tax as do employer funds, they are supported, because the investment income generated from those contributions remains free of tax until final retirement at age 55.

The issue is whether we have a suitable superannuation arrangement that incorporates three essential elements. First, does it provide people with adequate income for retirement? Secondly, does it reduce access to social security benefits? Thirdly, is it a scheme that benefits the nation in terms of both sociological and economic factors? One would have to say on the basis of that analysis that current arrangements fall far short of the ideal. As I said, the Government has failed in its opportunity to solve some of these problems in the past and all we are hearing at present is a debate on whether or not superannuation should be subject to additional taxes.

All sorts of figures have been bandied about in the Press and other media, in Parliament and elsewhere in recent months regarding the effect on quantum payments of 15 per cent tax or 20 per cent tax and on whether the proposal put forward by the Treasury will be a mixture of the existing 30 per cent tax on lump sums and a new tax on the income generated by the investments of both employers and employees. These are matters of the greatest significance not only to fund managers, not only to the big life companies, not only to members of the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia Ltd (ASFA), not only to people who sell superannuation, but, most importantly of all, to the 2.3 million Australians who are members of schemes. What is worse is that at least an equal number of Australians are not members of superannuation schemes. They are seeing this furore and saying to themselves, `For heaven's sake, why should I take the risk? Why should I be involved in a scheme that, because of constant changes of government policy, is so structured that I do not know what I will get from it in the end?' It is in that context that the trends indicated by the ABS figures are of the gravest concern. One must face up to that reality.

Public Service superannuation is a subject of some disagreement in the community. Regrettably, no-one has ever bothered to explain to the electorate at large what it is all about and there is a perception that Public Service superannuation is significantly more beneficial than private sector superannuation. On a fund for fund basis, there is some substance in that argument. Perhaps the basic difference is that the Public Service superannuant obtains his pension share of superannuation with full indexation and, generally speaking, that is not the position in the private sector. I draw attention to that fact because it is an issue the Government must address. We are told constantly by the superannuation industry and by others that people should be discouraged from taking lump sums, the argument being that if people take lump sums they also take the benefits of the pension when they turn 65. There is ample evidence to suggest that there is substance in that argument.

However, the Government has effectively done nothing through recent regulations to try to protect the public interest, to protect the pension, to ensure that people who do not have adequate income in retirement are provided for. I emphasise that the first of the three elements that should be present in superannuation is not being applied. Therefore, while they have access to a situation in which they can take benefits and a full pension, is it any wonder that people believe that it is a marvellous idea. It totally ignores the fact that 50c in the dollar of the contributions made to the generation of that superannuation fund, whether a lump sum or a pension, is taxpayer funded. The saddest part of all is that those benefits are funded significantly by the millions of taxpayers who do not have superannuation at all. The question of equity is fundamental to this issue and the Government must address that point.

The point I am trying to get to is that Public Service superannuants have access to full indexation but, generally speaking, private sector superannuants do not. Until that issue is addressed it is, in my opinion, a waste of time arguing the case that lump sums should be phased out in favour of pensions. Even blind Freddy knows that within a decade what might have been a very adequate pension on the day of retirement in terms of purchasing power virtually reaches zero, if we assume a rate of inflation of about 1 per cent. It is because of that that indexation is absolutely crucial. At present, the Government is providing a number of investments by which companies and superannuation schemes can obtain access to a degree of indexation. It surprises me, however, that the industry as a whole does not seem to have made use of those methods to the extent it should. The AMP Society, for example, tells me that it could probably provide benefits that attract a level of indexation of about 4 per cent; but we all know that under current arrangements that takes us only half the distance. The question therefore is: Who will make up the rest? What products could the Government sell-as are sold overseas-which would enable schemes and individuals to take up assets that would give them some protection through indexation in retirement? The issue is so fundamental that, until it is addressed, the argument whether people should or should not take lump sums becomes absolutely academic.

One of the issues which make Australia unique in comparison with the rest of the world-because no other country provides lump sums, and I emphasise that fact-is that Australians believe that superannuation is really a means of deferred income they can take on retirement, nowadays at age 55, although some would argue that that is too early. People can take a lump sum in retirement and pay off their house-a very sensible approach-perhaps help their families, or do various other things that they want to do with that sum and live on the remainder until they qualify for the old age pension. Governments must face difficult decisions in relation to these matters, but these are the fundamental issues that must be addressed if we are to make any progress.

In addition there is the question of indexation, which I regard as an absolutely fundamental distinction between public and private superannuation coverage in Australia. Another important matter that the Government should address is the future of superannuation funds run by the States. The last five years or so have seen a radical change-a transformation, in fact-in superannuation coverage, which has had two major effects. First, I refer to the State schemes which were similar to that of the Commonwealth, in that they gave the employers' contribution as a lump sum and the employees' contribution as a pension. The States have finally realised what is obvious. They say, `Why should we have the cost of pensions on our books if we can transfer it to the Commonwealth?' That is precisely what they are doing. They are now saying to employees, `You will take a lump sum in retirement; there will be no indexation; there will be no choice whether you take a pension or a lump sum; there is no question of a pension'. By doing that, the States have significantly reduced the cost of providing retirement income to ex-employees. They have done that fully expecting that the cost is transferred to the Commonwealth and there they imagine it will lie.

Something worse than that has happened. If one analyses the coverage of superannuation in the States one finds another trend. Whereas previously these schemes had been compulsory, as is the case with the Commonwealth, in some States that is no longer so. They are saying to new entrants-and, in the case of South Australia, to old entrants-`If you are not happy with superannuation, you can drop out'. An estimate I have seen suggests that some 33 per cent of State public servants who ought to be in such schemes and who previously probably were have now opted out. Thus we are seeing in the State public sector a deliberate intention to dilute what was meant to be the fundamental objective of superannuation-to encourage people to be independent in their retirement.

The Government must use its influence in the States, particularly with those with governments of Labor persuasion, to try to bring this situation under control, because ultimately the Commonwealth Government has no other power over the States. If the Government is going to increase taxation and introduce a new tax on the income from superannuation schemes, that will not affect unfunded schemes, and all the States schemes are precisely that-they are unfunded. Again, that is one of the fundamental differences between most public sector and private sector schemes. That is one of the reasons why people ask for justification for the public sector being treated so differently from the private sector. Why should the level of benefits be more generous in the public sector than it can possibly be in the private sector, given the different operating procedures and requirements in regulations under the Act, which do not apply to the Commonwealth scheme, for example but which do apply to private sector schemes? Is it any wonder that people are less than happy about that?

In recent weeks, the Opposition has moved in the Senate-and I understand the matter will be debated tomorrow-to deal with a very important question, namely, the lack of accessibility of contributors and beneficiaries of superannuation schemes to the management decisions of super funds. It seems to me that the Government has had a very cosy arrangement with the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). Incidentally, the affiliated unions are alleged to get about $1.4 billion income from the 3 per cent superannuation schemes. It is claimed they will have a total cashed up value of about $9 billion by the end of the decade. We are dealing with very large sums of money and significant economic power that can come from the management of the schemes.

This is why the Opposition parties have always been concerned about the capacity of trade unions ultimately to have sufficient economic power to control management decisions of the companies in which they invest. Precisely for that reason, we are moving in the Senate tomorrow that people who are contributors or beneficiaries of schemes must have the right to elect their representatives. But the regulations do not even mention the word `election'. They talk about nomination, and do not even say who is nominating these representatives. I can tell honourable members who nominates them: they are being nominated by unions, by the big fund managers. In many cases the people who are there to represent the interests of the contributors or beneficiaries are not even members of the schemes.

What is the fiduciary relationship therefore that these people have in a situation such as I have described? Is democracy now so expensive that we cannot even allow contributors and beneficiaries to have one of the most important fund raising and long term saving mechanisms in this nation-the right to determine whom they want to represent their interests? Under the companies codes every shareholder has a right to vote for members of the boards but, under this Government's authoritarian management, shareholders in superannuation schemes are being denied natural justice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Superannuation Benefit (Interim Arrangement) Bill. I want to develop the proposition-although I suppose it is not really appropriate for a Government member to do this-that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) really has no choice other than to dismiss the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) from his front bench. During my speech I will seek to outline why I believe it is vital in the interests of the Opposition that the Leader of the Opposition bite the bullet and follow my suggested course of action.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill deals with superannuation, a subject on the minds of Opposition members for some time. For example, not so long ago we dealt with a matter of public importance and during the debate the contrasting approaches of the two parties were dealt with. During that debate it was interesting that the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Bradfield, who has just spoken, failed to mention at all the figures that are the cause for concern-the figures of the Australian Bureau of Statistics that outline just who is participating in superannuation schemes. For the benefit of the House I will run through those figures, but not at this stage.

First, I question what has happened since the matter of public importance that has caused the shadow Minister to be concerned, when he did not previously express any concern whatever about those figures. The Bill continues the historic move by this Government, and particularly the Arbitration Court, to extend superannuation to all workers in Australia. The specific nature of the Bill is that it deals with 325,000 Commonwealth employees who are eligible for benefits and 75,000 who currently have no superannuation coverage at all.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to page 48 of Budget Statement No. 2 which states:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . freeing of constraints in shipping and stevedoring areas would lower costs to users, thereby improving the competitiveness of export industries and reducing the insulation of other domestic industries.
I ask the Treasurer whether he supports the basic conclusion of the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) draft report on coastal shipping which states:
Coastal shipping in Australia is inefficient and has jeopardised growth and employment prospects elsewhere in the economy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think there is any doubt that that conclusion would be right. But the value of any of these reports concerns how one gets there. The mere fact that that can be said after 30 years of coalition Government means that that Government either did not understand the matter, or that it understood how inefficient the domestic coastal arrangements were and decided that it was too hard to do anything about it. This Government has taken substantial steps to address it. My colleague the Minister for Transport and Communications Support has succeeded in changing the manning structure on Australian vessels, both on and off the coast. The Government is now looking at a broader maritime strategy which includes this reference to the IAC report. I am sure that the honourable gentleman is alluding to the structure of the draft report which, in terms of the debate, is disappointing. Having said that, it is only a draft report. The IAC will now begin to produce a final, more comprehensive report and will follow the usual practice of taking public submissions. I hope that the final report will be a more constructive document to the extent that it recognises the substantial advances that have already taken place on the waterfront, both in terms of the waterfront itself and shipping-particularly relating to the terms, conditions and manning levels of Australian coastal shipping and Australian international shipping.

ANSWER.PARA: I conclude by saying that I endorse the broad conclusion of the report. I do not think that any person interested in the Australian waterfront scene would not do so. Endorsing reports, writing such conclusions and getting there is what the game is all about. The fact that we have spent five years taking Australia this far in structural change is testimony to the fact that it has been such an inordinately large task, given the fact that once these structural arrangements are set in place-broadly, they have been undisturbed for 30 years-they take a lot of repairing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Social Security aware of some criticisms of the Government's child support scheme in the media? Can he inform the House of his response to these criticisms?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The media throughout the country has generally strongly supported our announcement of the child support scheme. This reflects in turn very strong community support for the scheme-support which has been gained because we have designed the scheme on the basis of principles of fairness and equity and because we have sensitively dealt with all the different interests involved. Regrettably, I am aware of some criticisms of the scheme in the Press. I am pleased to assure the honourable member and the House that each of the articles critical of the scheme has been factually incorrect. Very few journalists have criticised the scheme for things it just does not do. Every journalist who has understood the scheme has supported it.

ANSWER.PARA: On 22 April the Adelaide Advertiser ran a story expressing concern that the scheme could push some parents into poverty. Its thrust was that the new rules for assessing maintenance in capital form could cause hardship. The story failed to acknowledge the significant changes in family law that have been made as part of the child support scheme. Discussions between my office and some judges and senior practitioners in Sydney and Melbourne make it clear that in the two weeks since these changes came in they are having a very real effect. When maintenance is provided by way of capital it is now an amount that will provide real security to custodial families. Custodial families affected by these changes will clearly be greatly assisted, not adversely affected.

I am also aware of a most scurrilous article in the esteemed publication the Gold Coast Sun. In what it termed an exclusive the paper alleged that there had been a massive blunder by the Federal Government and that the Senate would stop maintenance payments for supporting parents for two months. The good reason why this story was an exclusive was that no reputable journal would carry it. Let us deal with the facts: there are a number of different categories of custodial parents. Custodial parents who separate and gain maintenance orders or agreements after 1 June will have delivered to them for the first time secure maintenance, regularly and on time. Pensioner parents who are currently happy with their arrangement because their maintenance is paid regularly and on time can continue that arrangement and will not be affected. Pensioner parents with orders or agreements who are not regularly paid will be able to get regular maintenance now.

There are a range of State maintenance collection agencies, such as the collector of maintenance in magistrates courts, whose functions will be taken over by the Child Support Agency. None of these agents can currently ensure regular payment of maintenance for a non-custodial parent who does not voluntarily and diligently comply with their order or agreement. We will take over the functions of these agencies in a staged way over the next year or so. In that process one of the matters we will be sensitive to is to ensure that we do not cause unnecessary disruption to arrangements of people who are receiving regular timely payments through these agencies.

I have referred to a number of Press articles. I conclude by saying that not even the journalists who got these stories wrong carried the deliberate untruth that the honourable member for Bradfield tried to convey to the Australian people last week.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister will not--

—I am referring to the Press, not to the honourable member, but I withdraw that remark. In a media statement of Wednesday last week he asserted that the child support scheme was built on reforms initiated by the coalition. I said no such thing and would not say any such thing because it would be untrue. I acknowledge the support of the Opposition for the child support scheme and thank the honourable member for Bradfield for his work on it. This House needs to be reminded that in the period in which the Opposition was in government and in which the number of sole parents and children in poverty was escalating, the coalition failed to address that issue. We certainly did not build on the only proposition that emerged from Senator Durack, which was that non-custodial parents should be sent to gaol.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. I refer him to the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) report. Having just, in answer to a previous question, endorsed that report by implication and having said that it is hard to get there, I ask him how that squares with the comments made by the Minister for Home Affairs, Senator Robert Ray, who stated:

QUESTION.PARA: At the moment, the Government shows no sign, and I endorse that, of doing away with protection of Australian ships.
Is it a fact that there is no way the Government is going to do away with protection of Australian ships and is not going to try to respond to the IAC report?

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not endorse the report. What I said was that I endorse the view that there are inefficiencies in the coastal trade. To not endorse that view would be pretty naive to say the least. I said, and I repeat, that I think the report is disappointing for the fact that it does not recognise the successes and changes that have been made, or comprehend those that need to be made to make such a maritime strategy succeed. What Senator Ray has said is simply that in more words. As I have said, this is a draft report. That report will become a comprehensive and final report. I regard it all with some mirth that--
—Well, laugh!

—Let us say that I am having a little chuckle inside. I do not know whether it is a qualification of membership of the Liberal Party of Australia that one should have no shame, but somehow those opposite all manage to do it. They basically ran Australia for all the post-war years, bar three years from 1972 to 1975. Whatever structural deficiencies the place has, those opposite are responsible for. They know that shipping and transport was always given to the National Party of Australia.
—Oh, it is all our fault. This was before 1970.

—We have one voluble, noisy, stentorian voice from the other side of the chamber now talking as a former Minister for Shipping and Transport and it was always the dead hand, the usual McEwen hand of protection. Whether those opposite talk about television, shipping and transport, or motor cars, it does not matter. They managed to make most efficient industries inefficient and now they have an IAC report; they have got something, and they are going to tell us. I say: Do your best!

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment and Education Services. In his address to the Young Labor conference in his capacity as Minister for Employment and Education Services, he said that there can be no place for privatisation in the Australian Labor Party as it is a concept `akin to the robber-baron mentality which puts profit before people'. Does the Minister stand by this statement?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. I made that speech in a Labor Party forum and the Prime Minister has called for a debate on this matter. I do not intend to pursue the matter in this public forum. The appropriate place to have such a debate is within the Party. I am amused at the way the Opposition is handling this matter. —Will the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel inform the House of what initiatives this Government has introduced to encourage pilots to stay in the Australian Defence Force?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Herbert for his question and his continuing interest in the defence forces, particularly those in his own electorate, including the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) base in Townsville. The Government has decided to introduce a retention bonus for pilots in the Australian Defence Force. The bonus will be set at $70,000 and in return pilots will commit themselves for a further six years of service. But this $70,000 is only part of a package to encourage pilots to stay in the Royal Australian Air Force instead of moving to commercial airlines.

ANSWER.PARA: The RAAF has initiated a whole range of measures designed to improve retention in the long term. We are increasing recruiting and training; we are improving manpower utilisation and management and filling more staff appointments with non-pilots; we are examining the creation of a specialist air crew scheme; we have increased the return of service obligation from six years to eight years and the retirement age for selected pilots could be raised to 55 years. Pilots are also beneficiaries of the various ways that we have increased conditions for defence service families. All these measures take time to have an effect.

Meanwhile, we do expect that Qantas Airways Ltd and other commercial airlines will continue to recruit; therefore the Government has decided to introduce the bonus. The bonus will be targeted very specifically at the people we need to help with the training-flight lieutenants in particular. Pilots aged under 37 years who have completed six years of service as pilots and who are in receipt of the flying allowance are eligible. This means that most pilots who are eligible are in the ranks of flight lieutenant and squadron leader and their equivalents, plus a few wing commanders. In total, 230 pilots are eligible this year to accept the bonus. The RAAF and the Government are determined to train our way out of our pilot shortage. In the meantime we are determined to keep our experience levels high so that training can continue without affecting operational flying. This bonus is just another way of showing this Government's commitment to the defence forces of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment and Education Services. —I must say that the lot opposite really amaze me. —I ask the Minister for Defence whether he can advise the House of the current situation of the Anzac ship project. Is the project proceeding to schedule? What is the timing of decisions leading to the signing of contracts for construction?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable gentleman has been very diligent on this matter, having been in contact with my office over the weeks, and I thank him for his attention to it and his concerns for his electorate. On Friday documentation development contracts were signed with Australian Marine Engineering Corporation Consolidated (AMECC) and Australian Warships Systems (AWS). These contracts involve design development and Australianisation-I should include New Zealand in that-and are each worth about $8m. The project is on schedule, despite a timetable that is demanding on the Department of Defence, the Royal Australian Navy and both consortia.

ANSWER.PARA: Draft tender documents have been with the consortia since 8 March. Final tender documents will be issued in the next few weeks. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories.
