—I am not aware of the matter the honourable member has raised. I will undertake to get an answer from Senator Richardson and have his office supply the honourable member with an answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business and focuses upon new materials and the electrical power industry. What major developments in new materials have the potential significantly to change the technology, and therefore the economics, of the electrical generating and distribution industry worldwide?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The three developments are the discovery of low magnetic loss metallic glasses, the discovery of high energy storage permanent magnets and the discovery, which I have mentioned in the House a couple of times before, of high temperature superconductors. Very important work is being done by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) and a number of the universities and we believe that we may be able to make a very significant contribution to the world power industry.

ANSWER.PARA: Metallic glass alloys of iron, boron and silicon discovered by the Allied Corporation in the United States of America have the potential for reducing core losses in transformers by 75 per cent. To make metallic glass strips, molten alloy is quench cast. That means that the temperature is reduced from 500 degrees to normal room temperature at a rate of one million degrees per second. That is an extraordinarily rapid drop. High energy storage permanent magnets, particularly iron-neodymium-boron alloys, have enormous high energy densities. They are very strong permanent magnets which can be used very effectively in a wide range of motors and generators. They can provide levitation, for example, in transport, which could certainly revolutionise the Sydney monorail, to mention only one use.

The ceramic materials I have mentioned before-the yttrium bismuth barium oxides-which are superconducting at reasonably accessible temperatures, have been discovered in the last 18 months. If temperatures at which superconducting operates can be raised towards, say, room temperature, there will be dramatic changes. The use of liquid nitrogen rather than liquid helium is very important. Liquid nitrogen is a by-product of the steel industry. It uses liquid oxygen in making steel, so there is a natural by-product and the price of liquid nitrogen is only 22c per gallon, whereas the cost of liquid helium is $11-a 50:1 differential. So this is a significant development which is very good for the steel manufacturing areas.

This is the most important prospect coming out of the work that CSIRO is doing in conjunction with the State Electricity Commission of Victoria. Superconducting materials can be used as electric storage devices. For example, a device about the size of House of Representatives Committee Room 1 would be able to store enough electricity to provide the peak hour requirements of Sydney or Melbourne. Just think of the implications of that. It means that future requirements for dams or coal fired generators will be much reduced if all we need is to provide the base load all the time and store that up, then producing out of the accumulator the difference between the base load and the peak load. That has very important implications for the whole of the electricity generation industry. Taken together, these developments could raise our electrical generation and distribution efficiencies by 25 per cent and would save hundreds of millions of dollars. If the technology is exportable, it could create billions of dollars of exports for this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney-General to Senator Tate's comments in the Senate on 20 April on the 2 1/2-month-old investigation into the Harris-Daishowa-Australian Labor Party affair, when he explained the delay in the Australian Federal Police completing its inquiries as being due to `difficulties in arranging mutually convenient times to interview two witnesses'. I ask: Have these witnesses now been interviewed? When will the police report be provided to the Director of Public Prosecutions?

—The last information I had on this matter was from the Director of Public Prosecutions, who said that the initial inquiries had been completed but, because of some other evidence which had come to his notice, he was asking for further inquiries. That would have been about three weeks ago. I have not heard from the Director since. I will have further inquiries made today.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: RENT OF UNOCCUPIED GOVERNMENT OFFICE SPACE

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Administrative Services to statements made last week by the honourable member for Barker that more than $50m a year is being spent by the Federal Government on rent for unoccupied office space. What are the facts about Government expenditure on so-called `dead rent'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do believe that the shadow Minister for public administration, the honourable member for Barker, put out a Press release last week claiming that the Government outlaid something like $50m per year on dead rent. When I saw that Press release I was, to say the least, extremely puzzled as to how he arrived at that figure. After reading the Press release I further noticed that an attachment listed 22 expenditure items for fit-out over the past three or four years in New South Wales. Thus I arrived at the answer as to how he calculated the figure of $50m. It seems that he added up these 22 items of expenditure on fit-out over the last three or four years and extrapolated them by a factor of 10. Why 10, I do not know. Nevertheless, he multiplied the $5m for the fit-out expenditure of 22 items over the last three or four years by 10 and arrived at $50m and said that this was the figure for dead rent for 1987-88.

ANSWER.PARA: It seems to me that the honourable member for Barker is going down the same track as his leader, the honourable member for Bennelong. He is the person who made $7 billion to $8 billion worth of unfunded pledges and promises at the last Federal election. He double counted the so-called savings he was going to make on payments to the States to the extent of $2 billion or $3 billion. So all that one can say is that the honourable member for Barker is about as good at public finance as is the honourable member for Bennelong. I can now inform the House of the exact figures. If the Leader of the Opposition wants to put up a shadow Minister in the field of public administration he should at least put someone in the position who is capable of simple arithmetic. If they put a figure into the public arena of dead rent over one year they should at least have a method of arriving at a figure that stands up to public examination.

The total rent paid this financial year to 16 March was in the order of $267m and rent paid for so-called dead rent was $3.9m for leases that needed to be committed, and rent paid before fitout commenced. There was another $2.3m in the same period for other factors. The total is $6.2m and not $50m. So the true figure for so-called dead rent was just over $6m and not $50m. I might point out, Madam Speaker--

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. The Standing Orders require answers to be prompt. The Minister is already on page 5--
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat.

—Actually the factors that go to make up the figures for so-called dead rent fall into several categories. The first is that leases often have to be committed before or during the construction of a building to obtain the accommodation in the first place. Secondly, as I have said, the private sector lessors usually require rent to be paid before fit-out commences. The Opposition might try to say that dead rent can be so categorised but unfortunately the private sector lessors are not altruists who would want to lease to anyone, including the Government, during a fit-out before rent is paid. When the shadow Minister puts forward the figure of $50m paid out for dead rent in one year he is giving a wildly inaccurate figure. The figure is arrived at by the use of shonky arithmetic. He has lost all credibility. If he wishes to criticise, let him do so, but before he opens his mouth he should make sure that his figures are correct.

—My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. Is it a fact that seminars arranged in Sydney and Melbourne which would for the very first time allow public debate on the Government's plan to place company law in the hands of the Attorney-General's Department in Canberra have been postponed? Why were the seminars postponed? Does this mean that there will now be no public discussion on the Government's proposals before the legislation is introduced in the House? Is it a fact that the 34 members of the Attorney-General's consultative group were required to take a vow of silence on their discussions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —We never require any vows of silence in the Attorney-General's Department. There is an advisory committee, a small group of business people who are looking at improvements to what is called corporate law, with a wider consultative group of some 34 people who come from all over Australia. There is no problem about the matter. Even some of those who are part of that group can have various opinions. They are not sworn to silence. As I think honourable members might note from some of the Press reports, there are various views as to what the law ought to be. The issue that the honourable gentleman is obviously worried about-this is the first question he has asked me in the whole of his career-is that we might be able to--
—That is not true.

—In respect of this matter it is. I might rephrase it; I appreciate the position. Perhaps it is the second question he has asked in the whole of his career. Would the honourable gentleman settle for two? I cannot remember what the first question was about but we will check it up later. I think at this stage the honourable gentleman would agree, as he has already announced he would oppose any improvements to corporate law from a Federal point of view, that there is not much point in inviting his discussions. He is welcome to have any input he likes into improvements in the law. The people dealing with it are talking about--
—No, I have asked you but you have turned me down.
—The honourable member can make a speech some other time.
—Order! The honourable member for Ryan will cease interjecting.
—We are dealing with improvements in the law which I think would be of the greatest benefit to the corporate sector in Australia.
—Yes, and I have asked you--
—Order! The honourable member for Ryan will heed the Chair.

—It is important and it is about time the Opposition faced up to the fact that the present scheme is cumbersome and is not working. Even the Leader of the Opposition had enough nous to know that that was the position, and he said so in the absence of the honourable member for Ryan on one occasion. We are very anxious to streamline Australian corporate law. The only way to do it is by having this Parliament approve of it. It cannot be done until such time as the business community in general feels it is satisfactory to them. It is certainly agreed throughout Australia that it is about time we had some law which was under scrutiny of a parliament and answerable to a parliament. At present we have a hybrid scheme, the only creation of which could come from the National Companies and Securities Commission, not answerable to any parliament, not answerable to any Minister. We are stuck with this arrangement made in 1978 and no amendment can be moved to it in this Parliament. It is a ridiculous, sterile arrangement which we must get rid of.

ANSWER.PARA: Accordingly, I propose to introduce what I think will be effective company law for the scrutiny not only of the Parliament but also of the business community. I would like to do that before this session ends. It will lay on the table until the Budget session so that there can be discussions about the law, but I can assure the honourable gentleman that it will be miles ahead of the present law. I am hopeful that we will get cooperation from State governments from the point of view of their being able to enter into government managerial arrangements whereby they could administer Federal law in accordance with what they regard as their privilege, namely, the collection of revenue from it.

As I told the honourable gentleman the other evening in a debate on another matter, all we would want from it would be 12 1/2 per cent, one-eighth. With one-eighth of the revenue the States collect we could have a very efficient, streamlined business law in Australia, administered by a business group called the ASC, with a business advisory council whose members come from all over Australia. I think it would work very well. I welcome the shadow Minister's interest in the matter and I invite him to continue asking questions on it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Defence seen claims by Queensland Ministers to the effect that there is discrimination among States in the award of defence contracts to the detriment of Queensland? Can the Minister outline the system whereby defence contracts are awarded?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable gentleman for his question. I have seen those statements. I have also seen statements by Queensland Ministers to the effect that, although there was discrimination against Queensland, after they had seen me everything was fixed up and now Queensland will be able to compete on an equal basis. All these statements are nonsense. There is no discrimination against Queensland. There has been a poor performance by Queensland Ministers. Virtually every other State has managed to take note of the fact that Defence spends about $3 billion a year inside Australian industry and has made some efforts to get some of that business for their own business houses.

ANSWER.PARA: In addition, a number of States have taken initiatives to ensure that the quality assurance performance of their local industries is up to scratch as far as Defence is concerned. Over the last few years Western Australia, South Australia, New South Wales and Victoria have made enormous strides in getting together a coherent approach to the Department of Defence and, more importantly, a coherent approach to their own industries to ensure that they take full advantage of contract opportunities.

One government which has lacked this approach and which has shown the least amount of interest has been the Queensland Government. One would think that the Queensland Government would have plenty of time on its hands, given the number of sitting days of its Parliament, to do something useful for its industry. But it does not. Instead, it moans, mewls and pules, saying that it is discriminated against, which is a traditional reaction of the totally inactive.

Tendering for defence contracts is on the basis of price, quality and performance. Those are the bases on which decisions are taken in purchasing inside Australian industry. There is no discrimination among States. The number of contracts is so vast that it would be virtually impossible to devise an active policy of discrimination against States, and there is none against Queensland. In so far as there is any legitimate basis of concern, I can set the minds of honourable members from Queensland at rest. They ought to look at the overall performance of the Queensland Government, and they would know where that question was coming from.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Attorney-General: Which States have indicated their support for the legislation he proposes to introduce shortly?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —No States have indicated their support, which is pretty well known. New South Wales indicated its support, but I assume that the incoming Government will withdraw it. As the honourable gentleman would know, for some time I have been suggesting that there ought to be some parliamentary law, which could be the subject of debate, scrutiny and amendment, in this area. The only way to do it would be in this Parliament.
—What about the split system?

—I thank the honourable member for that interjection. I suggested the split system on the basis that the States could keep under their control what are called the exempt proprietary companies and small business. They refused to accept that. I offered it to them in accordance with an undertaking I gave to the honourable gentleman here. I welcome his interest in the matter because his concern is more national in outlook than others show here. The States rejected my offer on the basis that they felt they could not administer a split scheme.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me come to the present position. Following my offer, at a meeting of the ministerial council, the majority of the States put to me the following proposition: I could introduce any law I liked, provided I had the support of at least two States. I did not regard that as being an effective way for a Federal Minister to exercise responsibility. In other words, I would be in the ridiculous situation of being able to bring forward what I regarded as a Federal law only if I had the support of two States. I would have an inhibition placed on me that no Federal Minister in history has had placed on him.

I made the further point that if that were the position, if that was where we are at present, I would give the States an input into what law I would be introducing into the Parliament. In other words, I would show them, as a ministerial council, or better still, as a meeting of Attorneys-General, what the proposals were and, if they had any objection to those proposals, I would report them to this Parliament. Further, because they are concerned about the employment prospects for their corporate affairs commissions I said that I would welcome entering into government arrangements whereby the existing State commissions could remain under State control and administer Federal law. All I would want, as I indicated in the previous answer, would be one-eighth of the revenue they collected.

There is a profit of about $72m in the revenue at present which the States are very anxious to keep. It is important that we streamline and get efficient administration at a Federal level. It is also recognised that we are not trying to move the whole lot to Canberra. Canberra is seen as an anathema on the basis that the law will be centralised. As has already been discussed, the proposed law will be on the basis that there will be a statutory business advisory committee. In other words, representatives of the business community from all over Australia will, on a statutory basis, be able to advise the proposed Australian Stock Exchange.

Further, I have suggested to the State Ministers that, to ensure that the State corporate affairs commissions have some input, we could have two part time members of the State corporate affairs commissions associated with the Australian Stock Exchange. A great weakness in the present scheme is that there is no dialogue, communication or direction from the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) down to the State corporate affairs commissions. There are 1,500 people working in the State corporate affairs commissions who have no real relationship with the NCSC, trying to struggle on without any real resources and devoid of money. This places a burden on the business community from the point of view of delay.

We need a bipartisan attitude to this situation. I can understand States wanting to hang on to the idea that this is a great scheme but, quite frankly, there would be nothing else like it in the democratic world: to think that law could be generated outside parliament and not be able to be rejected or amended by parliament. The Senate Select Committee on Securities and Exchange recommended Federal legislation in this area. I understand that all parties, other than the Australian Democrats, were represented on that Committee which took evidence from the business community. Members of the Committee were unanimous in their recommendation. It was an intelligent recommendation.

Some of my Labor Party colleagues still apply a State limitation-everything must operate within State boundaries. There is only one market in Australia. There is only one central business organisation-the stock exchanges, which have now formed themselves into the Australian Stock Exchange. That has been made very clear even in terms of the Rae Committee report. If we can get the law right-and I think we can-I am sure that we will be able to get the business community to agree that the proposal would be of the utmost benefit to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HAYDEN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-For the past five years, I have observed a great many examples of the dilemma which faces our consular officers overseas. On the one hand, they efficiently and faithfully carry out the Government's firm policy that Australians overseas should get the fullest possible protection and assistance in times of difficulty. On the other hand, they are constrained in this task by legal, financial and other problems.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Government has the most active sympathy for Australian citizens in difficulty overseas but there are limits to what it can do in such circumstances. My purpose in making this statement is that honourable members and the community as a whole should appreciate both the extent and the limitations of the assistance available to Australians travelling overseas.

Cases in which Australians get into difficulty with authorities overseas are matters of distress and sometimes hardship back home. They are the subject of frequent representations to me by honourable members. They often create misunderstanding in the community at large. They are sometimes the cause of perhaps understandable but unhelpful and counterproductive commentary. A number of such cases have occurred recently. I would like to clarify the responsibility which the Australian Government has-and the limits to that responsibility-to Australians entangled in legal and other problems while overseas.

Let me emphasise at the outset that the Government does not view the provision of consular services to Australians as optional. If it is not a formal legal obligation, it certainly is a moral one. The Government is glad to accept as a primary responsibility the protection of Australians overseas to the fullest possible extent.

The consular protection governments can give to their citizens is limited but well recognised in international law. The Vienna Convention on Consular Relations defines the functions of consular officials. Australia subscribes to this convention, having signed it in 1964 and ratified it in 1973. But the Australian Government is also prepared to do more for the protection of its citizens overseas-more, in fact, than most other governments, despite the scarcity of resources and despite the high and increasing numbers of Australians travelling overseas.

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has increased its activity in forewarning travellers of possible pitfalls ahead of them. Its informative Hints for Australian Travellers is issued with each new passport. It has produced pamphlets and other material on the dangers of involvement overseas with drugs. It stresses at every opportunity the need for travel insurance. It issues advice about travel in places where personal safety or health is threatened. The Department contacts every travel agent and other similarly interested organisation in Australia to inform them of concerns about conditions overseas which come to light through reports by our missions. A recent instance of this was its warning of an upsurge in cases in one particular country of travellers accepting drugged drinks from so-called friendly strangers and waking up minus money, passport and plane tickets.

The Department also provides a range of everyday services to Australians overseas. Consular officers advise about international banking arrangements, for example; help when money or other belongings are stolen or lost; and help next of kin in the event that an Australian dies overseas. They help travellers who become ill; help to find relatives and friends in emergencies; visit Australians in hospital or prison; and sometimes facilitate return home by Australians who are distressed in some way. Australian people and organisations overseas often need documentation to be authenticated, witnessed or certified for use back home. Consular officers can take evidence under oath. In some countries, they can perform marriages.

This by no means exhausts the list of consular services provided to Australians overseas. It is enough to repeat that no other government makes greater efforts. I re-emphasise also that these services are provided at a time of stringent economic conditions at home and significantly increased travel by Australians overseas. It is all the more necessary therefore that Australians fully understand that there are limits to these services and what these limits are. The necessity is underscored by evident misunderstandings about this in certain sections of the media, from which many Australians derive their information, and, I regret to say, even among some honourable members. By this I mean, first, there is an unreal expectation of what the Australian Government can and should do for Australians who choose to travel overseas in hazardous circumstances and, second, a misconception about the relationship between Australians and the laws of the country in which they are living or touring.

As the numbers of travelling Australians has increased, so have their expectations of what the Australian Government should do for them when in difficulty. The Government has active sympathy for Australians in difficulty. But it cannot always meet these expectations, either because they require action which is against international law or practice or because they are simply beyond our resources. People who do not understand this or who have been misled about it can sometimes be quite bitter when they do not get the service they want.

Honourable members will recall the wide public interest in the tragic case of the two young and reportedly underqualified pilots who went missing in the Atlantic last September. These young men were, of their own free will, engaged in a commercial operation in an area very far from our own shores. The combined efforts of defence forces provided by Nigeria, Gabon and the United Kingdom failed to find the two young men. The cost of this activity to the Australian Government-and by that I mean quite obviously to the Australian taxpayer-was much more than $1m. Another recent case which attracted publicity was that of the young nurse who was believed to have gone missing in suspicious circumstances in West Africa. A consular officer tracked down her movements and confirmed that she was in fact safe and well. The problem had arisen because she had failed to telephone her family in the time period she had arranged with them. The search for her involved 20 different departmental officers here and in four overseas posts, the co-operative efforts of officials of friendly governments, and an investigatory trip to Togo by a staff member of our mission in Lagos.

Australia has a comprehensive search and rescue system which is available free to anybody in distress in its territory, whether this person is a citizen or not. Search and rescue systems elsewhere may be as comprehensive but charges-I am advised by my Department-can be levied when loss or injury result from activity known to be hazardous. Australia cannot demand of those other countries that their search and rescue services should be free to Australians. Australians who intend to take part in hazardous activity in remote places, their families back home and the media have to understand that there is a heavy final cost to the taxpayer when this activity goes wrong. A sympathetic Australian Government will do what it can to persuade other governments to provide the level of service their experts see as appropriate to the circumstances; but we cannot give an open-ended commitment, at Australian taxpayers' expense, to search and rescue in remote places in terms either of scope or funding. Taxpayers are entitled to expect travelling Australians to act prudently; to consider the possible consequences of the hazards they are contemplating; to take the proper equipment with them; to take out adequate insurance; and to be properly qualified to undertake particular ventures.

The second area of misunderstanding-concerning Australian travellers and foreign laws-is complicated by an unreal, almost chauvinist, view in some quarters of the relationship between our society and others. The law of any nation is developed and conditioned by many experiences over many years. There are nations whose laws stem from a history of hostility by neighbours or of colonialism, for instance; from experience of drug abuse; from strict adherence to religious values and standards. We may not like or approve of these laws. This does not, however, give us the right to flout or ignore them as being in some way less substantial or consequential than ours.

Like it or not, Australians must obey the laws of the countries they are visiting. If Australians do not, there is a limit to what their Government can do to alleviate the consequences. Failure to understand this has led to wide but ill-founded public comment on several occasions in the recent past. I offer honourable members some examples because they show how many kinds of legal problems there are for unwary or foolish Australians living or travelling overseas. The case of Kevin Barlow and Brian Chambers, who were executed by the Malaysian authorities in 1986 illustrates the drastic consequences which await Australians who become involved in foreign countries with drugs, even so-called `soft' drugs. The case of Ian Grey in Mozambique shows the dangers of challenging the security laws-for whatever misguided romantic or religious purpose-in a society in which security is the paramount issue. The case of Robert Wenham in Saudi Arabia illustrates that problems with the laws of another country may not be confined to matters of crime; that they be the most complex and arcane matters of civil dispute. The case of Mr Pantelic in Yugoslavia illustrates two points: the complications for Australians in the concept of dual nationality and the fact that conduct which may be allowed in Australia may be illegal elsewhere.

These cases, different in so many respects, had one thing in common. This was the perception which informed so much of the considerable publicity generated by them. By this I mean the notion that the Australian Government should be able to pluck Australians out of their predicament; that it should `do something' to make other governments agree that Australians should be treated differently from the citizens of those other countries; that Australians overseas should somehow carry with them the legal rights and obligations obtaining back home; and that the Australian Government can and should impose Australian laws and practices on other countries' legal and penal systems.

One can imagine the uproar here if another government insisted that its citizens should have the benefit of its legal system in Australian courts or that its citizens should have special treatment in Australian prisons. The chauvinism which underlies such sentiments in Australia is inexcusable in whoever displays it, whether public commentator, legal grandee or even member of Parliament. They cause grave embarrassment to the Australian interest overseas. They can also imperil the very cause they seek to support. The intrusion of such sentiments in the cases of Mr Grey and Mr Pantelic, for example, put their situation in grave danger during certain periods of the legal processes against them. This is a most important point and it needs the most careful consideration. It is easy-and in some cases obviously gratifying-to thump the tub about cases of Australians under arrest in foreign countries. But experience shows that there is often no surer way of encouraging the governments of those countries to dig in their toes; that fulmination and muscle flexing can militate against efforts for the release of Australians under arrest overseas.

In making these points, I would like it clearly understood that the Government will properly and fully discharge its consular responsibilities to Australians in difficulties overseas. I want also to put precisely to the House the consular services available to Australians when they are arrested. Consular officers will ensure, as far as possible, that an arrested person receives the benefits of the same laws, administration and protection of rights and redress of injury as citizens of the country where the arrest took place. They will ensure access to legal representation and to regular consular assistance, including visits. To the extent that it is possible, they will see that an arrested person gets the same facilities-including accommodation, diet and medical or dental treatment-as citizens of the country where the arrest took place. They will provide whatever other assistance and advice can reasonably be given.

Now let me make clear what consular officers cannot do in such circumstances. They cannot intervene in civil cases involving Australians. They cannot provide legal advice. They cannot achieve the release of an arrested person. There may be certain circumstances in which the Government may address the question of release from arrest, but it is not a consular function. The Pantelic case, as I have said, illustrates the complication in the concept of dual nationality. There have also been instances over the years of problems concerning the obligation of military service on Australians deemed to be dual nationals. The Australian Government may have considerable difficulties in helping protect the interests of Australians caught up in the problem. Consular officers try to provide whatever help is appropriate, but the level and nature of help will be dictated by the attitude of the country concerned.

To help deal with the problem, my Department is negotiating with a series of consular agreements, of treaty status, with East European countries. The first, signed recently with Hungary, provides that travellers will be regarded as citizens of the country on whose passport they elect to travel. Thus, dual Australian-Hungarian nationals who travel back to Hungary on Australian passports will be regarded by the Hungarian authorities as Australians. They will be entitled to our consular protection and their right of prompt departure from Hungary is guaranteed. Negotiations for similar agreements are well advanced with Poland and the Soviet Union. Discussions are under way with Romania, Czechoslovakia and Yugoslavia. The job that consular officers do is complex and stressful. An additional disadvantage is that they seem to be visible only in times of trouble. I would like to state clearly that the Government is deeply appreciative of their work.

TALK.START.PARA: —A lot of them are unsung heroes.
—Is the honourable member speaking from personal experience?
—I am.

—I trust that this statement has helped honourable members and Australians generally also to appreciate their work and the legal, financial and other constraints on their services. The Government is in the process of reviewing the nature and scope of consular services to Australians overseas. It is my intention to ask the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade to assist by conducting an inquiry into the matter and making this review as comprehensive, effective and broadly supported as possible. The Chairman of the Joint Committee, the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney), and I have had discussions on this matter and his inclination is to accept such a reference because of its vast and important national interest. I commend the statement to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The statement that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) made to the House is, for the most part, a very useful document. The Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations which defines, among other things, the function of consular officials is a lengthy and detailed convention running to some 26 pages. What the Foreign Minister has said about the functions of consular officials is a useful reference point for those who want to understand in plain language broadly what consular officials do. The Foreign Minister concluded his remarks by referring to his intention to ask the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade to assist in conducting an inquiry into the nature and scope of consular services for Australians overseas. That is a very good idea, and we certainly support it. I disagree with one or two comments that the Foreign Minister made, and I will come to those in due course.

SPEECH.PARA: The Foreign Minister said that the Australian Government intends to provide the fullest possible protection for Australians overseas. Of course, we endorse that. He pointed out that the Australian Government seeks to do more than other governments do, and we also endorse that. That would be a common objective of any Australian government. Of course, there is always the problem of resources. The effectiveness of the assistance given by consular officials overseas depends greatly upon the resources that we apply overseas. I am sure that the Foreign Minister would agree with that. I do not believe he was hinting in his statement that the Government intends to erode in any way the existing overseas resource base.

The Minister referred to the complex nature of the functions that must be exercised overseas to protect the rights of Australians, especially when Australians overseas become entangled in legal systems. The Pantelic case illustrates that point, just as it illustrates the problem of dual nationality. I know a fair bit about that case because I went to Yugoslavia to help Mr Pantelic. The House will recall that Mr Pantelic came to Australia when he was young, became an Australian citizen, was a permanent resident in this country, was married to an Australian-born woman of Serbian extraction and went back to Yugoslavia for the purposes of taking holy orders or something akin to that in the Yugoslav Orthodox Church. Whilst he was there he was imprisoned and was charged by the Yugoslav authorities and sentenced. I will return to that point later.

The point of the exercise is that Mr Pantelic's liability to the jurisdiction of the Yugoslav courts depended on the fact that, whilst he had become a permanent resident in Australia and had taken out Australian citizenship, Yugoslavia did not recognise that action. I understand from what I learnt in Yugoslavia that it is extremely difficult for a Yugoslavia-born citizen to lose his citizenship even if he takes up citizenship in another country and notwithstanding the time that that person might spend in another country. I am glad to note that the Government has been able to work out a convention with Hungary regarding dual nationality; I believe the Government should be commended for that as well as for the negotiations it has entered into with other Eastern bloc countries.

The Foreign Minister also referred to what he called misapprehensions in the Australian community, including amongst other members of Parliament, to the effect that the Australian Government was able to pluck Australians out of legal predicaments in other countries and that, effectively, the Government was required to do something to make other governments agree that Australians should be treated differently from the citizens of those countries, as it were to be treated as Roman citizens who, as they travelled from country to country, were able to say according to Roman law, `I am a Roman citizen. Try me under Roman law'. I do not believe that any honourable member has said that; I am certain that that sentiment has not been expressed by a spokesman on this side. People most certainly should not be under that kind of misapprehension. Of course, as the Foreign Minister points out, there are different legal systems. He said that Australians should not be entitled to special treatment, but the obvious questions arise, `What if the legal system is effectively not by our standards a legal system? What if there are no enforceable rights? What if it is the practice of a government to torture or imprison people for lengthy periods without trial or to conduct extrajudicial executions, as has occurred in various countries?'. That is the point of it.

We all know that the legal systems of very few countries in this world give the citizens and others enforceable legal rights. What happens in those situations? Do we say, `True it is that this Australian is in difficulty, true it is that he has been treated like anyone else, true it is that he is being held without charge and true it is that he might have been mistreated or tortured but, because he is being treated the same as the citizens of the country in which he finds himself so treated, we should do nothing?'. I do not believe that the Foreign Minister would agree to that proposition for a minute, but it illustrates the danger of the kind of approach that in a rather over simplified way he has outlined. The truth of the matter is that we must act quite differently in relation to some countries in support of the rights of our citizens. That is the experience of other countries. For example, contrast an Australian citizen who gets into trouble in Britain to an Australian citizen who gets into trouble in a country of the kind to which I have referred. If an Australian gets into trouble in Britain, the United States or another country where the law applies and where enforceable legal rights apply, the role of the Australian Government is very different from the role it would adopt in, say, the Pantelic case or the Ian Grey case.

The Foreign Minister also criticised those who intervened in the cases of Mr Grey and Mr Pantelic. Despite his delicacy in not naming me, it was quite obvious that the Foreign Minister was referring to me. Let me reject and dispose of those criticisms by dealing with the case of Mr Pantelic. Mr Pantelic was charged on the basis that he was liable to Yugoslav law because he was a dual national. The basis of the charge against him rested on actions taken by him not in Yugoslavia but in Australia. A large part of the evidence against him rested upon his relationship with an association in this country, lawful in this country, and actions he had taken in this country that were perfectly lawful according to Australian law. There was the damning fact that he had marched in an Anzac parade. A photograph of him marching in an Anzac parade was in fact tendered at the trial.

I went to Yugoslavia. On my way there, I went to New York, where I met with Helsinki Watch, an organisation that looks to the enforcement of the Helsinki accords that relate to human rights. I discussed with representatives of Helsinki Watch the Pantelic case and Yugoslavia and one's approach to dealing with that kind of problem.

I then went to London where I visited Amnesty International, discussing with the person there, whose job it was to be concerned with these kinds of cases and whose expertise lay in dealing with Yugoslavia, the Pantelic case and how it should be dealt with-what could be done. I then went to Yugoslavia and, apart from seeing two senior government officials, more importantly for present purposes perhaps, I saw Mr Presel, a senior United States official, the minister counsellor, in the United States Embassy at the time. I saw Mr Pantelic's lawyers.

I went to Sabac and saw Mr Radulovic, with whom I discussed the Pantelic case, and then human rights issues and cases in Yugoslavia, because he was a lawyer specialising in human rights work. In Belgrade, I saw Mr Perovic, Mr Pantelic's lawyer at his trial and also on the appeal. Mr Radulovic also appeared at the first trial. Mr Perovic said he would welcome my presence in the court-the appeal was to take place the following day-and he made the point very clearly to me that public pressure on the Yugoslav Government could only assist cases of this kind and that if there was not public pressure and public outcry, people could simply get lost. That was the whole burden of the advice I received in the United States from Helsinki Watch, in London from Amnesty International, from Mr Presel and from the lawyers. Mr Pantelic himself, whom I have seen since he was freed, certainly welcomed my presence in Yugoslavia. I ask the question: Who knows better about these things? Incidentally, I add that two reports have come back to me from sources in Yugoslavia that my presence there for this purpose was valuable or crucial; I am quite content if it was valuable.

As to the Grey matter, let me simply say that the focus of the media, together with the actions of Mr Robertson, in my view were the reasons why the outcome was as it was. It is nonsense for the Foreign Minister to say that the intrusion of the kinds of sentiments I expressed put these people in grave danger.

From talking to two Yugoslav officials-Mr Matovic, Assistant Federal Secretary (Minister for Justice), and Mr Strbac, Assistant Federal Secretary, Federal Secretariat for Foreign Affairs-it was clear to me that my presence there was valuable from Mr Pantelic's viewpoint.

A wide question therefore arises. As I have said, who knows better than Amnesty International, Helsinki Watch, and the human rights lawyers themselves who daily deal with these kinds of cases? If the Foreign Minister had talked to Mr Pantelic's lawyers he would know their views and know that in their view the involvement of world pressure and attention from the media is vital if these cases are to be conducted with the prospect of a good outcome for those involved. Otherwise, people can get lost in the system, because the kinds of rights we have in this country, that we treat as being our birthright, as water and air, do not exist everywhere.

Should we take the view that we will not speak out? Why do these countries react to pressure? They react for the very good reason that they wish to have their institutions thought well of. They do react to public pressure. They face the old continuing problem; they seek public acceptance in the Western world. Amnesty International, of which I believe the Foreign Minister is a member, works on the publicity principle.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, not a member.

—The Foreign Minister is not a member of Amnesty; I am in error there. However, Amnesty works on the publicity principle. This Government has itself from time to time rightly criticised abuses of human rights. One example is the criticism made by this Government over the refuseniks in the Soviet Union. The Government has claimed success in getting some refuseniks out, and I commend it for its efforts. That is a good example of a public statement and pressure being exercised by the Government, through the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), as I recall, stating the Government's position and Australia's position in very plain terms.

SPEECH.PARA: The Foreign Minister would lead us logically to a situation in which we should never speak out and in which we should leave matters to governments. When an Australian is in trouble overseas, the suggestion is that the wisdom of governments should prevail. Logically, the Foreign Minister must be saying that organisations such as Amnesty International should stay out of these matters and not engage in widespread publicity and attacks on the records of governments, as it does. Why does Amnesty do that? That organisation, probably more experienced in human rights than any other, does it for the very good reason that publicity-pressure-brings results.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs KELLY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In November 1985 the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) commissioned a study into the problems facing spouses of service personnel. Before I commence this statement I want to put on record my thanks to the Minister for having the foresight to proceed with this study, because his initiative has led to the fundamental changes in the attitudes of the Government and of the Australian Defence Force (ADF) to the Defence Force family. The Minister realised that circumstances have changed. In the past, service families were expected without question to up stumps and follow the colours, wherever they led and whatever the family circumstances. That is no longer the case, and nor should it be. Community expectations have changed, and so have the expectations of service families.

SPEECH.PARA: The study the Minister commissioned was undertaken by Mrs Sue Hamilton of the Office of the Status of Women over a period of five months. The Hamilton study broke new ground. It identified, for the first time, all of the issues that service in the Australian Defence Force creates for the spouses and families of its members. It recognised that ADF policy should pay real attention to the needs of the spouse and family, to their quality of life and to the effect on them of a member's service in the ADF. The Hamilton report had no predecessor, and no substantial research base to work from. No broad examination, investigation or study had looked at the needs and wants of the people who, though they are not bound to the Australian Defence Force by service, are deeply affected by its policy and day to day decisions.

In the course of the study Mrs Hamilton travelled to all States and visited all areas with major concentrations of service personnel, as well as a number of smaller bases in remote locations. Open meetings for spouses were held in every area visited. Attendance at these meetings totalled about 4,300. Over 700 written submissions were made to the study. Many people took the opportunity to air their views through radio phone-ins around Australia, by private telephone contact or by office visit. Contact was not limited to individuals. Mrs Hamilton also had discussions with commanding officers, administrative staff and other serving personnel in the areas she visited; with chaplains and welfare staff attached to bases; and with civilian agencies in areas around bases. The Hamilton report is therefore thorough. I am pleased to report that the Government's actions in response to the recommendations of the report have been flexible and comprehensive.

The first recommendation Mrs Hamilton made was for a clear directive to be given at ministerial level that the issue of family morale in the Australian Defence Force is one of high priority. My colleague the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) gave his personal commitment. The Government expressed its commitment by appointing me Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. My actions since assuming this Ministry confirm that commitment. Since my appointment I have made extensive visits to defence bases throughout Australia to talk to service members and their families and to gauge for myself the issues that concern them and the problems they face. These visits have given me a vital insight into the sheer size of the Defence Force and the variety of places in which service families live and work. These visits have taught me that, above all, our efforts to improve the quality of life for defence families must be adaptable. They must allow for the local and regional differences between the many places-from capital cities to remote and isolated communities-that service life takes people to. Different places require different assistance and people moving from one place to another have different needs in different places. Service life can mean one can move from Canberra to Puckapunyal and then to Townsville or Melbourne.

The operational and training needs of a service career demand postings. Many, if not most, of the unique difficulties that affect service families derive from this inevitable need for postings. The Hamilton report recognised the problem and its importance. The Chief of the Defence Force, General Gration, recognises it, and so does this Government. Following the Hamilton report we employed an independent firm of management consultants to examine the policies on promotions and postings in the three Services. It concluded that the incidence of postings is at a level consistent with the operational and training needs of the Australian Defence Force. At the same time, it made recommendations to assist in achieving a balance between the requirements of service and domestic life. The Chief of the Defence Force has determined that postings will be for three years, subject to operational exigencies. Further, a policy of back to back postings in the same locality will be pursued wherever possible, giving those who want it stability for up to six years.

I do not want to give the impression that moving from place to place is necessarily an unwelcome thing. Many defence families and many of their children enjoy the variety of a service life and the range of experiences they gain from it. What the Government must try to do is to find the best way it can to ease unnecessary burdens and pressures on families when they are posted. One very important means of helping a family to adjust to a new location is to provide as much information as possible to the family about the place they are going to. Families need to know about schooling, about the availability of employment for spouses, about child care and community services. The Hamilton report identified this need and made recommendations about it. They have been implemented. The Government has set up the Australian Defence Force Family Information and Liaison Staff (ADFILS) to provide community development and education support for service families throughout Australia.

ADFILS headquarters in Canberra coordinates an extensive network of full and part time professional staff. The recruitment program to fill all the positions that have been created is well advanced. In all there will be one senior community development coordinator, six community development coordinators, eight regional education liaison officers, and 30 community development officers. In addition, 51 family liaison officers have been established in the Services to act as the first point of contact for families. They will operate as a supplement to the support systems that have been run by the individual Services for many years. The regional education liaison officers will provide professional advice and assistance to service families and to the family liaison officers, establish and monitor the education needs of families and represent those needs to State governments and authorities. The community development coordinators will provide the essential link between civilian and service communities and ensure the smooth delivery of support services for defence families. They will also select, train and monitor the 30 community development officers who will be based in areas of major service concentration.

This extensive professional network will be a boon for mobile families. It will make reliable information easy to obtain and assistance readily available to any family that needs it. ADFILS is a very important source of direct support to Service personnel and their families and I confidently predict that once it is fully operational-and that will be soon-the network will prove to be the most valuable resource that Government has ever provided to service families. It is essential that all members of the Australian Defence Force know about ADFILS and the services it has to offer. Communication is effected through ADFILS outposted staff, by the regular publication of a newsletter and by frequent contributions by ADFILS to the three service newspapers. I make it my business whenever I visit a base to talk to servicemen and servicewomen and to spouses groups to raise with them family issues, so that everyone I can reach is up to date with their entitlements. Close attention has been given to the prompt settlement of claims for compensation submitted as a result of loss or damage to goods during removal. The spouses working party on removals, on which service spouses are represented, keep a close eye on the efficiency of removals. There is evidence that all aspects of removals have improved considerably.

Disruptions to children's education can be a major problem for service parents. The frequent requirement for interstate postings means children, particularly those at important points in their schooling, may suffer disadvantages. We are currently taking action to minimise any bad effects. My consultant, Mrs Mayer, is currently working on obtaining agreement with State education authorities on uniform reporting processes. We have developed a pilot scheme to introduce a student portfolio into schools with a high service population. The portfolio will contain examples of the students' work and interests that will be portable from school to school. This will assist teachers to place students at the right level and give them vital information about what a student has learnt at the previous school and what has been missed out. The student information portfolio has been introduced in every State and Territory and has been enthusiastically received by service parents. I would like to see a common-core curriculum introduced in high schools that have a high defence population. This will involve complex negotiations with the Directors-General of Education in each of the States but it is the direction I want to pursue.

The student portfolio is only one of a number of initiatives we have taken in an area that is clearly of great concern to defence parents. I have introduced an extra tuition allowance payable for children in the last two years of primary or in any stage of secondary school who move as a result of a posting. Where needed, extra tuition for up to six weeks will be available, with tuition fees being reimbursed up to a maximum of $40 a week. The eligibility criteria for the education allowance have been broadened. In the past, education allowance was restricted to children who would suffer serious interference to their education if required to change schools as a result of a posting. The new provisions give the approving authority greater discretion also to consider the impact of the member's next posting where that is likely to cause serious interference. This will particularly help members on short duration postings to remote areas, such as Tindal.

In writing her report, Mrs Hamilton talked to many service spouses to find out what they thought. This process of consultation proved so useful that Mrs Hamilton recommended the establishment of a national consultative group of service spouses. This group was established in 1986 and its expenses are funded by the Department of Defence. Members come from all over the country. The aim of the group is to improve the quality of life for service spouses and their families. The group provides a forum for their views and a mechanism to make recommendations to me and to the Chief of the Defence Force. Service spouses; thus for the first time are in a position to influence the policies that directly affect service families. That is quite a unique move: in this country for the first time we have formal channels so that the spouses can officially put views to Ministers and to the Chief of the Defence Force.

Mr Deputy Speaker, as you can tell from what I have listed so far, the Government's implementation of Mrs Hamilton's report has been both flexible and comprehensive. We have set up support networks and employed professional help, as well as introducing new conditions of service where that is a more effective and appropriate response. Child care is an issue that shows how this combination of responses works. Approval has been obtained for reimbursement of child care expenses for up to two days during removals where only one spouse is available to do the moving. Discussions on the child care needs of service families were held with the then Department of Community Services in the wake of the Hamilton report. A number of centres were identified where there was a mutual service and civilian interest in community child care. Centres which have been or are soon to be established as a result of these discussions include Townsville, Katherine, Wagga, Nowra, Rockingham and Hastings. I recognise that service families have to compete for places at these centres and that they are disadvantaged by their frequent removals. Nevertheless, these facilities do contribute to meeting the needs of service families living in these areas.

I am currently working on a comprehensive defence policy on provision of child-care support for defence families. I am committed to improving the level of support available to defence families in recognition of the special pressures which Defence Force employment imposes in a society which is changing. Self-help will continue to be an important element though, in my view, some employer support by defence is also warranted. I hope to have policy guidelines formulated in time for consideration in the lead up to the August Budget. Meanwhile, approval has been given for licensed family day care schemes to operate from service married quarters and for surplus defence facilities to be used to house child care centres. Limited child-care facilities have already been established at some bases. I opened the new centre at Swanbourne in Western Australia earlier this year. Next month I go to Enoggera to open the occasional care centre and kindergarten there.

Because of their mobility, service spouses often find that they are discriminated against in obtaining employment. This is not only unfair but a terrible waste of talent. Recently I met some service spouses at HMAS Stirling. I will just quote an example because it gives honourable members some idea of the way they are treated. A woman told me that she had applied for a job, and when asked what her husband did, she replied that he was in the Navy. No job was forthcoming. She called again the next day using her maiden name. This time when asked what her husband did she said that he was engaged in underwater research. She got the job. I think it is a total waste of talent for these women to be discriminated against in this way. I am presently undertaking a series of visits to speak with employers about this problem. I am being helped in this regard by the Committee for Employer Support of Reserve Forces. I take this opportunity to pay thanks to Allan Edwards, the Chairman, for the support he has given me in this exercise. My aim is not preferential treatment for these women, but simply to make sure that service spouses get a fair go in employment.

There are several other initiatives which the Government has pursued to improve the lot of service families. Legislation will be introduced today to amend the Defence Force Retirement and Deaths Benefits Act. The purpose of the amendment will be to allow retiring members to make an election, up to three months before retirement, to commute a proportion of their pensions to a lump sum for payment on their retirement. This will minimise if not entirely remove any delay between severance and receipt of the commutation lump sum. Members of the Australian Defence Force are now entitled to four reunion visits each year if they are separated from their spouses on long term postings. If the serving member is posted to a remote locality at the time that his or her children are finishing their last years at high school, or if his or her spouse has compelling career obligations, the family might decide that their collective interests are best served by the temporary absence of the serving member. In a case such as that reunion visits are a crucial element in maintaining family stability. To alleviate the disruptions to families who are presently required to move to a new locality when a member is posted, consideration is being given to a proposal that the member be able to decide, having regard to family needs, to defer movement of the family and continue to receive housing assistance at the old locality. This proposal is one of three that are under consideration by my colleague the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis).

Another important recommendation of the Hamilton report also under consideration by the Minister for Industrial Relations is disturbance allowance. With regard to disturbance allowance, the rates for the third, fourth, fifth and sixth moves are being reviewed. Possible inequities relating to members without families are also being considered. The overall aim is to fairly reimburse service personnel for movement necessarily incurred by the needs of their employment. An improved means of recognising and compensating members for the costs involved in the movement of their household pets is also under consideration. One of the additional costs associated with removals is that involved in complying with State regulations. Drivers licences are an example. My consultant has been meeting with State authorities to try to obtain a more tolerant approach. If I had my way there would be a national drivers licence for Defence Force personnel. Unfortunately, I have been advised that constitutional difficulties might be encountered in unilaterally pursuing such an objective. So we will have to proceed via the States.

No statement about service families would be complete without talking about housing. The Hamilton report made no specific recommendations about service housing, apart from indicating that there was a problem and that measures to address it were under way. They certainly are. On the 1 January the Defence Housing Authority was set up. The legislation establishing the Defence Housing Authority ensured the flexibility to manage defence housing commercially, to reduce management costs and delays in deliveries and to improve maintenance. The Government has pledged that $750m will be made available to the Authority over 10 years for acquisition and building of new houses and for improving our current stock. That is a very significant financial commitment and one that means a lot to defence families.

The reality has far exceeded the promise. An amount of $73m was earlier provided for capital expenditure on housing this financial year. An additional $46m for the Authority has just been announced, $10m of which is for essential improvements such as security locks; the extra $36m is for spot purchasing of houses and land for defence families where the need is greatest. This brings to $119m the funds committed to improved defence housing this financial year. Including the measures implemented in response to the Hamilton report, annual defence expenditure which contributes to supporting service families totals some $193m. That is over $5,000 per year for each married member of the Australian Defence Force.

The benefits of what we have done are not merely economic. The real benefits lie in the process of communication that we have made possible and in the understanding and flexibility of administration which follows. The flow of information between families and headquarters is guaranteed, and guaranteed to flow both ways. Spouses are represented at the centre, where policy is decided, and they are supported locally when they need information and help. Commanding officers on bases are involved and their support is crucial. The result is a vastly improved system of reciprocal communication. That is the improvement we have made that forms the basis for all other improvements, both now and in the future. In three years we have addressed problems that have been building up and festering for decades. It is a record of initiative and achievement that we can be very proud of. It is unshakeable evidence that this Government cares about the people, whose work it is to defend this country, and their families.
I present the following paper:
Hamilton Report-Implementation of Recommendations-Ministerial statement, 27 April 1988.
Motion (by Mr Beazley) proposed:
That the House take note of the paper.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Beazley)-by leave-agreed to:
That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the honourable member for McPherson speaking for a period not exceeding 20 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) for making a copy of the statement available in good time. I hardly know where to start on this matter. On the very day that the problems of the Royal Australian Air Force have overwhelmed the Government, the Minister comes into the House and tries to solve the problem in a panic reaction by dumping $70,000 in the lap of a few selected RAAF pilots. On the very day the same Minister has the hide to come in here and tell us how much the Government has done and is doing for the Services. I must say that, for a woman, she has a hide as thick as an elephant's.
—Do you support the $70,000?

—I certainly do not. I will have a bit more to say on that in a moment. Basically the Minister's statement concerns the report of the Hamilton Review of Effect of Service Life on Spouses. The Hamilton report was presented to the Government in April 1986-nearly two years ago. Since then, very little has been done. As in all defence matters, the Government reacts only when it has to, usually too little and always too late. All the birds have flown or are flying out. The Government is trying to hold back an enormous tide with a broom. The announced $70,000 bonus for pilots is nothing but a desperate move by a very desperate Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday in this House, in answer to a question from me, the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), who should be taking an interest in personnel matters but never does, said that of course the RAAF is operational. Twenty-four hours later, his assistant Minister is in the House saying that we have a desperate plight on our hands, that the RAAF is collapsing and that we have to give $70,000 to a few selected pilots. What a joke. The Minister comes in here and says that we are going to train our way out. This year we will lose 140 pilots or thereabouts. The Government has the capacity to train about 70 pilots a year, if that, by the time it has complicated matters with its new fancy PC9 aircraft and all the other problems. It thinks it is going to train its way out or bribe its way out with a few selected pilots. It is a joke.

The pilot retention scheme, if that is what we can call it-it is bribery that the Government is offering-will be condemned within the Services and without. The Armed Forces Federation of Australia, has already put out a Press statement, which I have seen, universally condemning it, and so it should. The Government has had to resort to this bonus scheme because it has not paid attention to improving pay and conditions of service across the board. What does it think is going to happen? It is going to give a bonus to a few pilots. What about all the rest of the RAAF, the air crew and the pilots who do not get it? What about all the Royal Australian Navy personnel who do not get it? What about the Army people? What is the Minister doing for them? They are no doubt reading her announcement now, saying, `This is what they think of us; nothing for me. It is only when the Government gets a political crisis on its hands that it is forced to do something'. The Government is offering very little indeed. It is offering $70,000 over six years. As I understand it, it is to be taxable, which brings the figure down to about $36,000. When we divide that by six we see that the amount will be $6,000 a year. Does the Minister think she is going to bribe these people for another $6,000 a year to get her out of an enormous political hole?

Half the speech that we have heard this afternoon tells us nothing but that the Minister will look into the situation. The improved conditions that the Minister has announced, late as they are and little as they are, are welcome but the rest of the problems she says she is looking into. Before she knows where she is, people will be calling her the mirror Minister. She is always looking into something.

We on this side of the House have been warning the Government for the last two or three years about what is happening to the Australian Defence Force. I have been saying in recent months particularly that it is falling apart, that the Minister is presiding over the dismemberment of the Australian Defence Force. By her actions today, that is exactly what she has proven. She keeps on telling this House, `All is well'. Yesterday the Minister for Defence said, `How dare you ask a question about the operational viability of the RAAF? Everything is all right; there are no problems'. Yet today the Minister has come in here and tried to dump $70,000 on a few selected pilots. Does she think that is going to fix the dismemberment of the Australian Defence Force? What a joke. No-one has believed her when for months she has said that everything was all right. I can only presume that she thought everything was all right. It just shows the arrogance, the neglect and the disinterest of her Government in defence matters.

Does the Minister not understand what is happening to the forces? Maybe she understands at long last what is happening to the RAAF. Does she not understand what is happening to the Navy, whose operational capabilities have been cut back month by month, and to the Army, which is desperately short of men and cannot sustain itself in the field? Does she not understand that 27,000 people have been lost in the last three years? Does she not understand that the Army has lost 10,000 men and something like 1,200 officers in the last 15 months? Thirty sea commanders have been lost from the Navy, plus many engineers. Some of those losses have been from the command of ships. Never until recent years have I heard of people giving up a command and leaving the service. It is the pride and objective of every serviceman to have his own command, and it was unheard of until the Minister took the helm for people to leave the service when they were in command of a ship or battalion.

The experience levels have been drastically reduced in every Service. The Chief of the Naval Staff, in a submission two weeks ago to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, which is looking into Defence Force wastage, said quite clearly that all he could look forward to was more collisions, more accidents and more groundings at sea. The trend, he said, is increasing. The Otama incident in which, unfortunately, two men were lost, was, as the Chief of the Naval Staff said, a partial result of the low experience levels in the submarine service. Those were his words.

TALK.START.PARA: —He did not say that and you know it.

—He did. While all this is going on, the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel parades around the country saying, `High wastage rates are good for the Services'. The Services have lost 27,000 personnel in three years. The Minister might care today to modify that view.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday in this House the Department of Defence made an absolute fool of the Minister for Defence. As the result of the Minister's sheer neglect of the Department, it openly conspired to deceive this Parliament in reply to a parliamentary question. The honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner) is in the House and presumably is going to speak. I hope he is going to pursue what he said publicly and get to the bottom of this matter. The Department made a fool of the Parliament and made a fool of the Minister for Defence. That was yesterday. Today, what do we have? Not 24 hours later, after the Minister has said, `All is well in the RAAF', the assistant Minister has come in here and said, `Things are crook; things are desperate. The RAAF is falling apart but we are going to fix it by giving a few pilots a selective bonus of $70,000'. Within and without the Services both Ministers are now considered as a joke, and in certain areas they are regarded as positively dangerous.

Let us turn to the contents of the statement that was put down today. Some of it is certainly welcome but it does not go very far. It is two years late and it is too little. There is very little in it of any great substance. At the beginning of the statement the Minister uses the word `flexible'. She says that one has to be flexible about these matters. What does that mean? It means that one has to be nimble on one's feet; that one does not do anything until one is forced to do it. That is what flexible means to the Government.

The Minister said that there has been a clear ministerial directive that family morale is to be regarded as a high priority. Does the Government think it will fix morale by having a discredited Minister standing up and saying that family morale is to be a high priority? They are like the words of King Canute and they will be about as effective. The Minister went on to say that the Government has maintained its commitment by appointing her as Minister. I can tell her that she is not regarded as a blessing in the Services. What will make her name is her announcement today about a $70,000 bonus. That will live for a long time. All it will do is create an enormous number of problems. She is already well known for not appearing at spouses meetings when they ask her to go and, best of all, for initiating the spouse guidelines on how she should be treated--

TALK.START.PARA: —You know I did not initiate those.
—Why did the Minister not disown them? She never did.
—They were not mine to disown.

—The Minister never asked for them to be withdrawn. On page 4 of the statement it says that the Chief of the Defence Force has determined that postings will last for three years. Does she not understand what is happening out there? Every time a gap appears because someone resigns someone is plucked out of somewhere and shoved in the gap. Does she not understand that postings being for three years is an impossible dream under her administration and the problem is getting worse? Did she not hear the service spouses say last night that it is an impossible dream? How can postings last for three years when we are surrounded by the shambles of posting policies that she has created?

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the question of Australian Defence Families Information and Liaison Staff. We are all pleased to see this recommendation implemented in part-two years late and certainly not as recommended by the Hamilton report. It is still not properly in place and no-one has yet seen the full benefit of it. The Minister talked about her consultant, Mrs Mayer. Let us get this straight: Mrs Mayer is a failed Labor politician. She is not a consultant. She has no experience in this matter. She was put on because she was out of a job-jobs for the girls.
