She has been running around trying to introduce some pilot education scheme. As I understand it, the scheme and the concept are already well in place so I do not know exactly what she has done but I know she has cost us a lot of money.

I turn to the National Consultative Group of Service Spouses, a great bunch of women trying to do a very difficult job which the Government will not give them the resources to do properly. The Minister talked about what the Government has done for child care. Why does she not do something sensible for child care instead of saying people have to rely on self-help? Why does she not make some facilities available in the big bases and staff them and welcome women who have jobs into these centres instead of saying, `We will give you this old broken down building but you must make a go of it.'? Why does she not do something positive for them?

Where are the spouse employment offices? Are they in place? No, they are not. Yet the Minister rabbits on about how important it is to get jobs for the 70 per cent of service wives who want to work. I heard the story today from the Minister about the woman at HMAS Stirling who could get a job only when she gave her maiden name. Is that a revelation to the Minister? How long does she think that has been going on? She talked about the Defence Force retirement and death benefits (DFRDB) scheme and allowing the election of early commutation. That was announced in September 1987. It is still not in place. Why does she not do something positive about DFRDB? Why does she not eliminate the anomalies, particularly about officers' ages? Why does she not look at the portability and top up provisions which are non-existent and interest on contributions? The reason the Government will not do anything about DFRDB is that it knows that if the scheme is opened up for review honourable members opposite, perhaps excluding the honourable member for Hughes, who seems to have a genuine interest in defence matters, will try to rip the DFRDB system off the hook altogether.

The Minister talked about improving education and the education allowance. At last count something like 80 out of 70,000 people were in receipt of education allowance. The Minister talked about looking at the disturbance allowance. Here is the rub: Who is going to look into the disturbance allowance for the men and women in the Services? The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) will. So we will get all the hufty-tufty of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission guidelines and `Can you do this?' and `Can we have a bit more productivity here?'. Why is it that the Minister for Industrial Relations has to get involved in deciding conditions of service for members of the armed services? They are not public servants. They belong to a unique profession and it is about time that the Government treated them as such. We saw in the last pay case what happens when the Minister for Industrial Relations gets involved in service matters. I am very pleased to see that the Minister is considering compensating families for moving household pets-very important.

The result of today's statement will be very little. The benefits are not yet flowing through to service families. The Minister is flailing around trying to use a cosmetic approach to an enormous problem. While the very security of this country is falling apart in front of the Government's collective noses it is deciding about household pets. Today it tried to do a quick fix on the Air Force. Tomorrow no doubt it will be the Army and the day after, no doubt, it will have a quick fix for the Navy. Why does it not do something positive and meaningful about home loans, which it has been talking about for three years? Why does it not restore the entitlement to all who join the Services? Why does it not lift the ceiling that has been there since 1980? Why does it not offer an option of a cash grant and all the things the Minister thought she would like to do?

Why does she not address the pay and conditions in the service that the Chief of the Naval Staff, Admiral Hudson, and the Chief of the General Staff, General O'Donnell, submitted to a joint parliamentary committee two weeks ago? And while she is at it, why will she not answer the question why she, the Minister for Defence or the Department tried to get Admiral Hudson's submission back from that committee? It is quite obvious that what he said in that submission was not to the Government's liking so it tried to get it back. I think it is very interesting that the one Service that is having the most problems did not put in a submission. If the Government wanted to do something meaningful for the Services it would spend in this area the $200m that it says it is proud of saving-and well done-through better management of the defence forces? It could do all of this for $200m-give some meaningful pay rises, have a total review of pay and conditions and put some guts back into the services. But it will not do it. It will fiddle around the edges while the Services fall about under its feet. It is creating an enormous shambles.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

INTERJECT.PARA: Debate (on motion by Mr Lindsay) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS TARIFF (URANIUM CONCENTRATE EXPORT DUTY) AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill returned from the Senate without requests.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The confusion created within the business community by conflicting statements from Government Ministers on future economic policy.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today's matter of public importance is about the community's concerns relating to the direct consequences of conflicting statements made by members of the Labor Government. As the May economic statement approaches, debate within the Government's ranks heightens over government spending and taxation and moves towards privatisation and the uncertainty in the business community becomes more intense. Simply put, the Hawke Government is in economic disarray. Conflicting and confusing remarks are emanating from every corner of the Australian Labor Party. While the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is promising tax cuts, another Minister is promising tax increases. One Minister, the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, is advocating spending cuts. The same Minister is advocating increased spending. While the Industries Assistance Commission, with the Treasurer (Mr Keating) at its helm, is advocating less protection, another Minister, the Minister for Home Affairs, Senator Robert Ray, is seeking to ensure that protection remains at current levels.

SPEECH.PARA: One wonders whether, when the Prime Minister said that there would be less taxation, he was acting with Cabinet authority. If he was, the other Minister was speaking in direct contradiction to the authority of that Cabinet decision. If the Prime Minister was not acting with Cabinet authority, if he was just speaking off the top of his head, tax cuts must be one of those things. We remember when he said, `There will be no capital gains tax'. When we hear some of the other remarks of the Minister concerned we might think that he will get rolled in that area.

Who is accountable for what is going on? Who is calling the shots? What direction is the Government taking? This weekend, at the Young Labor Conference, we heard the Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan) calling for increased government spending and increased taxes. He said:
We must face up to the hard issues of increasing tax revenue . . .
The Minister prefaced his remarks with a quaint history of the Labor Left's prominent role in making Australia one of the highest taxing countries in the world. He said, no doubt beating his chest:

. . . for me the Left is the faction which provides the vision for the Party as a whole . . . It was the Left which provided the background research for the capital gains and fringe benefits taxes . . .

There is an admission and a half. That is not bad for the Left. We know who won that battle. `There will be no capital gains tax' said the Prime Minister. Fringe benefits tax was a latecomer, certainly not a tax the Treasurer was trying to promote amongst all his cigar-smoking mates. The Minister continued:
Many policies of the rational Left-
that is quite an admission-
involve an increase in government spending-more education, more industry policy, more care and assistance for the less well off.

That is what one might call the traditional Labor position-higher taxes, more spending and more protection. Let us consider the economy-the balance of payments situation, the high interest rates, the level of the Australian currency. Yet we have a Minister making these remarks. I get back to the question of whether he was speaking with the authority of Cabinet. Was the Prime Minister speaking with the authority of Cabinet when he said that there will be tax cuts this year? If he was not, quite clearly we have a conflict of significant proportions in this area. This hardly jives with the remarks the Prime Minister was making over the weekend. I doubt whether the Prime Minister, when he heard the Minister's comments, would have been greatly amused. He would have been faced with making a decision as to taking disciplinary action against the Minister. If the Minister is acting against the advice of Cabinet he should go. Therefore, the position of this Minister comes under question.

At Question Time today a proposition was put to him. He was asked whether he was representing government policy. While he attempted to muddy the water at no time did he retreat, in essence, from the comments he made at the weekend. His excuse was that he made the remarks in the context of increased business taxation. That is quite a turnaround. He said that he was not talking about personal tax, which the Prime Minister was talking about, but about business tax. Business tax is the very topic upon which this matter of public importance is based. It is the business community's concern about taxation that the Government says it will address in the May statement. The Government has said that there will be no loss of revenue, but there will be an attempt to bring business tax down to make business more competitive on an international basis. Yet the Minister corrected his statement on taxation to say that he was talking about business taxation. Even if the Minister continues to defend his tax statements by suggesting that he was referring to business taxes only there is still a very real cause for concern among the business community. Not only does the Minister's statement run contrary to the Treasurer's promise to reduce business taxes but it has a devastating effect upon the confidence and optimism of the business community.

Investment is essential in Australia. The long term development of sustained economic growth is dependant upon private investment, particularly in the capital area. Investment is designed to increase the capacity to produce, raise productivity and reduce costs. All of these factors must be seen against this uncertainty. Investment is the engine of economic growth. Without it we will be lost as living standards fall, as Australians know all too well today. The economic climate in Australia is still not right for investment to take place. Investment has remained unaccept- ably low since it peaked in 1982. Investment has declined markedly in relation to gross domestic product (GDP). No wonder. How many honourable members recall the famous J-curve? We have not heard much about it for a long time. The J-curve has disappeared. It has got lost somehow or other down the track. It has got lost in the continuing balance of payments debt. The debts roll up every month, $1,000m a month. Last year it was $14 billion to $15 billion, as it is this year. Yet the Government does nothing to address the basic problems in Australia.

As I said, the economic climate is still not right for investment. Investment has declined and continues to decline. Investment grew by less than one per cent in real terms in both 1985-86 and 1986-87. Average investment as a proportion of GDP in Fraser years, 10.5 per cent, contrasts starkly with the flat figure of 9 per cent under the Hawke Government. Despite falls in interest rates, new private investment remains low. A slight reduction in interest rates will not be enough to spark an investment revival. This must be seen in the context of the poor performance of the balance of payments. Interest rates in this country are unlikely to fall while the balance of payments debt continues high.

The Government has failed to address other contributing factors-the uncertainty in our ability to preserve gains in competitiveness beyond the short term, large depreciation-induced increases in the real cost of imported investment goods, areas of underutilised capacity in the economy, increases in the less capital intensive service sector's share of economic activity, high interest payment commitments eroding retained earnings, unease and an end to the easy funds following the end of the long bull market. Most disturbingly, private business fixed investment in new plant and equipment is declining. The Coopers and Lybrand monthly bulletin has highlighted this point. It states:
As a share of economic activity, private investment in plant and equipment is now lower than at any point for well over 20 years.

There will certainly be no temptation to invest until there are real signs that more stable economic conditions will prevail. This situation appears a long way off, particularly given the chaotic situation which exists in the Labor Party Cabinet. Meanwhile, as Australia stagnates, investors are turning to overseas opportunities. While total private investment in Australia increased by only 5 per cent in real terms between 1980-81 and 1986-87, Australian investment abroad increased ninefold-a fair indication of what the business community thought of this Government. Australian investment abroad has exploded in recent years as companies have voted with their feet for better returns. Labelling these companies as unpatriotic is simply absurd. It is a hard and fast fact that Australian investment is just not as attractive as overseas investment. We cannot blame enterprises for moving offshore to countries where governments and unions offer a more predictable and stable investment environment. While this continues, investment in this nation will be hard to get.

Meanwhile, while that problem is on the boil and investment opportunities in this country diminish and more opportunities are looked for overseas, we must turn to the Government's debate on privatisation. It is in this area that substantial amounts of money are looked for by our public enterprises. The major public enterprises run by this country, which are supposed to be profit oriented, have their hands out for considerable amounts of money-the Commonwealth Bank, $1,600m; Australian Airlines, $300m; Qantas Airways Ltd, $500m-all over a period of time. These enterprises must be funded within Australia and the halted move towards privatisation within the Australian Labor Party will have to face a decline in the desire to invest in Australia if profit performances are not maintained. I turn again to the worthy Minister for Employment and Education Services. He came up with a few more wisdoms on how to handle privatisation. He said:
I am a democratic socialist. I believe that the people of Australia have a right to share in the wealth that they create.
There is nothing wrong with that. He continued:
I do not believe we will achieve that by handing over to the private sector those Government business enterprises which return significant gains to the Government in revenue.

That hardly faces the test of reality, because the contribution to government revenue of Australian Government enterprises is very small indeed. This points to the fact that democratic socialists are not good at economics. To add to that confused situation, I turn to another democratic socialist. Five months ago the Prime Minister ventured:
I can't see any social democratic principle that is involved in government running an airline.

That is not a bad difference of opinion, but we can go one better. In March 1988 Mr Hayden-the old doyen of the Party, the one run out of town by the New South Wales Right, the poor old Queenslander who went down the chute, had this to say:
I am a democratic socialist. I've said that often enough and public enterprise is important to me.

There we have three different views. No wonder there is absolute mayhem about what this nation will do with its public enterprises. Which social democrat do we believe? Which will will prevail in the famous June conference? To add to that, another social democrat-this time Senator Evans-said:
Under the pessimistic scenario and without additional capital the airlines would be unprofitable beyond 1991.

So the reality comes through. Yet while all this has gone on, where is the Treasurer, this new found friend of business, the guy who will travel only behind the smoked windows of an unmarked Commonwealth car when he goes back to his home city of Sydney? He has so much affinity with the world that he has to get around in an unmarked Commonwealth car with darkened windows.

TALK.START.PARA: —He wears a disguise in Bankstown.

—Yes, there is no doubt about that. He stays in Canberra not just to get his travel allowance but also for his own safety, apparently. The conflicts of interest that have emerged within the Government are enormous. Across the board we have had conflict in relation to taxation, including the positions of the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and another Minister. We have had conflict in the Government because of the views put by the Industries Assistance Commission report, the Treasurer and Senator Ray. We have the conflict between Senator Walsh, the Minister for Finance, and another Minister saying we must spend more or we must spend less, and while all this goes on no-one outside knows what is going to happen in the May economic statement. As a consequence of that, the business community in this country at present will not look to invest $1 more than is necessary, $1 more than its current level of commitment. It is a shambles, a disaster for Australia, and we must look at the consequences in the lead-up to the May statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose I should say we have just heard a brave attempt at a speech by the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore), because at the moment the Opposition parties are in an extraordinary state. We see confusion and we see division. I need only remind honourable members opposite about their media policy and what is going on in their party rooms at the moment.
—We have a very good media policy.

—The honourable member for Kooyong is also a brave member of the Opposition but he is not brave enough to get on top of the current division within his Party. Honourable members opposite talk about investment, but in the case of the Bond media group or Skase where does the Opposition stand? We know where we stand-we have gone for the 75 per cent rule-but we do not know where the Opposition stands. We are not sure where it stands. That is just another aspect about which the Opposition is unable to create policy. It has been five years without one. It has not been able to develop any media policy.

SPEECH.PARA: What about tax policy? Let us turn our attention to that. We are not sure in whose court they reside when it comes to tax policy. But there is one certainty, and that is that the former Premier of Queensland is now off the backs of members of the Liberal and National parties. They can get on and have a rational debate, as they did when they were in government and sought some rationality in policy. They do not have a rational tax policy now. We are not really sure whether they are being led by the President of the Liberal Party, who wants to move towards a consumption tax, or whether they are being led by the parliamentary members of the Liberal Party, who want to reject the consumption tax notion. Will we find that members of the National Party will overrule members of the Liberal Party at the last minute and say, `This is the way it is going to be'? One certainty about tax policy is that under this Government equity and fairness have been put back into the system and all the rorts injected during the time of the Liberal-National Party have been taken out.

We hear about confusion in the community at the moment, and there is confusion about the Opposition's tax policy. The difficulty members of the Opposition face is how they can revert to all the rorts and all the schemes that were developed when they were in government. That is the difficulty they face. They are on record as saying that they would go back to the free lunches, they would go back to the system of having no capital gains tax. They are on record as saying that; there is no doubt about it. If they do away with these base-broadening measures, where will the money come from? Mr Elliott's answer to that is very straightforward; they will have a consumption tax. The Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), is in a different situation because he is not really sure that he can go down that path. We know that the National Party will not allow the Opposition to do that; they will do what old Joh told them to do. They will jump on the Liberal Party when it comes to whether or not there will be a consumption tax.

It will not be possible for the Opposition to come up with a sustainable tax policy. The electorate understands that. The people remember very well the inefficiencies and inequities in the tax system that existed when those opposite were in government. Now members of the Opposition are simply reminding the people of the confusion evident then. They can remember that in the Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth there were those unchallenged cases sitting in the bottom drawer, when the Federal Government was not willing, under the Liberals, to take on tax rorts in Western Australia, my home State. The honourable member for Cowan (Ms Jakobsen) will be following me for our side in this debate, and we were both operating then in a climate where we knew that tax rorts prevailed and the Government of the day and its Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong and now Leader of the Opposition, did not have the courage to take them on. I will say this in defence of the honourable member for Bennelong: in 1978, 10 years ago, in an address to the Institute of Chartered Accountants conference in Perth delivered on his behalf by the then member for Balaclava, now the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee), he said, `Your profession is going to have to get rid of these unacceptable practices'. As early as that he recognised there were unacceptable tax practices. The Curran and Slutzkin schemes were but part of that, but honourable members opposite did not have the courage to take that issue on.

Come 1981, by the time the deals had been done behind the scenes, they did not have the courage to take on the question of tax reform, so we had to take that on when we came to government. There is no doubt why members of the Opposition are going through these hoops and curls at the moment over tax policy. There is no doubt why they are going through them over media policy too, because they do not know whom they are trying to please. So when honourable member opposite talk about confusion, let us get the record straight. The confusion exists in the Opposition because what members opposite have always lived on-and this is true; this is the case-is a quick fix, that they can get over the line in an election and suddenly find themselves back on the right side of the House.

I have bad news for the Opposition. Those days are long gone. The 1975 quick fix, sponsored by the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), supported by the Governor-General, where honourable members opposite can quickly fix up a government and stitch it up over night, those options have gone. Now honourable members opposite have to put policies before the Australian community and they cannot do it. We are watching all the little meetings that are going on round here at the moment about media policy, let alone what happens in tax policy. We saw what happened down in Melbourne over tax policy. The Opposition tried to patch up a deal, but it cannot do it. It cannot have a quick fix any more where it can just get over the line, because suddenly honourable members opposite are going to take advantage of a short-term opportunity. The Australian electorate is a bit more discerning. People have grown up a lot and they have grown up to the Opposition's disadvantage, because they are better educated, they are more aware and they want fairness and equity. But they know that they will not get it out of honourable members opposite. If they want fairness and equity they will get it out of this Government, because it is on the record.

Let us continue this theme for a bit longer. The honourable member for Ryan has said that there is a lack of certainty in the business community. Perhaps I am looking at the wrong figures, but I see that the plant and equipment investment projections for 1988 through 1989 show a 10 per cent increase in real terms and this is what businesses themselves have told this Government and they have told the community at large. They have said, `We are going to increase our investment by 10 per cent in real terms'. That is not a business sector which is confused. That is a business sector which says, `This is an economy that is on the move. Australia is back to work and we are going to go places, and we are going to go places because we are going to put plant and equipment investment in place.'.

Just to add to that theme, there was the 10 per cent increase in plant and equipment investment in the December quarter of last year and there was a 5 per cent increase on average right throughout the 1987 calendar year. So what we are looking at in 1988-89 is a further increase in plant and equipment investment. I talk to a lot of business people in my home State of Western Australia and they share equally the confidence that we have on this side of the House. They share the confidence because they know some of the tough decisions have been taken.

Let us talk about confusion further, because there was a lot of confusion in this debate. Where were members of the Opposition when it came to an exchange rate policy? They could not face it. We recently had some discussion in this chamber about a former Prime Minister and what happened to exchange rates under him. I would only make this observation, that honourable members opposite were never able to make the tough decisions on exchange rates. They were never able to do it. It was beyond them because we did not know whether they were bowing to the Country Party or whether the liberal economic rationalists would carry the day. The consequence of all that was that honourable members opposite, when in government, had a massively protected Australia. They had an overvalued exchange rate and they had a domestic economic structure for whom export was what one did when one had something left over in the factory. Members opposite never had a positive attitude towards export policy. What the Opposition had was a time when exports were those things that manufacturers simply got rid of when they had something left over. Now all that has changed.

We floated the dollar in February 1984. We made this economy more competitive and more dynamic. Australia is back to work. When one gets out there one finds that that is the case, but people would not have been back to work under a coalition government because it did not have the policies. It certainly did not have an exchange rate policy. It did not have an industry policy. We found it necessary to put in place the car plan and also the steel industry plan. Why? Because industry was badly structured, uncompetitive, there was not the go-getting attitude that we wanted to ensure was in industry in Australia. It was necessary to put that plan in place, but honourable members opposite had neglected that.

So let us not come into this place and talk about confusion and lack of direction. When one looks back on the Fraser-Howard years and one then looks further back to the Menzies years, what one finds is that honourable members opposite were the sorts of people who were looking for the great wave to surf home on. They were lucky some of the time because they got a good wave. They got a good wave in terms of the Bass Strait oil finds and they surfed along on that for a while, but I have bad news for them. There are not those easy rides any more. One has to take the tough rides and honourable members opposite are not equipped to do it. They are not equipped to do it on media policy. I have already said that. The honourable member for Cowan will remind the Opposition of a few of its other deficiencies. Honourable members opposite are not equipped on media policy, but they were not equipped with respect to investment policy either.

I found it interesting that the honourable member for Ryan talked about the hit that people have taken in terms of investment. Again let us go back to some figures. In December 1983, in terms of the calculations, the profit share of gross domestic product was 12 per cent. It has gone up to 14.8 per cent in December 1987, according to the calculations that have just been released today. One looks at those figures and one asks, `Is this the same conclusion that the honourable member for Ryan has drawn?'. Clearly it is not. The honourable member for Ryan conveniently wanted to get up a conclusion that business in Australia is confused because of the Government's policies. Business is not confused. The only thing it might be confused about would be where the Opposition stands on media policy or tax policy, but business is not confused about our policies.

I will tell honourable members this: there are some people out in the community who are not confused about certain goals, and let us talk about those. The people who have got back to work since we have been in government-there have been one million new jobs created since we have been in government-are not confused because they know now that they have got jobs. But honourable members opposite saw a quarter of a million jobs disappear in their last year of office. The Australian community is not confused about our employment policy. Nor is it confused about our housing policy, because it knows that in terms of delivery of housing services, we have seen 1.4 million Australians back into housing in the five years that we have been in office. That has come about through the first home owner scheme and the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, and that is on the board. When members opposite go around their electorates and when we go around our electorates there is one thing that stands out: Australians are getting into houses in a way that they were not under the Opposition when in government. It got the housing starts down to 105,000, the lowest in 20 years. What a disgrace it was when honourable members opposite had people unable to get houses under their Government. We have sought to try to reverse that. We have still got a job to do, but we have reversed that in terms of the direction.

There is no doubt, if one talks to people in the Australian community, what is happening about jobs. We have got Australians back to work. What is happening in terms of housing? We have got people with a roof over their heads. They are the sorts of certainties that one can talk to on our side of the House. There is another certainty and that is in terms of industrial disputes. We have reduced the level of industrial disputes. The great Fraser formula was to divide, and when honourable members opposite divided Australia they got people at one another's throats. It does not work in terms of our enlightened Australia. What we are about is trying to ensure that people in the workplace can get on with the job. The measure of that can be shown in industrial disputes. When one talks to people in business and talks to people in industry they say, `We are very happy with the way the industrial climate has developed'.

I will tell the House what else they say, which is rather interesting too. They say, `Look, things are difficult. We recognise there is an external account problem, which comes about because of years of neglect, and we realise that not all your policies would please everyone in business, but we hope like hell that you mob stay in office because we are terrified of what would happen if we got the Howard crew in office'. The trouble is that they do not know what policies honourable members opposite stand for. They do not know who is pulling the strings behind the scene and they do not know which particular group honourable members opposite are going to bow to. So when one talks to people out there in business, there is one thing they are very certain about and that is that they do not want the Opposition in government. Certainly when one talks to the general community, it does not want the Opposition in government either, because it knows that honourable members opposite would go back in the same old directions in terms of division, in terms of attacks upon people whom we regard as being important.

We know who members opposite would attack. They would attack people on housing. They would attack trade unions. They would attack young people. They would attack minority groups. They would certainly pose a challenge in terms of our policy on multiculturalism-all those sorts of things. We know what would happen. Mr Elliott is on record on a lot of those things. He says, `I am not really sure we should be going for a multicultural Australia'. On this side, we are not for that sort of divisiveness. We believe Australia is a country that is capable of having a variety of people. But if honourable members opposite go back to their policies of high unemployment and high interest rates, then clearly they are going to get division, because if they put people out of work, if they put people out of houses and if they put people in industrial disputes, we are going to get strife. Of course they will. What members of the Opposition have got is a working laboratory model that is called Maggie Thatcher's Britain, and what a model that must provide in relation to ordinary people, where people regularly take to the streets out of frustration. She has the most divided Western economy you could possibly imagine. One thing we are certain about is that those opposite pray at the feet of Maggie Thatcher because they see her as having the sort of answer that they would want, except they are not prepared to face the social realities of the divided society, the bitter society that they would create with those policies.

A lot is being said in this debate, but there are some things that we ought to say in conclusion. When those people opposite get up and talk about confusion, the confusion can be demonstrated from their years in office. The confusion can be demonstrated right from today. One has merely got to read today's newspapers. What is happening on media policy? What position should they take? I was here last year when coalition members jumped up and down in the Senate, used their normal negative approach and blocked our 75 per cent rule. They would not want to talk to some of the people in the community to whom I have talked because one of the things about our media policy is that we want to ensure that all Australians have access to the best in terms of television. We have that in terms of policy.

Where do honourable members opposite stand in regard to media policy and tax policy? Is it again-and I reiterate this point-the consumption tax that John Elliott wants or the non-consumption tax espoused by the Leader of the Opposition? We are not sure. The Australian community is not sure and people are not about to find out given the sorts of contributions we are hearing at present. Honourable members opposite are patching up the cracks day by day. There is no doubt in our minds. The record shows that we on this side are very clear about our policies. There is no confusion; the confusion lies with the Opposition. We are confident about the direction of our policies and we commend them to the Australian community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that as always I was interested to hear the comments of the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards). His delivery is always most urbane, polished and sonorous but, as usual, so much of what he says is wrong, is half true, and is so biased, so prejudiced and so ignores the truth that regrettably I must say his whole contribution was denigrated. The honourable member for Stirling said that the people of Australia have confidence in honourable members on his side of the House. He said just a minute ago, `They say that they hope Labor stays in office'. I ask you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and the honourable member for Stirling: `Where is the confidence in the Australian Labor Party and the Hawke Government as demonstrated in Adelaide, Port Adelaide, at the Victorian by-elections, the Western Australian by-elections, the Brisbane City Council election, the Groom by-election, the Barambah by-election and the New South Wales election? Where was the confidence in the Labor Government demonstrated in those cases?' It was not demonstrated. The people of Australia have had enough.

SPEECH.PARA: Dissatisfaction is not only the subject of this motion. People in the business community of Australia are confused and puzzled by the vagaries and inconsistency of this Labor Government, as are all the people of Australia. I was fortunate to visit Japan last March as a guest of the Japanese Government and in many discussions with senior Japanese officials the message came over loud and clear that their concern about Australia related to the lack of policy consistency. That is what the people of Australia are worried about as well.

We are rather concerned about the statements that were made last weekend by the Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan) when he called for higher taxation-for taxation increases. Let us consider the newspaper headlines in recent days. The headline in the Canberra Times stated `Duncan speaks out on economic policy. Tax increase suggested'; in the Sydney Morning Herald, `More tax? PM is not amused'; in the Australian Financial Review, `Duncan in hot water on tax statements'. I will say he is, and he will be in more. The headline in the Age stated `Minister calls for higher taxes'; in the Sun Herald, `Lift tax revenue, says Labor man'. Does not the Government, the Minister or the Labor Party know that all Australians are sick of high taxation? Do they not know that this Government is the highest taxing government that we have ever had? Have they forgotten what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said, as headlined on the front page of the Sun Herald of 24 April-`Lift tax revenue, says Labor man' under which was an article headlined `Promise of ``big'' tax cuts'. That article stated:
. . . Australians can look forward to `significant' personal tax cuts over the next two years, Prime Minister Bob Hawke promised yesterday.

At the same time, however, Mr Hawke warned that Australia is so heavily in hock to the rest of the world that the task of reforming the economy is far from over. Thus on the one hand the Prime Minister promises huge tax cuts and on the other hand his junior Minister-but he must have some value since he is in the Ministry-says that taxation must be increased. It is interesting to ask at what venue the Minister made that statement. He was speaking at the National Conference of Young Labor. I wonder how many people were there. I bet there were fewer than would have been the case a few years ago, because the young people of Australia are seeing through Labor, as are the people of other generations. The young are seeing through the broken promises and the pious platitudes of the Labor Party. Let us consider one of the Minister's pious platitudes for size. He said in that address:

We must show them that we are the party of caring policies, policies developed with ordinary Australians in mind, policies which will help them achieve their aspirations, policies which will lead to a better and more decent society.

Help them achieve their aspirations! Just how have ordinary Australians fared under Labor? What has happened to the things that really matter to ordinary Australians? For instance, the honourable member for Stirling referred to housing and home loans. Let us consider the level of home loan repayments. It is always so easy for the Government to hark back to the Fraser years. Honourable members opposite serve up that stale pastry time and time again, but let us consider the level of home loan repayments. In March 1983, when Labor came to power, average monthly loan repayments were $545 or 19.2 per cent of income. In September last year that had increased to $606 or 27.4 per cent of income. The public housing waiting list in December 1982 totalled 110,000, but in December 1986 it was 154,000. How will Labor solve the problems by increasing taxes!

What about unemployment? That matters too to ordinary Australians. Honourable members opposite continually talk about new jobs, but they do not talk about unemployment. They are very fond of trotting out the statistics under the previous coalition Government. Let us consider a few relevant statistics, because the coalition-the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia-and I are concerned about unemployment. Honourable members opposite boast about the number of jobs, but they never talk about unemployment. Let us compare the figures. The average monthly unemployment level under the Fraser Government was 403,000, and under the Hawke Government it is 619,000-an increase in unemployment under the Hawke Labor Government. The average monthly unemployment rate under the Fraser Government was 6.1 per cent and under the Hawke Government it has increased to 8 per cent. The Minister was speaking at the National Conference of Young Labor. The average monthly youth unemployment level under Hawke is 119,000, but under Fraser it was 115,000. The average monthly youth unemployment rate under the Hawke Government is 20 per cent and under the Fraser Government it was 18.6 per cent. I could go on and refer to the various factors associated with unemployment. The Hawke Labor Government has not reduced unemployment.
I would like to consider another statement made by the Minister. He said:
I am a democratic socialist. I believe that the people of Australia have a right to share in the wealth that they create.

He is right. People do have a right to share in the wealth they create without being ripped off by more and more taxation. I cannot understand how any Minister of a responsible government could possibly, in this day and given the state of the economy, advocate higher taxation. Those ordinary Australians of whom the Minister speaks do not want to pay more taxation. They know that they are being over-taxed right now. They know that the Labor Government is the highest taxing government we have ever had and now the Minister wants to increase taxation even further. Day after day honourable members opposite dish up this stale pastry.

Personal income tax is worth considering as well just to get the facts right. In March 1983 the rate of personal income tax for a single income family on average weekly earnings was 17.5 per cent; in November 1987 it was 22.5 per cent. That is the Hawke Labor Government's record. The level of personal income tax per week for the average weekly earner in a single income family has increased from $65 to $117 in that period. That is what the ordinary Australian is faced with, and it demonstrates the impact on the ordinary Australian of the Hawke Government's taxation policy. I will refer very briefly to what happened a little earlier today when I asked the Minister whether he stood by the statements he had made on the weekend. His answer was:

I made that speech in a Labor Party forum and the Prime Minister has called for a debate on this matter. I do not intend to pursue the matter in this public forum. The appropriate place to have such a debate is within the Party.

The Minister made the claim for increased taxation in a forum that was open to the Press: it was a public forum. Now he does not want to debate the matter, but I can tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the people of Australia will not accept more taxation and the Minister should wake up to the fact that the Government must be prepared to debate the matter in a public forum. It is not good enough for him to say that within the Party is the place to have such a debate. The people of Australia are interested in taxation; they do not want to pay any more tax. They know they are being taxed too heavily and want to pay less tax. Less tax is what we in the coalition will deliver when in government after the next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Ms C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was a little disappointed in the speech of the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), especially when he contributed to the debate by using statistics, which we all know can be made to say anything one wants, and also when he failed to give the Government any credit at all for reducing unemployment.
—You blow your own trumpet all the time. I do not have to do anything about it.
—Indeed you do. The honourable member should give us credit, especially since his coalition Government made such a mess of the situation before it lost office.
—You always forget the four-year drought.

—We forget nothing on this side of the House. We do not forget that unemployment has been reduced or that jobs have been increased. We do not forget that interest rates and inflation have been reduced since we came to office. I do not think the Australian people forget these things, either. The Opposition has a vacillating record on many important economic policies and business does not forget that, nor do the Australian people forget it.

SPEECH.PARA: As the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) rightly pointed out, the Opposition was well known, if not infamous, for the tax rorts over which it presided while in office. If it were to return to office, we would have a rerun of the free lunch syndrome. The honourable member for Cowper obviously had no idea of why this matter of public importance was put forward by the coalition, and the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) was even less certain of his subject or the reasons for it.

Tax revenue can be lifted without increasing tax rates. I make this point because it seems to be a matter on which the Opposition is basing its argument today in the erroneous assumption that there is somehow some conflict in the Government on this issue. Tax revenue can be lifted by increasing the number of jobs and the number of people in employment. It does not have to be done by increasing tax rates.

I was glad that the honourable member for Cowper raised the quality of life issues because I think it is important to say that people in this country are better off under Labor. They are better off because we believe in social justice and in the social wage. Those people who now have jobs who did not have them before are definitely aware of the benefits of our policies as opposed to those terrible policies under which they tried to survive when Fraser was in government and when the Liberal and National parties ruled in this House.

Today, we are being asked to discuss a nonsense matter. Once more the Opposition is scraping the bottom of the barrel in its attempt to throw mud at the Government and take the spotlight off its own inadequacies and indecision in important areas of policy. The honourable member for Stirling also mentioned the debacle in the Opposition in the communications policy area. The party of deregulators is unable to tear itself away from regulation and is reduced to carping criticism of a government which has responded imaginatively and without fear to the nation's economic needs on every conceivable front. The business community is very well aware of the economic direction in which the Government is proceeding and approves of it. The President of the National Farmers Federation very recently acknowledged that government policy was heading in the right direction. He even endeavoured to take some credit for that. Does the Opposition seriously think that business has forgotten the reduction in business tax rates or the advantages of imputation? I think not.

Business is aware that under this Government's management interest rates have fallen markedly. Inflation has fallen and continues to fall. Wages have been necessarily restrained as a consequence of the devaluation of the dollar. International competitiveness has been restored, thus improving the capacity of business to operate and prosper in conditions which favour innovativeness and expansion. As the honourable member for Stirling said earlier, risk taking was something forgotten on the Australian commercial landscape and business did lack some thrust; but I think it has been restored now because business has an awareness of government policy and a belief in the fact that this Government will provide economic conditions under which business can operate. Furthermore, business is also well aware of the Hawke Labor Government's concern to ensure the maintenance of stable, improving economic conditions in the knowledge of the need for business to plan its operations with an eye to the future. The accord with the trade unions has produced such an environment industrially. There is no way in which the coalition could have produced that environment. Its confrontationist policies ensured that this nation had difficult circumstances for the people employed and the business community.

Our monetary and fiscal policy has created a similarly advantageous economic environment since 1983. Five years ago the Government adopted the practice of making a substantive economic statement in May as a preliminary to the August Budget. At that time, and since, the statement was made bearing in mind the need for business to be able to plan its activities on the basis of the conditions presumed to be continuing in the forthcoming financial year. Those members opposite who look at this matter honestly will acknowledge that, as the primary implement of fiscal decision-making, the August Budget was always a fairly clumsy tool and often caused major disruption to the investment planning of business precisely because it occurred after the commencement of the financial year at a time when its planning had been put into practice. At that time business applauded the decision and it has continued to applaud it since.

The adoption of the May economic statement as an important preliminary pointer has provided Government with a fine tuning apparatus and provided business with an advance warning on the Government's thinking and direction pre-Budget. It enables sensible, appropriate and reasonably well informed planning by business. For all its claims to be the friends of business, the Opposition never had the gumption or the intelligence to institute such a measure. Hidebound in its conservatism, it continued to lurch from Budget to Budget for all the tedious and backward years that it held government. The hapless business community watched those opposite and their equally colourless predecessors as they presided over huge budget deficits, industrial conflict arising from their confrontationist policies, and unenlightened contractionary economic policies that forced Australia into recession and unemployment, and resulted in a strangulation of consumer spending, with a consequent loss of business profitability. These things need to be remembered.

There is no substantial contradiction within the Government on the general thrust of economic policy. The economic ministry is firm on the importance of maintaining a moderate level of growth while sustaining job creation and keeping interest rates within recent parameters, and also reducing inflation as much as possible. The strength of the dollar will always be difficult to predict given a floating exchange rate, but the Government is still determined to make the structural changes necessary for our economy to become more viable and export oriented, particularly exports from the manufacturing sector. That obviously assists employment and benefits the workers of the nation.

Given the improvement in the economy, it is, however, appropriate that there will be some debate about the need for the continuation of economic restraint. We are a caring and compassionate government. In this vein the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has recently indicated that he would like to be able to improve the lot of middle income families at the earliest opportunity, probably through tax cuts. Other members of the Government are aware of the danger of fuelling domestic demand. Still others believe that the time has come for some such economic stimulus, which in itself can have a positive effect on employment, consumer confidence and business profits.

None of this detracts from the authority of the economic Cabinet on matters of economic policy. Current conditions will always have a bearing on our policies. We are not wedded to a particular formula on a specific page of the economic textbook-the Maggie Thatcher model mentioned earlier by the honourable member for Stirling.

It is completely vacuous of the Opposition not to recognise the dynamic of the economy and the contradictions inherent within it. Its proposal today suggests that business is homogenous; that it has one voice. It fails to acknowledge that what is good for export firms may not be good for those trading domestically. It does not indicate that the interests of primary industry and manufacturing industry are not necessarily the same; nor does it recognise that the needs of big business and small business differ markedly, as do the requirements of international and domestic capital.

I totally reject the words and the sentiment of this matter of public importance, confident in the knowledge that this Government is in tune with the needs of the Australian nation and is taking the economic action which is appropriate to the current circumstances, while refusing to rule out the possibility of easing back on the brake as soon as possible. It must indeed be disappointing for the Opposition to hear business praising the Government for its success in economic policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The debate is concluded.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On 10 December 1987, in a statement to this House on a report entitled Foundations for the Future, I outlined the Government's proposals to establish the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC). These proposals derived from the commitment by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to bring the various elements of the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio into one statutory commission `so that there will be an absolutely firm legislative basis for expressing the total commitment of the Commonwealth and the people of Australia to the Aboriginal people'. In my statement of 10 December, I stressed that the ATSIC proposal would not go ahead if it did not receive a positive endorsement from the Aboriginal and Islander community. In making this commitment it must be remembered that the Government could have made the necessary changes to the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio without getting involved in this comprehensive process of consultation. As Minister, I could have done this while sitting at my desk in Canberra. Instead, I undertook to consult personally with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people prior to proceeding with the proposals.

SPEECH.PARA: Between 23 January and 10 March this year, the Secretary to my Department, Mr Charles Perkins, and I attended 46 meetings throughout Australia involving an estimated 6,000 representatives of some 1,200 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations and groups. These meetings were preceded by 450 community meetings in 415 locations to ensure that preliminary matters were worked through prior to my visits. Far from being a `whistle-stop tour', as some have suggested, the ATSIC consultations are the most wide-reaching ever undertaken by a Minister in this portfolio. Throughout these consultations I stressed at every meeting that the proposed commission would not go ahead if Aboriginal and Islander people did not want it. I also made it clear that the proposal could be changed if need be. There were a few who doubted my word on this point. Some said the Government had made up its mind and the community meetings amounted to `token consultations' only. Allow me to explain what has happened as a result of those community meetings.

Following the first round of consultations it became evident that there were a number of widely shared concerns regarding aspects of the Government's proposals, but that there was overwhelming support for the basic principles outlined in the Foundations for the Future booklet. Accordingly, a further document was prepared setting out a range of alternative options to those aspects which were of concern. This document was also widely circulated, and was the basis of the second stage of the consultation process. This second stage amounted to a series of follow-up meetings convened by departmental officers and Aboriginal liaison officers in all States, the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory. As a result, and in keeping with the commitment this Government has given to consultation, it is now proposed to vary the Foundations for the Future proposals in a number of significant areas.

Firstly, let me deal with the key area of regional councils. Virtually all consultation meetings called for an increase in the 28 regions originally proposed, mainly on the basis that those regions were too large. It is now proposed that there be about 56 regional council areas, subject to the finalisation of boundaries. These amended boundaries reflect Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander requests and recognise historical, cultural, linguistic and other important factors. Instead of regional councils comprising one representative from every Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander community and organisation within their regional area, it is now proposed that regional councils consist of 20 members, elected under a `one person, one vote' system. This overcomes concerns about inequities in representation. Regional councils will meet up to four times a year.

I now turn to the proposal to establish zone councils. Many consultation meetings expressed a view that a separate council at the zone level was unnecessary and could interfere in the relationship between regional councils and the Commission. It is therefore proposed that the planned zone councils be abandoned. In the absence of zone councils, a postal ballot of regional councillors in a particular zone will be held to elect commissioners.

A section of the Foundations for the Future proposal which created much discussion was the question of commissioners. It was originally proposed that the Commission consist of 12 members, those members being an appointed full-time chairperson and 11 part-time commissioners-seven to be elected and four to be appointed by the Minister. There has since been a call for additional commissioners, especially in the larger States and those with large Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander populations, and for a greater proportion of elected commissioners. It is also accepted by the Government that the unique circumstances of central Australia require there to be a special zone, and therefore an elected commissioner, for that area. The Government now proposes a 15 member commission, with an appointed full-time chairperson and 14 part-time commissioners. The chairperson and two commissioners will be appointed by the Minister. Twelve commissioners will be elected: Western Australia, New South Wales and Queensland would each have two commissioners; there would a commissioner for a new central Australian zone covering parts of Western Aus- tralia, South Australia and the Northern Territory; the remainder of South Australia and the Northern Territory and Victoria and Tasmania would each have one commissioner; and a Torres Strait Islander commissioner would be elected by the Torres Strait Regional Council. Under these changes the fears people had that the Government-nominated commissioner would dominate the elected commissioners have now been eliminated.

Mr Deputy Speaker, members of the House will recall that I visited the Torres Strait Islands twice during January and February. I now inform the House of details of the proposal agreed to at the second meeting held on Thursday Island. The interests of resident Torres Strait Islanders will be represented by the Torres Strait Islander commissioner, who will be elected by the Torres Strait Regional Council. There will also be an Office of Torres Strait Islander Affairs created within ATSIC, to ensure that the Commission and other Government programs adequately address the needs of Torres Strait Islanders, including those living on the mainland. The office will provide a secretariat to a Torres Strait Islander advisory board, consisting of six part-time appointed members plus the elected part-time Torres Strait Islander commissioner, who will chair the board. According to 1986 census figures, more than three-quarters of the Torres Strait Islander population live on mainland Australia, rather than in Torres Strait. There is a clear need to ensure that the interests of both groups are not overwhelmed by the interests of the much larger Aboriginal population, and that both Islander residents and mainland Torres Strait Islanders do not feel that their interests are ignored. I believe the above proposal, plus the inclusion in the legislation of a provision ensuring that the Torres Strait Regional Council has direct access within the Budget process to the Minister, will satisfy Torres Strait Islander concerns and ensure that many of the complaints about their past treatment will be overcome. The issues that were raised during my first visit will be dealt with in this place at another time.

An area that was initially the subject of some confusion and misunderstanding concerned the powers of the Minister. There will be two categories of Commission functions: Firstly, those functions on which the Minister can make specific directions, and secondly, those functions on which the Commission will make final decisions and about which the Minister may only make a general direction. This latter category is consistent with the degree of ministerial powers which currently apply to the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC). It is now proposed to add land acquisition to this second category of functions, which will mean that ATSIC will have autonomous responsibility for all the powers and functions currently held by the ADC, plus those additional functions set out in the Foundations for the Future statement.

Another issue which received some attention by Aboriginal groups during my consultations was that of the preamble. I am bound to say that the Government remains committed to a preamble which does no more than recite the facts which have led to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people of this nation being the most disadvantaged socio-economic group within the Australian community. More importantly, the Government in no way resiles from its decision to recognise the fact of prior occupation and original ownership of the descendants of the people now known as the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. There have, however, been some reservations voiced by Aboriginal people in relation to certain parts of the preamble. These reservations centre more on the way in which those facts have been expressed rather than with the facts themselves. As a consequence the Government is prepared to give further consideration to the wording of the preamble in its drafting of the legislation.

I would now like to make some clarifying points regarding the establishment of the Aboriginal Economic Development Corporation (AEDC). Honourable members would be aware that the AEDC is a commercial corporation charged with building a significant capital base for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. There has been some confusion relating to the dividend arrangements which will apply in respect of the AEDC. The legislation will provide for the Corporation to recommend an annual dividend to the Minister, who will accept or vary that recommendation after consultation with the Treasurer. The maximum dividend payable will be 50 per cent of net profits and there will be a dividend moratorium for the first three financial years of operation of the Corporation. The dividend provisions apply because the Corporation is essentially a commercial entity; they are consistent with the Government's policy guidelines on government business enterprises. The AEDC will be subject to normal corporate taxation requirements.

In relation to the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies I am continuing to consider a number of relatively minor adjustments to its operation. Final decisions have not been taken. In the light of these changes to the Foundations proposals, the essential features of the proposed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission can now be summarised in the following terms:

the amalgamation at regional, State and central office levels of the two major Aboriginal Affairs portfolio bodies: the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal Development Commission. Subsidiary bodies of the Commission will include Aboriginal Hostels Ltd and the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies.

the establishment of an all Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, the overwhelming majority of whom are elected, with executive responsibilities across the whole spectrum of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs.
the establishment of around 56 incorporated regional councils throughout Australia, with statutory responsibility for setting priorities for ATSIC expenditure within their regions.
the establishment of a new Aboriginal Economic Development Corporation in addition to programs funded by existing enterprise loans and grants.

specific attention to the interests of Torres Strait Islanders-both in the Torres Strait and on the mainland-through the provision of their own elected commissioner, the creation of a Torres Strait Islander Advisory Board, and the establishment of an office of Torres Strait Islander Affairs within ATSIC.

In a very real sense, these changes represent a complete overhaul of the existing relationship between the Federal Government and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. No longer will they be held at arm's length from government under the guise of `advisory' bodies and the like. No longer will the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people be excluded from the executive decision-making processes of government. No longer will the priorities for expenditure be determined by appointed commissioners or bureaucrats in Canberra without reference to the views of Aboriginal and Islander communities, be they in the bush, or more isolated regions of Australia, our rural towns, or our State capitals. It is precisely because these changes to the structure of the Aboriginal portfolio are far-reaching, that I have been at pains to involve all Aboriginal communities and organisations in developing them. Their participation was crucial in making these changes. Many of the key concepts in the original Foundations statement can be traced to the Coombs and O'Donoghue reports, both of which were based on direct consultations with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. I repeat, my own consultations involved the most sustained and extensive round of meetings with the Aboriginal and Islander community ever undertaken personally by a Government Minister. The process as a whole far exceeds all the consultations ever undertaken in respect of any previous Federal or State legislation dealing with matters affecting Aboriginal people. This is how things should be. This is how I will continue to approach matters with such far-reaching and sensitive implications.

One matter consistently raised by Aboriginal and Islander people has been the announced commencement date of 1 July 1988. I inform the House that the establishment of the Commission will be 1 January 1989. This will allow legislation to be drafted, enable me further consultation on specific details which may arise during the drafting process and ensure that the necessary time required to conduct the elections will be available. The Bill will be introduced early in the Budget sittings.

To enable the Commission to commence operations on 1 January, it will be necessary to hold elections for regional councillors, and subsequently, for commissioners before the end of this year. It is proposed these elections, which will be supervised by the Australian Electoral Commission, be held in October, November and December.

In conclusion, I wish to thank the many Aboriginal and Islander communities for their willingness to consider and debate these issues, and for the welcome and hospitality afforded me everywhere I travelled. I would also make the point that the consultations gave me an opportunity to hear first hand the communities' views on a range of other issues. This is something that cannot be done behind a desk in a capital city. This was an additional advantage of the meetings. Other people I would like to thank include the Secretary to my Department, Charles Perkins, for his loyal and sustained support during this arduous process; Lois O'Donoghue, chairperson of Aboriginal Hostels Ltd for her general support and assistance at meetings; and Department of Aboriginal Affairs officers at central, State and regional level for their excellent work throughout the consultations. They travelled long distances and put in many hours. I applaud their efforts. I also thank the members of the ATSIC task force for their important contribution to the process, my own staff for their dedicated and unflagging support and the parliamentary members of my own Party who assisted in the consultation process.

As I pointed out in my previous statement to this House, these proposals lay the foundation upon which real progress and achievement for Australia's Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people can be built. Aboriginal people, by their responses to the Government's proposals, have demonstrated their willingness to build on these foundations. It is now the Parliament's turn, as the representative of the Australian people, to face the challenge and indicate its willingness to meet Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people half way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-As the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) has said, this is an important issue for the Parliament to consider because we are dealing with the administrative arrangements for handling the Aboriginal affairs area within Australia. We have had a look at the statement which the Minister has put down today. I thank him for making it available a couple of hours before he came into this House.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a few things which we certainly welcome about the statement. We note that many of the things which he talked about four or five months ago in the booklet entitled Foundations for the Future, which was brought into the Parliament, have now been accepted. I recognise that a lot of that has come through consultation with the Aboriginal community. There has been a lot of discussions in redrawing the boundaries amongst Aboriginal people. We welcome the redrawing of the boundaries and will have a look at that area of the proposal.

The essence of this statement today is that the Government has decided to delay bringing in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission proposal. Again, I make the point that the Minister did say last year that he would consult as long as it was necessary. We note that consultation has taken place. Even though the figures look impressive in regard to consultation, we also need to be aware of just what it means to move into an Aboriginal community and spend three hours there with a new proposal. Many Aboriginal people really did not have any idea about it until the Minister went into those communities.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true and you know it.
—The Minister says that it is not true.
—You know it is not true.
—Well, they had a look at the video and discussions were--
—There were two-day meetings prior to my arrival and I was at most meetings a lot longer than three hours. Whoever advises you is telling you lies, as has been the case all the way through.

—I do not accept that. Even if the meetings lasted for a day, as even the Minister has acknowledged, it would nevertheless be very difficult for people, whether they be Aboriginal people or other Australians, to comprehend the changes that the Minister has been proposing. They are large changes, we all recognise that. Even though a lot of travel has certainly been undertaken by the Minister-we acknowledge that he has done a positive job in getting around the country and talking to the Aboriginal communities-it must be recognised that even if those consultation processes took up to a day in each of the regions, that was still a very short period for people to comprehend these changes.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to the proposed delay of six months, I put it to the Government that this will really be a delay in the consultation process of only about three months. The legislation will have to be drawn up very soon and that does not allow for a lot of discussion in the Aboriginal communities of these new ideas. I believe that another three to six months should have been set aside for consultation to allow the Aboriginal elders in the communities to talk more about this issue. I also believe that sufficient time has not been allowed for consideration of the proposal which has been put up for the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC). The issues which have been raised in the Minister's statement today indicate that there will be a very narrow focus in the next six months on future consultation. The consultation provision could have remained a little broader-another three months or so.

The second question which the putting off of the commencement date raises is whether the Government's judgments in the area of Aboriginal affairs are to be accepted as good judgments. When we look at the record we find that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said in September last year that we would have some sort of understanding or treaty by the end of 1987. That has now been taken off the agenda, at least until 1989. I also note in regard to the treaty that, even though consultations have been undertaken, there has been no statement about that by the Minister today.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make another one when I am ready.

—I am sure the Minister will. We find also that the reporting date for the Muirhead Royal Commission on Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, whose establishment we supported, has been put back by another year. We find also that the date on which the Government will bring the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) into operation has been put back for six months.

SPEECH.PARA: I mention the problem concerning the preamble, which we have pursued in the Parliament, particularly in Question Time. We have suggested that the Government seek a legal opinion about the preamble and let all Australian people know what the feeling is in regard to the preamble that has been put forward. In this regard I am reminded of the situation which has arisen in New Zealand where, as a result of one piece of Government legislation in particular in regard to state incorporations, the Treaty of Waitangi is a living document. The New Zealand Government is now faced with a situation which it did not foresee and did not predict-and neither did the Opposition. My plea is that we make sure that we know the implications of the preamble as proposed for ATSIC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am going to New Zealand on Friday. I will tell you when I get back.
—I went to New Zealand earlier in the year and we discussed that matter then. I think the point has been made that we are looking for a clear indication of the implications of this proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to the new Commission, we repeat that we do not believe that a new commission, the new broom approach-the starting up again syndrome, as Senator Chaney has referred to it-is necessarily the best way of improving the delivery of services to the Aboriginal people. I believe that this situation arose not because of the Minister's position or his belief but because the Prime Minister decided shortly after the last election that there would be a new commission. It was all part of his strategy to handle the Aboriginal affairs area. I believe that the Minister was handed the task of setting up a new commission and has had to make the best of a bad situation.

In this regard I think that, as a general principle, it is much better to refine the structures which we have in government unless they are absolutely chaotic and a totally new approach is necessary. I do not believe that that is the case in this area. Therefore, we are still unconvinced by the Government's proposition that a new commission in the form proposed is the best way to go. I point out that this is the only area in which the Government is wrapping together welfare and enterprise in the delivery of systems. We do not have that in other areas of Australian government administration. I believe that that will create lots of problems for us down the track. Members of the Aboriginal community--

TALK.START.PARA: —`We will look after the welfare but don't let them near the enterprises' is what you are saying. You do not want Aboriginal people to have power over enterprises.
—No; I am certainly not saying that. We believe that the Aboriginal people should move towards self-management, self-sufficiency and control over enterprise.
—That is what it does.
—We do not agree that it necessarily does that.
—It does; I am trying to educate you.

—I thank the Minister. We believe that the welfare and enterprise arrangement is a problem in this new structure.
