Also, we do not believe that the Institute of Aboriginal Studies ought to be brought under this umbrella. I believe that it is valuable for our community to have an independent body. This independent body has been set up since 1964, and we believe that it is much more effective in operating at arm's length from the Department or from any new commission. I believe that it is far better for that body, as a repository for information, in collecting and putting down data and information about the Aboriginal people-films, cataloguing and so on-to be removed from the political process.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that under the proposed mechanism the established capital base of the ADC is basically destroyed. I do not believe that the new Aboriginal Economic Development Commission will have any greater capacity to deliver enterprise than has the present ADC. I do not believe that the new Commission will be able to go out into the market and raise capital any more effectively. Of course, time will tell in regard to that matter. I hope that, if this legislation comes into being and the Commission is set up, the enterprise side will be a major positive. I do not believe that that is the case at the moment. The proposal as we see it in this statement today leaves many things still to be sorted out in this area. We support the changes the Minister has outlined to us but we believe that there is a need for more consultation, that there is a need for a separation of the welfare and enterprise of the delivery of those services. We believe that the Institute should remain separate, that the ADC in its present form may need some modification, but essentially it is a structure which we believe would be able to meet the needs of enterprise in the future.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION OF RADIO AND ORCHESTRA FACILITIES FOR THE AUSTRALIAN BROADCASTING CORPORATION AND THE SPECIAL BROADCASTING SERVICE AT ULTIMO, NEW SOUTH WALES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works I present the sixth report of the Committee for 1988, relating to the construction of radio and orchestra facilities for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) and the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS) at Ultimo, New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The report I have just tabled relates to the approval by the Committee of the construction of radio and orchestra facilities for the ABC and SBS at Ultimo, New South Wales. The Committee has concluded that the project will lead to a more efficient use of resources resulting in economies which it is expected will substantially pay for the new complex. The project will be funded on an instalment purchase basis and not from the Budget. The ABC advised the Committee that savings of $10.2m per annum are expected as a result of the collocation of ABC radio and SBS radio and these will be offset against the cost of the project.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee has noted the concern of the ABC staff union regarding the achievement of the project cost savings and the Committee recognises that the realisation of the potential savings will depend greatly on co-operation between management, staff and their unions. The Committee has also drawn attention to the failure of the consultation process between ABC and the ABC staff union and believes that meaningful consultation must take place if this project is to succeed. It was suggested to the Committee that the project should not proceed during the current review of national broadcasting policy. This matter was given serious consideration by the Committee but it has accepted advice from the ABC that the design of the complex is sufficiently flexible to accommodate modifications should these be necessary. In conclusion, on behalf of the Committee I should like to congratulate the ABC Board for responding to the needs of staff by agreeing to provide child care facilities in the Ultimo project. These facilities will replace existing child care facilities sponsored by the ABC staff union.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not long after I was elected in March 1983 a delegation of service personnel within my electorate discussed with me generally the overall morale of the defence forces in Townsville and the general condition of the defence forces as a long term career. They recounted their despair that under the previous Government the Public Service and the general community-even the Government-did not seem to care sufficiently about their problems. They evinced a general feeling that these groups were incapable of remedying a situation that had been allowed to deteriorate for years.

SPEECH.PARA: In September 1985 there was a meeting at the new Townsville Commonwealth Centre between a group of Defence Force spouses and the new Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). The defence spouses at that meeting placed before the Minister their concerns as to their role as spouses of serving personnel. Their concerns included pay and allowances, housing, the unreasonably long working hours of their spouses, their children's future and education and, ultimately, the long term career prospects of their spouses. The Minister for Defence listened to what they had to say and in November of that year, 1985, he commissioned Mrs Sue Hamilton to prepare a report identifying the problems faced by families of people in the Australian Defence Force.

He recognised that there was a serious problem for defence spouses in conditions generally within the Australian Defence Force. He recognised that there had been tremendous social change over the previous 15 years within Australian society. He recognised that today's family demanded an improved standard of living, that quality of life was important, that there had to be commensurate expectations within the Defence Force community as there were in the civilian community. Mrs Hamilton visited a large number of defence bases around Australia and spoke to approximately 4,500 spouses of personnel in the three Services. On 30 April 1986 her report entitled Supporting Service Families was released. It covered a number of matters, as have been outlined by the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) in this House this afternoon.

One of the main problems identified in Mrs Hamilton's report was the widespread dissatisfaction with the standard of service housing. She heard many complaints from service families about housing and visited a number of defence married quarters. From her conversations and her observations she was persuaded not only that the complaints were entirely reasonable but also that the low standard of service housing was a significant contributor to poor family morale in the Services. Indeed, the most frequent area of complaint during her visit to service establishments around this country was the poor standard of maintenance of service housing. Service tenants complained of delays in carrying out maintenance and poor quality of work and materials when maintenance was done, resulting in rapid deterioration. So she made a recommendation in her report that this was a critical priority area requiring urgent attention by the Government.

The whole issue of defence service housing has been debated in this chamber over a number of years. Indeed, the Monaghan Task Force on Australian Public Service and Defence Housing Programs interim report, which was debated in this Parliament many years ago, recommended payment of an explicit subsidy and the abandoning of the long term practice of housing for personnel being established reasonably proximate to their base or establishment. I believe that the general consensus of all members of this House is that housing is and should always be regarded as a strict condition of service and that rent arrangements pertaining to defence housing must be preserved, protected and defended.

The establishment by the Hawke Government of the Defence Housing Authority represented a milestone in the direction of improving conditions for service personnel. The Housing Authority quickly publicised the fact that almost half of the stock of defence service housing in this country, that is, approximately 12,000 houses occupied by service personnel and their families, was below standard. As Mrs Hamilton was able to ascertain, this was a major contributing factor to the poor morale in the Australian Defence Force.

The condition and quality of defence service housing at Townsville, the home of the Third Brigade and the Royal Australian Air Force base at Garbutt, present a totally different picture. The average standard of defence housing in Townsville compares more than favourably with defence housing in other areas around this country. More than 1,800 service homes are located in the Townsville and Thuringowa region. Over the last two years approximately $1m has been spent on maintenance programs and important repairs to existing housing stock of approximately 90 homes. These works include enclosing and paving under houses, refurbishing kitchens and bathrooms, fitting exhaust fans and ceiling fans and fitting security doors, deadlocks and window security screens. Furthermore, 15 new homes are about to be constructed in Townsville for service personnel, costing about $1.4m. More than 65 homes are to be purchased and built in the Townsville region to satisfy the requirements of the personnel who will make up the Fifth Aviation Regiment, `A' Squadron, to operate the Black Hawk helicopters, which are to be located in Townsville.

When I was elected there was a tremendous backlog of complaints about housing in my electorate. You, Mr Deputy Speaker, will recall that the Hamilton report was initiated by Townsville-based spouses of service personnel at a meeting in September 1985 at the Townsville Commonwealth Centre. A lot has been done in the Townsville region to upgrade existing housing stock and to ensure that new housing stock meets the expectations of Defence Force families for comfort, security and maintenance, which they are entitled to as a condition of service.

But if the housing problem is being solved by this Government, many other areas are also being addressed by the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel at a rate unmatched in the history of this country. Her performance certainly cannot be compared with the lack of performance by the Fraser Government when the backlog of these issues accumulated, resulting in frustration and despair for service personnel and their families.

In 1986 I had discussions with Mr Des Tracy, the then Principal of the Vincent State Primary School in Townsville, concerning a specific issue that confronted defence families-the problem being encountered by children in gaining a fundamental understanding of reading, writing and arithmetic because of the frequent transfers from school to school as a result of parents' postings. Mr Des Tracy and his support staff at the Vincent State Primary School developed a program called `Basic Learning in Primary Schools', which was designed to provide an intensified course to uplift the reading, writing and arithmetic skills of primary school children to enable them to cope with the established school curriculum. Service personnel owe a tremendous debt to Mr Des Tracy, the former Principal of the Vincent State Primary School in Townsville, for his wonderful, imaginative initiative in assisting the education of children who had suffered as a result of frequent postings of their father or mother, as the case may be.

In Townsville we have also established a regional educational liaison officer who provides professional advice and assistance to service families, monitoring their education needs and representing them before the State Government, in particular, the Queensland Department of Education. We have also established at the Heatley State High School and the Vincent State Primary School a pilot scheme which introduces a student portfolio into those schools containing examples of a student's work and interests. When the child has to leave the school because of the posting of the child's parent he is able to take away with him a portfolio as to his performance and the subjects he has attempted. This is a major initiative that has been welcomed by service personnel in Townsville.

Child-care facilities have been established for defence personnel in my electorate. They are a tremendous facility for the families of service personnel there. I pay tribute to the work of Mrs Jan Ramsdale, who played a major role in campaigning for the provision of child-care facilities at Vincent in the Townsville region and in their establishment.

The Australian Defence Families Information Liaison Service has now been put in place. It assists service families in settling into new areas, finds employment for spouses and liaises with local education services. The former Commander of the District Support Group at Lavarack Barracks, Colonel Peter Desmond, has established, with the help of a number of people, a program called `Leisureama', which introduces newly arrived personnel to civilian facilities-sporting clubs and so on-in the Townsville area so that they have an opportunity to integrate quickly into the civilian community.

The Government, in particular the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, should be congratulated on the excellent work done to date in the campaign to implement as quickly as possible the recommendations of the Hamilton report. I know that members on both sides of the House will continue to campaign to ensure that the interests of defence service personnel around this country are at least maintained to a level commensurate with the civilian community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to mention initially the contribution of the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay). I recognise his longstanding, deep and sincere interest in defence. Whilst I recognise that sincere interest, I cannot endorse many of the comments he has made because he is trying to endorse Government policies which are essentially corrupt, inadequate and lacking certainly in a great deal of perception. I will go a little further on these points. I am thankful for the opportunity to endorse the comments made earlier this afternoon by the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), a former officer with a distinguished service career in our armed forces. We certainly look forward to the contributions of the new honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor), also a former distinguished member of Australia's armed forces. It is a pity that he cannot be a part of this significant debate today.

SPEECH.PARA: From my own point of view, I am a former senior Royal Australian Air Force officer, having joined the RAAF in 1956 as an airman, so I have some understanding of the problems that confront our armed forces personnel today. In the slightly more than 25 years I served in the armed forces, and having been married for almost all of that time, my family suffered, probably typically, the challenges that many service men and women confront today. Two of my children were born in Melbourne and two in the Northern Territory. As far as I can recall, we changed our residential address-I have been trying to work it out precisely today-about 23 times in 25 years. My children went to 11 different schools in three different countries. While I am on the topic of children, any service father or mother would appreciate that, when children are moved under the auspices of the defence organisation, bright children seem to mature and broaden their horizons appreciably and respectably and can compete with all the other school children with whom they spend their time, but for average children-and I had two-it is an interminable struggle. For below average children-and I had one-especially where remedial tuition is involved, it is a challenge indeed and one that invariably affects them substantially. It is a blight on their potential working lives.

In the 25 1/2 years that I spent in the Services I served in almost all the mainland States, the United States and the United Kingdom. As a formerly dedicated serviceman I am appalled that since this Government came to power in 1983 we have seen the largest exodus of devoted and sincere people from the armed forces ever in peace time. Total separations over that period stand at approximately 41,800 personnel of all ranks, to February 1988. What a disgraceful record this Government has in personnel management. All we have heard today are platitudes-what the Government may be going to do. Members of the Government talk about our leader and harp on the things he has tried to achieve in the time he has been in the Parliament and especially while he has been our Leader. All the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) and the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) can look at today is a weary record of non-achievement-promises with very little effect.

The effect of their policies is something that I want to address while on the topic of the 41,800 personnel who have left the Services over recent years. In 1983, 6,485 personnel separated from the armed forces; in 1984 the figure was 7,451; in 1985, 7,709; in 1986, 9,015; and in 1987, 9,113. The figure for January 1988 is 1,209 and, for February, 836. What an appalling indictment of this Government. If this trend continues, and allowing for the fact that the January separations are generally the highest for each year, we could be looking at a wastage rate for 1988 of over 14.5 per cent of the total manpower of our forces. Last year the average wastage rate was an unacceptable 12.6 per cent which, when one compares it with the rate we are likely to achieve in 1988, is almost acceptable. Since 1985 over 27,000 personnel have left the Services, which represents 30 per cent of the 70,000 armed forces personnel, or over 43 per cent of the trained personnel base of 62,000 people. So the sorry record continues.

In the Army since 1985 we have had a turnover of approximately 10,000 soldiers and 1,200 officers from an overall authorised strength of about 32,000 people. This is equivalent to about 35 per cent of the total strength. There are 258 officer positions vacant at the moment and this appears to be growing at the rate of about 60 year. In the Navy in the first nine months of this financial year there have been about 155 notifications given by people planning to separate at the rank of commander and below, and they have been given against the backdrop of a 10-year average of about 98 for the equivalent nine-month period. Thirty seamen commanders have left the Navy since 1987, compared with the long term yearly average of seven. Among these commanders, as previously mentioned in the debate, were five who were either currently serving ship commanders or who had recently served in major command and control positions. This is particularly relevant when we only have about seven ships that currently attract commanders of that rank.

We have seen today the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel trying to get into the bribery game. The Air Force has suffered even more than the other services in many respects, particularly in that ever-important arena of pilots. The RAAF this financial year is expected to lose not less than 130 pilots. This compares with the 20-year average of just 47. Let us look at some of the figures. In the financial year 1985-86 the wastage rate was 70. In 1986-87, the wastage rate increased to 107. In just six months of the financial year 1987-88, 117 resignations were tendered compared with a six-monthly 20-year average of just 23. In the worst set of circumstances, we could see the RAAF lose upwards of 300 pilots this year, which is an appalling and totally unacceptable rate. There have been allusions to the situation in 75 Squadron-the only squadron we have defending the north. There are only seven pilots for 20 aircraft, and yet we hear the Minister summarily trying to explain that away by saying that the FA18 re-equipment program is going on. Where are our reserves of pilots to cope with the normally routine challenge in the armed forces of training other pilots to take over as these new aircraft are introduced? Should the current trend continue, pilot wastage this year could be about five times the ability of the Australian defence forces to replace the loss, as the RAAF's capacity to train pilots is limited to approximately 70 pilots a year. This is especially so when one realises that fewer than that number graduate, given the extraordinarily high standards set for Air Force pilots. There are generally heavy losses occurring amongst other specialist Defence Force personnel areas. We are losing engineers, project personnel, communications specialists and computer experts, amongst a very wide array of people whom we can literally not afford to lose.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are they going to get a bonus?

—Given this Government's initiative, a bonus of any sort is entirely likely. There is a new trend for officers to resign mid-career, thus leaving the pool of higher people capable of reaching the highest level of command in the Services depleted. One must really begin to wonder whether it is the best who leave first.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the Hamilton report on Supporting Service Families. It is probably appropriate to recall quickly what the original terms of reference were. The terms of reference for the study given to Mrs Sue Hamilton were:
1. To conduct a study into the main problems facing spouses of service personnel, taking cognizance of:
a. the diminution of normal community lifestyle choices resulting from the exigencies of service life, and
b. community attitudes towards service spouses and families.
2. The study should include, but should not necessarily be limited to:
a. identifying employment difficulties facing service spouses and recommending any practical steps that can be taken to improve employment opportunities in public service and private employment;
b. identifying any adverse effects of existing posting and promotion policies on family life and, having regard to service requirements, recommending practical solutions; and
c. identifying deficiencies in living conditions and support facilities for spouses at service bases and recommending practical solutions and priorities for action.
3. On completion the study is to be forwarded to the Minister for Defence.

It is interesting to note that the Hamilton report was first announced in December 1985. The Minister for Defence announced that Mrs Sue Hamilton would identify the main problems facing service spouses caused by the special circumstances of service life. In April 1986 the Hamilton report and its recommendations were published. The report is therefore now two years old. What an indictment of a Government constantly claiming, in its smart alec ways, that it is responsive to the needs of the people of this nation-a caring, benevolent Government. What utter rubbish!

In June 1986 the report was accepted by the Minister and the Chiefs of Staff Committee. The implementation team was established to assist the Deputy Secretary A in the Department of Defence and the Assistant Chief of the Defence Force (Policy) to implement the report. Looking briefly at the 15 substantial recommendations, we can look at the directive at ministerial level that the issue of family morale in the Australian Defence Force is one of high priority. After many years of service one does not get a ministerial directive to increase or raise morale. Morale is a function of leadership and the work ethic. It is not something that one dreams up and issues a directive on. Unless there is proper organisation order, combined with adequate and appropriate leadership, morale will continue to stay in the pits and that is, unfortunately, where it remains today.

We heard the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel today talk in terms of back-to-back postings and staying in one geographical area for something of the order of three years and possibly six years. Given the rate of exodus from the armed forces at the moment, one cannot believe that three-year postings-let alone six-year postings-are within the province of our expectations. It is much more likely that many of these very well and highly trained personnel we have will move at much more frequent intervals in order to make up deficiencies in other areas.

We have heard about the Australian Defence Families Information and Liaison Staff (ADFILS) scheme. I have looked through many of the implementation arrangements that are being made at the moment, and I am appalled at the arrangements that indicate to me increasing bureaucracy in a monolithic Department of Defence and some of the major headquarters areas that exist around Australia-a bureaucracy which is already constraining and curtailing the operational efficiency of the armed forces where, in the major headquarters around Australia and particularly on Russell Hill in Canberra, there are far too many bureaucrats pushing too many pens across too many desks and achieving too little.

In conclusion, despite the Minister's glib assurances that everything is under control, it is obvious that the general situation in respect of management of the armed forces still poses significant problems and there is little indication or prospect that the position will be rectified in the near future. There is nothing new offered to disenchanted and disillusioned service men and women in the Minister's statement this afternoon. They have heard it all before. They are aware of the promises and have not been persuaded by them. The Minister refers to the promises and achievements. How absurd! But a promise is not an achievement until it has been fulfilled and the Australian Defence Force personnel are very well aware of this fact and are unlikely to forget it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —There were going to be, I understand, two speakers from both sides in this debate. We did have on our side an impromptu contribution from the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay), for which we thank him. The Opposition has graciously agreed that I also speak, having been intended to be the second speaker for the Government, and I understand that that may, in part at least, be due to the goodwill shown by the Government in facilitating the earlier speech by the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore). I thank the Opposition for its sanction.
—Now say something sensible.

—I thank the honourable member for McPherson. I shall try to do that. May I first of all thank him for his words of kindness to me, as I believe they were, in acknowledging my very deep commitments in relation to the issues under debate. Let me reciprocate to a degree by referring to the contribution by the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson). While I strongly disagree, as he did with the honourable member for Herbert, on the subject of exactly the solutions that we ought to be adopting and the criticisms of the Government, I nevertheless feel that his own contribution, in talking about the difficulties of service life, was extremely important. Very few of us in this place really do understand what service life is like and how difficult and disruptive it is of family life. My understanding has been gathered not as a serving member of the armed forces but as a local member who has endeavoured to work closely with the local community of service families. I acknowledge that the honourable member's knowledge is based on some very hard long years of service.

SPEECH.PARA: Last Monday I had the honour of representing the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at the Anzac Day sunset service in Martin Place in Sydney. At that service representatives of the armed forces spoke of their concern that the Australian public is not aware of the sacrifices which members of the armed forces and their families make for their country. I strongly share and support those sentiments and I remind the people of Australia that the sacrifices that are made by members of the armed forces and their families are not made only in time of war, but are ongoing and evidence an ongoing commitment to defend this country.

I have said before in the House but I want to say again that when I was first elected as the Federal member for Hughes I was totally unaware of the enormous problems that existed in service communities. It was only when I became a member that I became aware of the fact that at that time, in 1984, service personnel and their families were still very much treated as second-class citizens. I am proud to have been part of a successful campaign by service spouses to secure some justice from this Government; justice, I might add, which had not been forthcoming from the previous Liberal Government nor, I believe, from any government of any political persuasion since Federation.

The story about how things really got moving in the Government and how we started to make some advances has never really been told. It is a great tribute to those service spouses who had the courage effectively to stand up to authority. They are very much the unsung heroes of this debate and of the great advances that are being made in the conditions of service families.

As I have said, back in 1984 when I was first elected as member for Hughes, I was unaware of the conditions that people had to put up with. I was unaware that at Holsworthy-the major defence establishment in my electorate-there were, for all practical purposes, no shops. I was unaware of the incredible disruption to the lifestyle of families and children, caused by service families being moved around Australia at regular intervals. I was certainly unaware of the absolute dearth of any community spirit or community solidarity in service communities. I was also unaware of the fact that service communities just did not have the advantage of all those achievements of the 1970s that resulted in improvements to the quality of life of civilians-that awareness by people that they had a right to basic community services. When I went out to Holsworthy I met with people at the neighbourhood centre. I specifically requested a meeting. At that meeting we began to talk about the problems, and I am pleased to say that one of the skills I can bring to bear as a member of Parliament-I say this modestly-is an organisational and lobbying skill, which I decided to try to bring to bear in relation to service conditions.

I pay tribute to the former Democrat Senator Colin Mason, who strongly championed the cause of service spouses. I might say, although I do not want to be particularly partisan in this debate, that members of the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia were certainly nowhere to be seen. We organised a deputation of spouses to come to Canberra, and I believe that was the first time-this is something I will say many times in this debate-that a Federal Minister for Defence ever really listened to service spouses.

Having said some nice things about members of the Opposition in this debate, let me give the down side. The down side of the Opposition's attitude at that time, which I hope is changing, was partially reflected in the comments made by the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) when he referred to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) in this debate and said, `For a woman you've got a hide as thick as a rhinoceros'. Unfortunately, that was the sort of condescending, sexist approach that high ranking officers of the department of Defence and politicians adopted towards service spouses. They did not recognise that people who live the life of a service spouse have rights and are thinking, caring people who are prepared to stand up and be heard for the advancement of their community.

What happened when the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) met the women from that delegation-I have checked with my office-on 22 May 1985? He listened with great interest and compassion to their story. He did not try to stifle them; he encouraged them and invited them to talk to the media about their concerns, which they did on the front steps of Parliament House. The Minister subsequently visited Holsworthy Village. I recall a memorable meeting in a shabby hall in Holsworthy which was attended by in excess of 100 spouses and many screaming babies in a situation of absolute turmoil and chaos. The spouses poured forth their anger at the neglect that successive governments had shown, Minister Beazley listened, took note of what was said, and acted on the concerns that those spouses raised. Let me say, without singling out individuals, that people like Joanne Balserini, Beverley Bolton, Kathy Sinclair, Margaret Davis, Margaret Walton and Sue Brookshore were extremely courageous when they came to Canberra to stick their necks out, because that had not been done before. There they were on the front steps of Parliament House taking on the establishment. Of course, it is now well accepted that there is a national voice for service spouses, but at that stage there was nothing. These were people of great courage.

I have spent some time on this matter because it is important to understand that the reforms of this Government were very much inspired by people power, by spouses getting together and deciding to speak out for the advancement of their community and their lifestyle. In 1985 Minister Beazley established an inquiry into the problems faced by spouses of Australian Defence Force personnel. As we all know, that inquiry was conducted by Sue Hamilton, Assistant Secretary, Office of the Status of Women, and it reported in April 1986. The inquiry was extremely substantial. It involved open meetings for spouses in just about every major area in Australia, and attendances at those meetings totalled in excess of 4,300 people; more than 700 submissions were made to the inquiry.

I want to say something which is not only unrehearsed but which has occurred to me in the course of this debate: I hope that one of the things we can develop in this Parliament is a much stronger bipartisan approach regarding policies on service personnel. I believe that members on the Government side are committed to trying to achieve that if it is humanly possible. We have accorded defence the highest status within our Government. The Minister for Defence is a member of the Cabinet of the country. For the first time in the history of the Australian Parliament there is a Minister for Defence Science and Personnel who is directly and specifically responsible for the conditions of defence personnel and their families and for reporting to Parliament in that regard. However, in order to achieve a bipartisan policy, some policy commitments must emanate from the other side. It is a matter of great regret that in the 20 minutes for which the shadow Minister for defence, the honourable member for McPherson, spoke, not one single policy proposal was espoused for 15 minutes. After 15 minutes, and in the honourable member's remaining 5 minutes, a couple of ideas came forward. They included suggestions for more child care, more staff for Australian Defence Families Information and Liaison Staff (ADFILS), and spouse employment offices, and other ideas for greater government expenditure on defence.

There is a massive problem, an insurmountable problem, that is, that the shadow Minister for defence does not speak for the Opposition on this matter. He is not in the shadow Cabinet and the people who call the shots in the Opposition have not proposed increases in defence expenditure to meet the needs that I believe we all acknowledge. Something has to be done, something even more than this Government has done, to improve conditions. Of course, the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), has backed the call of the Business Council of Australia for massive spending cuts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not in defence.

—Not in defence, says the honourable member for Macquarie. I refer the honourable member to the document put out by the Business Council of Australia at 6 o'clock on Sunday, 17 April, backed up by a Press statement issued by the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong, not only on the same date but at the same hour and the same minute, in collusion with the Business Council of Australia. At page 16 and 17 of its report the Council called for cuts of $300m in defence alone. I am glad that the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) displays an interest. Perhaps he should consider what his shadow Minister is saying. Among the $300m cuts proposed it was suggested that the Defence Housing Authority should fund the cost of new housing as far as possible from rents and borrowings. What will that do to the quality of life of families of Australian Defence Force personnel? There was a proposal for cuts of $300m in defence alone. Can honourable members believe that? What did the shadow Treasurer say about these spending cuts? Let us look at his document-and the honourable member is welcome to look at it. He said, in the first line:

SPEECH.PARA: While the Business Council's call to reduce government expenditure is welcome, it does not go far enough.
He wants more cuts in defence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did he say that it does not go far enough in defence?

—He said that it does not go far enough. Proposals have been put forward by the Business Council of Australia which fall short of the demands of the shadow Treasurer in terms of expenditure cuts. There are many things I would like to have said in this debate, but time does not permit. I return to my major theme: let us have bipartisan policies. At present a joint committee is looking into Defence Force wastage. Let the Opposition put forward specific proposals for improvements. We on this side already have a commendable track record, and we will do a lot more. The time for rhetoric is over. It is time to put forward specific proposals. Until that occurs there is no credibility in the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise for only a few minutes at the conclusion of this debate. When we were advised of the statement by the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly), it was suggested that there would be only a couple of speakers from each side, but I am glad to have the opportunity to comment at this late stage. I preface my remarks by reminding the House that within my electorate of Macquarie is the largest Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) transport base in Australia, probably one of the biggest bases in the Commonwealth. I frequently visit that base purely as a member showing interest, and I meet many of the personnel at functions. Before I was elected to Parliament, I had many people from the base who, on their retirement, joined my staff in performing the work in which I was engaged.

SPEECH.PARA: The main question that people in my electorate, and especially people associated with the RAAF base at Richmond, want answered tonight is: if things are as good as the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel suggested today and if the Government is doing so much, why are so many service personnel resigning? This question has been raised a couple of times already. The answer is quite simple. First, there is a lack of confidence in this Government and a sense of neglect and even, in some cases, of betrayal. There is also the knowledge that the best way to protest is by resigning. To me, that is what has happened.

It is hard to criticise the Ministers handling defence matters when their intentions are right, and I believe they are. I believe that the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel and the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) are trying to do the best they can in exercising the responsibilities of their portfolios, but they stand alone in an unsympathetic Cabinet and that is where the main problem lies. Therefore, I will direct my criticisms not at these Ministers but at the Government which leaves them ill-equipped to respond to problems facing the defence forces.

The main problem with the paper brought down this afternoon is similar to that which characterises the Government's economic policy-the pace of adjustment. For three years now, the Government has consulted, talked and promised. It regularly advises the Parliament that reforms are in place. Yet anyone in touch with the services knows that this is not true. I refer, for example, to postings. In the past few weeks, I made representations for an airman who was to be sent against his wishes to Adelaide. His replacement, who was to come from Adelaide, wanted to stay in Adelaide. But orders, no matter how irrational, are orders and the postings swap took place.

The reforms about which the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel talks are not proceeding at the pace she suggests. I commend the initiatives in bonuses-of which we heard today-counselling, child care and education allowances, but I have to say, as the Minister knows, that they are too little too late. These announcements and orders on paper to lift morale will not restore the broken relationship that exists beween the Government and its service personnel. Ministerial statements and afternoon teas at bases will not solve the crisis in the Australian Defence Force. What is needed is the restoration of funds cut in past Budgets-and we have seen it happen in every one of the Government's Budgets. Also needed are radical boosts to the programs announced today, and a new commitment from the Government to those who are expected to give their lives.

That point seems to be getting put aside regularly these days. We are talking about people in our armed forces who may one day be expected to give their lives for this country. It is surprising that the statement today was brought down in the shadow of Anzac Day, which I am glad to say was a day of great remembrance in my own electorate and indeed throughout Australia. I hope that the Minister will not be remembered as one of those politicians who, by failing to promote political will in government for defence, betray those who may be sent ill prepared into battle in some future war. To escape that possible ignominy, she and the Minister for Defence need to do a lot more in the next Budget than they have been able to achieve in past Budgets.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Duncan, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DUNCAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Education Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The main purpose of this Bill is to amend the States Grants (School Assistance) Act 1984 to supplement for cost increases grants already appropriated for government and non-government schools programs in 1988. The Bill also modifies certain existing provisions in the Act relating to non-government schools which change their location. Under the new provisions, where the change is to a location adjacent to the school and, where it does not involve a change in the level of education being provided by the school, the school or school system will no longer be required to notify the Minister of the change. These new provisions will apply to schools which are seeking approval this year to change their location in 1990.

Further amendments include: extension of the provisional approval period to two years for new non-government schools or for a school undergoing a notifiable change; new non-government schools will now be eligible for establishment grants if they serve a developing area. Previously these schools were required to be situated in a developing area.
The total amount of supplementation to be provided by this Bill is $21m. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Miles) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Duncan, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DUNCAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Education Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Act 1987 was introduced and passed in the Parliament in the last session to provide grants to the States and the Northern Territory for universities, advanced education, institutes of tertiary education and technical and further education for 1988. The main purpose of this Bill is to amend that Act to adjust for cost movements in the tertiary education grants. It will also provide additional funds for superannuation in higher education to cater for the 3 per cent productivity claim and emerging costs for the States.

As part of the Government's drug offensive it has been decided that funds should be made available for the coordination of drug and alcohol education in teaching hospitals. It is felt that an important means of combating drug and alcohol abuse is to ensure that the curriculum for undergraduate students in medical schools brings out the dangers and problems that arise from this abuse. Consequently provision is made in this Bill for funds to be made available under a new program for the 10 university teaching hospitals presently receiving recurrent funds from the Commonwealth Government. The funding for this new program is to be provided initially through the Department of Employment, Education and Training, and in 1988 will amount to some $560,000.

In total the Bill will provide for additional Government expenditure of some $66.5m of which $42.9m will result from the Government's agreed procedures to make retrospective adjustment for cost variations and some $23m will be provided in connection with superannuation in higher education institutions.

In introducing this Bill we have also taken the opportunity to make a number of minor technical amendments. Non-government teachers colleges have been provided with grants under the special assistance for students program in line with other higher education institutions. They have not however been required to produce as a condition of this grant statistical and other information pertinent to this program. In line with the requirements for other higher education institutions we have now included this as a condition of grant under this program.

We have also, consistent with grants for higher education institutions, made provision for grants under the States Grants (Nurse Education Transfer Assistance) Act 1985 to be offset in accounting procedures by institutes of tertiary education. In the technical and further education sector we have recognised that building work undertaken up to the end of a particular year and commitments entered into for the purchase of equipment during the year cannot necessarily be paid for within that year. Consequently grants for 1988 need not necessarily be expended in 1988 but may be carried over for later payment. It is to be stressed that this Bill is of a routine variety consistent with amending Acts made in previous years to legislation providing funds for tertiary education. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Miles) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH EMPLOYEES' REHABILITATION AND COMPENSATION BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Howe, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Bill 1988 seeks to repeal the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971 and to introduce a new scheme of compensation and rehabilitation for persons who are injured in the course of their employment by the Commonwealth. Between 1976 and 1986, the Commonwealth's expenditure on workers' compensation increased by over 700 per cent, from $25.04m to $203.29m per annum. Clearly, this situation could not be allowed to continue. Accordingly, the Government decided that the compensation Act should be reviewed with the aim of establishing a more equitable and cost-effective compensation system, with particular emphasis on the rehabilitation of injured employees. The result is a Bill which, when it comes into operation, will provide for many important changes in the compensation system and the circumstances in which compensation will be payable. The Bill will minimise the human and financial cost of work-caused injury and disease while at the same time providing adequate compensation and support for long term incapacitated employees.

The main aspects of the new scheme are the provision of a better range of benefits for injured employees and the establishment of a new body to administer the Act. The Bill will also provide incentives for injured employees to return to work as soon as possible and will provide greater powers in relation to rehabilitation. The Office of the Commissioner for Employees' Compensation will be abolished and replaced by the new Commission for the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation of Commonwealth Employees. The new Commission will consist of three persons to be appointed by the Governor-General-a Chief Executive Officer and two part-time commissioners, one to represent the Commonwealth and the other to represent the interests of employees. This structure will allow employees and employing agencies to participate directly in the administration of the compensation and rehabilitation system.

Some specific functions of the Commission will be: to determine claims accurately and expeditiously; to minimise the duration of incapacity by arranging for the assessment of the rehabilitation needs and prospects of employees; to cooperate with other bodies with the aim of reducing the incidence of work-related injuries; and to conduct and promote research into the incidence and prevention of work-related injuries. The Commission will be required to comply with directions of a general nature issued to it by the Minister.

While the new scheme will be administered primarily by the Commission, the Bill makes provision for statutory authorities to be appointed in the future as self-administrators by ministerial notice in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. Those authorities will have all the powers and functions of the Commission in relation to the determination of claims lodged by its employees but will also be required to comply with ministerial directions. The Commission will be required to report on the operations of self-administrators under the legislation and the Chief Executive Officer will be empowered to require the provision of such information as is necessary for that purpose. Self-administration will help to instil an awareness in those authorities of the costs of compensation and the benefits to be derived from effective rehabilitation and occupational health and safety measures.

Under the existing Act, the Commissioner determines the liability of the Commonwealth to pay compensation. This legislation will impose that liability to pay compensation on the Commission or self-administrator. In order to fund the system, the Commission will be required to calculate, on the basis of the each organisation's claims record, the contributions to be made by departments and statutory authorities to the Consolidated Revenue Fund. These contributions will act as a direct financial inducement to each department and statutory authority to reduce workers' compensation costs by effective rehabilitation and occupational health and safety measures.

I turn now to the benefits which will be payable under this legislation. The benefits package is aimed specifically at assisting those employees most in need-that is, the long-term incapacitated workers. At the heart of the new scheme is the change from a system of fixed long-term benefits adjusted by regulation to one of weekly benefits calculated on the basis of the individual employee's normal weekly earnings. An employee's normal weekly earnings will be based on his or her pre-injury salary and will take into account certain allowances and regular rostered overtime which the employee is required to work as a condition of his or her employment. Employees who are incapacitated for work will receive weekly benefits equal to 100 per cent of normal weekly earnings for the equivalent of the first 45 weeks of that incapacity.

Where appropriate, the Bill will encourage employees to return to work on a gradual basis by allowing their income to increase according to the number of hours worked. For example, an employee who returns to work for 50 per cent of the number of hours he or she worked before the injury would be entitled to an amount of compensation which, combined with the income from that employment, would provide the employee with 85 per cent of his or her normal weekly earnings. There will be upper and lower limits on weekly payments so as to provide a measure of equality and a guaranteed minimum income for those who are on a low wage. The maximum amount payable will be an amount equal to 150 per cent of average weekly earnings for all employees in the Australian work force. The minimum amount will be either $202 per week plus $50 for a dependent spouse and $25 for each dependent child, or 90 per cent of the employee's normal weekly earnings, whichever is the lower. These benefits will be indexed automatically in line with movements in the consumer price index.

The level of weekly benefits payable to an injured employee who is capable of returning to work will be calculated by subtracting the amount the employee is earning, or would be able to earn in suitable employment, from his or her normal weekly earnings. Suitable employment for an employee who is permanently employed by the Commonwealth will mean employment by the Commonwealth or a statutory authority. In the case of a casual employee, suitable employment may include self-employment or employment in private industry. This distinction reflects the Government's commitment to maintaining the employer-employee relationship and reinforces the nexus between an employee's contract of employment and his or her rights to compensation. Given that benefits under the scheme have been set at levels which are fair and equitable, the Government has decided that it would no longer be appropriate for employees to be able to redeem weekly benefits for lump sums except where those weekly payments are below $50 per week. Weekly payments will cease at age 65. This Government does not consider it appropriate that employees should continue to receive workers' compensation benefits after the normal retirement age.

Under the existing Act an employee was required to establish only that his or her employment was a contributing factor in the contraction of a disease. This test does not adequately reflect the rights and obligations of the Commonwealth and its employees in relation to work-related disease and frequently results in the Commonwealth being liable to pay compensation for diseases which have little, if any, connection with employment. This Bill seeks to remedy that situation by requiring an employee to show that his or her employment contributed in a material degree to the contraction of the disease. The Government believes that this is a test which is firm but fair and which properly reflects the balance between the interests of the Commonwealth as employer and its employees. An employee will not be required to show that his or her employment caused the disease, or even that it was the most important factor in the contraction of the disease. It is intended that the test will require an employee to demonstrate that his or her employment was more than a mere contributing factor in the contraction of the disease. Accordingly, it will be necessary for an employee to show that there is a close connection between the disease and the employment in which he or she was engaged.

In determining whether employment contributed in a material degree to the contraction of a disease in a particular case, regard would be had to whether the employment in which the employee was engaged carried an inherent risk of the employee contracting the disease in question and whether some characteristic or feature of the employment tended to cause, aggravate or accelerate the disease. A disease which has been contributed to in a material degree by employment will be deemed to be an injury. Compensation will be payable if that injury results in the death, incapacity or impairment of the employee.

The Bill will also contain disease provisions, similar to those contained in the existing Act, under which an employee suffering a specified disease will automatically be entitled to compensation if he or she had been engaged in certain specified kinds of employment. The Bill will extend coverage to employees injured in ordinary recesses, such as lunch breaks, and by acts of violence arising as a result of their employment by the Commonwealth, for example, staff working overseas injured by warfare, terrorism, et cetera. The journey provisions in the existing Act have been modified to require that journeys to or from the place of employment must commence or terminate at the employee's place of residence.

A significant factor in the escalation of compensation costs which I described earlier is the length of time that employees remain on compensation. It is obvious to this Government that the only way to reduce the period spent on compensation is by the effective rehabilitation of injured employees. To this end, the Bill will encourage the speedy rehabilitation of employees who are injured by enabling employing agencies or the Commission to arrange for the assessment of the rehabilitation needs of the employee and the type of work which that person could perform following appropriate retraining.

Consistent with the goal of minimising incapacity and impairment, employing agencies and the Commission will have much broader powers in relation to the provision of rehabilitation programs than were previously available. The Commission will be able to approve persons and organisations as rehabilitation program providers and to arrange directly with them for the provision of rehabilitation programs tailored to the individual needs of employees. If an employee refuses to undertake a rehabilitation program, his or her rights to compensation will be suspended. On the other hand, employing agencies will be required to take all reasonable steps to provide suitable employment for employees who have undertaken rehabilitation programs. The Commission will also examine the introduction of a new system of work trials for injured employees to enable them to participate fully in the work force. The Commission will have the power to arrange for the provision of necessary aids and appliances, and home, vehicle or workplace modifications.

In conjunction with this, the Bill will provide for the payment of up to $200 per week in compensation if, after four weeks of incapacity, the employee reasonably requires another person to provide household services, such as cooking, cleaning and household maintenance. A further amount, up to a maximum of $200 per week, will be payable if he or she reasonably requires attendant care services, such as feeding, bathing, supply of medication or other services of a personal nature.

In addition to the weekly benefits which I have already outlined, the Bill will provide for the payment of lump sums for permanent impairment and non-economic loss. These payments will replace awards of damages at common law for losses of a non-economic nature. A maximum of $80,000 will be payable for injuries which result in a permanent impairment and up to $30,000 for non-economic loss.

Under the existing Act, lump sum payments are made on the basis of a table of maims, with the level of payment being determined having regard to the loss, or loss of the efficient use, of various parts of the body. That approach has been abandoned and the level of payments in future will be determined using a `whole person' approach, similar to that used under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986.

The whole person approach allows the degree of impairment to be assessed on a more accurate basis and expressed as a percentage loss of the use of the ability of the person to undertake normal living activities. A guide to the assessment of amounts of compensation payable in cases of permanent impairment will be prepared by the Commission for the purposes of the Bill, subject to ministerial approval. There will be a minimum threshold of 10 per cent impairment under which compensation will not be payable, except where the impairment resulted from the loss of a finger or toe. In recognition that a permanent impairment may lead to considerable pain and suffering and loss of enjoyment of life, up to $30,000 will also be payable for any non-economic loss suffered by an employee. The non-economic loss element of compensation will also be assessed in accordance with the approved guide.

This Government recognises that special provision must be made for the dependants of an employee who has died as a result of a work-related injury. Accordingly, the death benefit payable under this legislation will be raised to $120,000 more than double that which was payable under the existing Act, and a further $40 per week will be payable for each dependent child of the employee. It is intended that, in administering the Act, the Commission will expedite the payment of death benefits in order to avoid creating hardship, particularly in cases where the surviving spouse and children were living in the same household as the deceased employee.

Perhaps the most controversial aspect of the new legislation is that common law actions against the Commonwealth will be replaced by the comprehensive benefits which I have described. It is clear to this Government that the common law negligence action which bases its entitlement on proof of fault is a costly, inefficient and inappropriate mechanism for compensating injured workers. Delays in settling these actions act as a positive disincentive for employees to return to work and encourage them to maximise the extent and duration of their injuries. The provision of an adequate level of weekly income, substantially increased lump sum payments on death or impairment, payments for additional expenses for medical costs, aids and appliances and household help, combined with a commitment to rehabilitation and the return to suitable employment, make redundant any need for redress to the courts. Accordingly, it will no longer be possible for an employee to sue the Commonwealth or a fellow employee. Actions against third parties will also be discouraged. Employees or their dependants who sue third parties will not be entitled to receive further benefits under the scheme and will be required to pay back any amount of compensation they have received. The Commission will pursue third parties if necessary by taking over an action in place of the employee.

There are some other matters which this Bill will address. For example, under the current system, an employee is deemed to be on unauthorised absence after two years absence from work as a result of an injury. This unjust situation will be remedied in this Bill. An employee who is incapacitated for work following a compensable injury will be considered to be on compensation leave. Compensation leave is designed to continue the employer-employee relationship during the period of incapacity. This is a significant improvement on the current system. An employee on compensation leave will, for the first 45 weeks of incapacity, continue to accrue sick leave and annual leave entitlements. Long service leave entitlements will continue to accrue throughout the whole period of incapacity.

This Bill will also seek to reduce the unreasonable costs associated with work-related injuries by introducing measures to prevent double dipping by employees using sick leave payments or superannuation entitlements while on compensation. For example, many employees who have been retired on invalidity grounds under the current legislation enjoy benefits under both compensation and superannuation schemes at a rate considerably in excess of their previous income. Special transitional provisions relating to the combined superannuation and compensation benefits payable to employees who have been invalided out of employment are contained in the Bill.

Top up of weekly benefits from sick leave entitlements will be prohibited. Payments by way of salary, wages or pay under compensation schemes in force in the States will reduce compensation accordingly. No make up pay or additional benefits under awards will be allowed where an employee receives benefits under this legislation.

The review and appeal provisions contained in the Bill are significantly different from those contained in the existing Act, under which the Commonwealth is generally the respondent in proceedings for review of determinations made by the Commissioner for Employees Compensation. This Bill will provide for the Commission to be respondent in proceedings before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the courts, and will also introduce compulsory reconsideration by the Commission before application can be made to the Tribunal for review of a determination. Reconsideration will be an informal procedure under which the original determination of the Commission will be reviewed by an officer of the Commission not involved in the original decision. Parties will be encouraged to adduce all relevant evidence at the reconsideration stage so as to resolve as many disputes as possible before the matter is heard by the Tribunal. These measures will facilitate the settlement of many applications for review before a formal hearing is held and improve the quality of primary decision making, thereby reducing the number of appeals to the Tribunal. In short, the Commission's direct involvement in review proceedings will be of mutual benefit to the Commission and the Tribunal.

Madam Speaker, the Government considers that this Bill will create a progressive compensation and rehabilitation system for Commonwealth employees which will result in fewer injuries, less suffering, lower costs and a better quality of life for those employees unfortunate enough to be injured in the course of their employment. I commend this Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Connolly) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: UNITED STATES NAVAL COMMUNICATION STATION (CIVILIAN EMPLOYEES) BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Howe, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to apply the provisions of the proposed Commonwealth Employees Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 to civilian employees of the Government of the United States of America at the naval communication station at North West Cape. These persons are currently covered by the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971, which is to be repealed. The proposals put forward in this Bill will have no impact on government expenditure since, under the terms of the agreement between the governments of Australia and the United States which establishes the station at North West Cape, the Government of the United States will reimburse the Commonwealth for any expenditure incurred under this Bill. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Connolly) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Barry Jones, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1988, which is now before the House, contains a wide variety of amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1987. Schedule 1 to the Bill, operative on and from 1 January 1988, contains a number of amendments. The first set of amendments relate to revised charging arrangements for general aviation aircraft at Essendon, Coolangatta and Launceston airports. Aircraft using aviation gasoline, Avgas, will now no longer be subject to terminal, navigation, rescue and firefighting charges for landings at these airports. The revenue forgone as a result of this change will be offset by a half a cent per litre increase in the excise and customs duty on aviation gasoline.

These revised arrangements were introduced after consultation with the aviation industry had revealed that, under the previous charging arrangements which came into effect last July, general aviation Avgas operators who used the three airports were disadvantaged compared with their competitors operating at the general aviation capital city secondary airports. The extent of the disparity was not foreseen by either the industry of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce at the time the changes were made last July. The changes relating to customs duties on certain petroleum products are also included in this schedule and ensure that the rates that became operative on and from 14 December 1987 are carried over the principal Act.

The next set of amendments relates to the Government's decisions on the Industries Assistance Commission's reports on the pulp, paper, paper products and printing industries, medical and scientific equipment and glass and glassware. The Government decided to accept the recommendations contained within the Commission's report on the pulp, paper, paper products and printing industries that tariffs assisting these industries be reduced over a two-year period on a tops down basis to a maximum of 15 per cent. Tariffs are generally 20 to 25 per cent, but many are at 10 per cent and below. All phasing of rates would commence from 1 January 1988. Some tariff anomalies will be corrected and concessional entry allowed on coated paper and on some other types of paper not produced locally. Tariff assistance for paper-making machinery will be reduced to minimum rates. Policy by-laws have been implemented to allow for paperboard used in cigarette packages and aseptic liquid containers to enter at minimum rates and for paperbacked textile wall coverings to enter at 15 per cent, the same rate as `paper' wallpaper. The Government rejected some of the Commission's recommendations and will not reintroduce the bounty on certain types of paper which expired last February. The pulp, paper, paper products and printing industries constitute a large and diverse sector of the Australian economy. These industries have specific areas with potential of developing into internationally competitive and technologically developed sectors of the economy.

In its decision on the medical and scientific equipment industry the Government has accepted the thrust of the Industries Assistance Commission's recommendations for reduced tariff assistance. Tariffs will be phased down progressively over two years commencing on 1 January 1988, with the general rate of 15 per cent being reached on 1 January 1990. The bulk of imports will continue to enter at minimum rates. Following the receipt of the Industries Assistance Commission's report on glass and glassware the Government decided to adopt, with a few exceptions, an industry-wide tariff rate of 15 per cent for the glass and glassware industry. Tariffs above 15 per cent are to be reduced on a `tops down' basis over three years to reach 15 per cent on 1 January 1991. The Government was of the opinion that the decision would minimise tariff-induced distortions in trade and investment decisions, thereby improving the international competitiveness of Australian industry. The Government also decided not to grant any short term assistance to users of glass fibre rovings who were required to pay higher prices for imports at a time of tight domestic supply. Amendments to implement certain changes in accordance with Australia's international trade agreements obligations are included.

A series of amendments made in the context of the current textiles, clothing and footwear sectoral policy are also included. These cover variations to the developing country exclusions from preference which are made annually; the insertion of the 1988 tender quota rates of duty following the settlement of the relevant premium tender quota rates; the extension of the validity of the 1987 quota allocations; and an increase in the customs value criterion which determines whether footwear is subject to tariff quota from $1.35 to $1.45. This schedule includes amendments to redress assistance anomalies which have become apparent following publication of the harmonised tariff. Six anomalies have been brought to notice which would have unacceptable consequences for the industries concerned. These, and the remedial actions proposed, are:
Polyethylene terephtahlate-
Duties are reduced from ten per cent to two per cent when used to make fibres and yarns. The change involves broadening the terms of a customs by-law;
Parts for leather coats, jackets, and the like-
This amendment ensures these goods continue to be subject to tariff quota;
Hand-made rugs-

The purpose of this amendment is to continue duty free entry of certain carpets until June 1988. These rugs and carpets are made by powered machines that are held in the hand and were not to be eligible for concessional entry following the Government's review of the textiles, clothing and footwear handicraft arrangements. They were to be subject to the carpet duty rates of 40 per cent general and 30 per cent developing countries from 1 January 1988. However, after representations from importers a review of the decision resulted in a deferral of implementation until 1 July 1988 to ensure that undue hardship does not occur to importers' business operations;
Men's or boys' suits-
An amendment to ensure that men's or boys' suits that consist of a jacket and a pair of shorts continue to be subject to quota;
Adjustable shoulder straps for brassieres-
An amendment to correctly exclude these goods from quota and thus maintain the arrangements that existed prior to the introduction of the harmonised tariff;
Paper sheeters, slitters, slitter-rewinders and rewinders-

This amendment will restore tariff assistance to local production of paper sheeters, slitters, slitter-rewinders and rewinders. Producers of these goods suffered a substantial loss of tariff assistance on 1 January when the previous import duty of 15 per cent was reduced to minimum rates. When Cabinet approved the introduction of the harmonised tariff it gave authority to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) in consultation with the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) and other relevant Ministers, to approve modifications on compelling industry grounds, before 1 January 1988. After receiving a submission on behalf of the bulk of the Australian industry and considering the arguments put forward it was concluded that this small industry could suffer serious injury, with consequent job losses, if tariff assistance were not restored. All Ministers consulted agreed that compelling industry grounds existed for restoration of the moderate 15 per cent tariff rate which applied prior to 1 January. Restoration of the Government's intended level of assistance will help to maintain the viability of the industry.
Two further amendments which, through the restructuring of the tariff, correct existing inconsistencies in tariff drafting are-
(A) Blinds and fittings and mountings for curtain tracks of polymers of styrene or vinyl chloride were incorrectly classified; and

(B) The tariff structure for therapeutic respiration apparatus could result in an incorrect rate of duty being collected. This change arose from the Government's consideration of the Industries Assistance Commission's report on medical and scientific equipment.

The final group of amendments includes redrafting of a minor nature. Schedule 2, operative on and from 3 February 1988, provides the basis for fulfilling the commitment of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) given at the Ruby Hutchison Memorial Address of 13 March 1987 to limit the indexation increases for August 1987 and February 1988 to a total of around 6 per cent. The amendments decrease the rates of duty as applying immediately prior to indexation on the February 1988 adjustment date so that when the legislative provisions for indexation are applied, which require the use of the published consumer price index, the resultant indexation increase is 2.5 per cent. This increase, when combined with the August 1987 indexation adjustment-3.5 per cent-yields a total indexation adjustment of 6 per cent.

Schedule 3, which is operative seven days after the royal assent, contains a variety of amendments. The first set of amendments results from further Government decisions on the Industries Assistance Commission's reports on the chemicals and plastics industries, the pulp, paper, paper products and printing industries and glass and glassware. The amendments are:
Pigments-

The changes proposed for inorganic pigments will provide significant benefits to industries using these products. The current very complex structure will be substantially simplified. This will ensure that the intent of the Government's decision on the policy for chemicals and plastics is properly realised. It will also assist industry by permitting more accurate and efficient classification of imports of these pigments;
Calendars-

The general tariff rate for calendars of a kind other than paper and paperbound of heading 4910 will be phased from 25 per cent on implementation on 1 January 1988, to 20 per cent from 1 January 1989 and to 15 per cent on 1 January 1990 in line with the phasing arrangements for the general tariff rate for calendars of paper and paperboard. This will avoid the creation of an anomaly in assistance between paper and paperboard calendars and calendars of other materials;
Tampons-

The Government decided to set the general tariff rate for tampons at 2 per cent. An anomaly previously existed in that tampons entered under tariff item 59.01.000 were dutiable at 2 per cent whilst, if entered under sub-item 48.21.900, were dutiable at 25 per cent. This proposal avoids the anomaly.
All goods other than tampons of subheading 5601.10 are to be dutiable at 15 per cent in order to bring subheading 5601.10 into line with the long term industry rate under subheading 4818.40.

There are two further amendments to apply the correct rate of customs duty where the drafting of the tariff structure could result in incorrect rates of customs duty being collected. These amendments involve the duties applying to graduated rules and machine and hand scales; and certain types of cords, cordage, braids and sleeving of glass, and arise from the Government's consideration of the Industries Assistance Commission's reports on medical and scientific equipment and glass and glassware.
