Finally this schedule includes an amendment to part II of schedule 4 where the Government has decided to admit free of customs duty national or traditional costumes imported by recognised ethnic groups. This will facilitate imports of genuine ethnic items in non-commercial quantities.
Financial Impact

The decision on the pulp, paper, paper products and printing industries will result in an estimated decrease in revenue of $1.31m in 1987-88, $9.65m in 1988-89 and $21.79m in 1989-90. The impact of the decision on medical and scientific equipment is difficult to assess and the duty reductions are likely to stimulate import growth in this already fast growing market. Such growth may completely offset the lower duty rate to be applied. The decision on glass and glassware will result in an estimated decrease in revenue of $95,000 in 1987-88, $350,000 in 1988-89 and $700,000 in 1989-90. The decision on the hand-made rugs will result in revenue forgone during the period 1 January 1988 to 30 June 1988 of approximately $90,000.

Whilst it is difficult to estimate the impact in regard to the decision on pigments, it is considered that there will be a small increase in revenue. Whilst there may be an initial reduction in revenue in regard to the decision on polyethylene terephthalate, this will be offset, at least in part, by the stronger competitive position of the relevant manufacturers. The other changes in the Bill are expected to have minimal financial impact. Details of the amendments contained in this Bill have been included in an explanatory memorandum which has been circulated for the information of honourable members. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Connolly) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Barry Jones, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1988, which is now before the House, gives effect to part of a package of measures announced by the Government on 13 April 1988 aimed at reinforcing the strategy and objectives of the Government's passenger motor vehicle policy and continuing the process of structural change in the automotive industry. On 29 May 1984, when the Government announced the current motor vehicle policy, or the plan as it has become more commonly known, it was indicated that special consideration would be given in early 1988 to the state of the industry report for 1987 prepared by the Automotive Industry Authority. The intent was to conduct a mid-term review of the plan to assess progress being made by manufacturers to model rationalisation and the success in achieving greater efficiencies in component production. That review formed the basis of the changes now being introduced by the Government.

The plan, which was introduced in 1985 and runs through to the end of 1992, aims to: give the industry time to restructure and modernise, make it more efficient and internationally focused, hold down the price of cars, reduce job losses in the short term and provide long term job stability.

The strategy for pursuing these objectives involves the following integrated elements: rationalisation of the assembly industry in terms of models and manufacturing groups, rationalisation of the components sector to reduce industry fragmentation and costs, increasing competitive pressure on the industry by Gradually reducing barrier protection, and providing a stable policy framework which will allow adjustment to occur over a period of time with minimum disruption and cost.

The Government believes that the plan has enjoyed substantial success in its first three years. To increase industry volumes and economies of scale, the Government set the industry a target of reducing, by 1992, the number of models from 13 to six and the number of manufacturing groups from five to three. Through industry restructuring and rationalisation of companies and model lines, these objectives are well within reach. The Automotive Industry Authority advises that it expects that only eight models will be manufactured by the end of 1989, and following the December 1987 announcement of a joint manufacturing venture between AMI Toyota Ltd and General Motors-Holden's Ltd, the number of manufacturing groups has now been reduced to four. Further cooperative manufacturing ventures are likely.

Increased investment activity associated with new product development and upgrading plant and equipment has also been apparent as the industry prepares itself for the post-1992 period. The vehicle sector, for example, has increased its investment from $194m per annum in the period 1982-1984, prior to the introduction of the plan, to $503m per annum in the period 1985-1987. During the life of the plan we have also witnessed a dramatic increase in automotive exports. In 1987 automotive exports reached $755m, an increase of 63 per cent over the previous year and almost double the level of exports in 1984. While devaluation has clearly been an important element in this success, the export facilitation arrangements of the plan, together with a much stronger commitment to export by industry management, have also been important.

Nevertheless, in spite of the undoubted successes of the plan so far, the Government recognises that there are changed circumstances which threaten the plan's objectives. The major unforseeable change since 1984 has been the fall in the value of the Australian dollar. This has altered the relative competitiveness of locally produced and imported products to the extent that the competitive pressure now on the domestic industry is well below that envisaged in 1984. As evidence of the substantial erosion of importers' competitiveness, the importers' market share is now about 11.4 per cent compared with over 15.5 per cent only two years ago, 1987 and 1988 tender quotas attracted zero premiums and both 1986 and 1987 quota allocations were significantly underutilised. The depreciation has also had the effect of forcing price increases in the industry at a rate well above those occurring in the economy generally.

In summary, the Government believes that the effects of the depreciation on relative competitiveness threaten to erode the benefits of industry rationalisation achieved to date and, by reducing competitive pressure on the industry, significantly blunt the effectiveness of a major element of the plan strategy. They have also seriously hindered progress towards the plan objective of lower real prices. Accordingly, following advice from the Automotive Industry Authority and the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, and after consultation with the industry and its unions, the Government has introduced changes considered necessary to ensure that the plan remains an effective mechanism for transforming the industry into a competitive force in the 1990s.

This Bill gives effect to the following changes being made to the tariff elements of the plan: The abolition of tariff quotas, and the reduction of the 57.5 per cent tariff on completely built-up (CBU) motor vehicles to 45 per cent with effect from 13 April 1988. From 1 January 1989 there will be further annual reductions leading to an end rate of 35 per cent in 1992. Completely knocked down (CKD) packs and certain original equipment components will also now attract the CBU tariff rates.

To retain competitive relativities, the tariff rates applying to CBU light commercial vehicles and those CBU four-wheel drive vehicles, including amphibious vehicles, not classified as passenger substitutes are to be reduced from 35 per cent and 25 per cent respectively to 20 per cent for the remainder of this year. This rate will be phased down in annual reductions to an end rate of 15 per cent in 1992. The tariffs on CKD light commercial vehicles and CKD four-wheel drive vehicles, including amphibious vehicles, now become 10 per cent. Margins of preference applying to goods of developing country, Canadian and Forum Island country origin remain unchanged, and goods of Papua New Guinea origin remain free of duty. Tariffs on goods of New Zealand origin will be subject to the lower of the current rate or the rate applicable to Canadian goods. Discussions are, however, now under way between Australian and New Zealand officials in the context of the Australia-New Zealand closer economic relations trade agreement.

Other elements of the Government's decision which are not covered by this Bill, but which are an integral part of the overall package of changes, involve certain amendments to the local content and export facilitation arrangements of the plan. Administrative action to give effect to these changes is occurring and does not require legislation. Briefly, the changes to the local content scheme involve the introduction of a simpler and less stringent system of penalties for non-achievement of the 85 per cent local content target. Beginning in 1989, the penalty will be the same as the duty rate applying to CBU passenger motor vehicles. This change will provide considerable additional flexibility to the vehicle manufacturers in their sourcing arrangements and, as such, increase competitive pressure on the components sector. The currency devaluation, through the local content scheme, has provided an unhealthy degree of protection to domestic component suppliers.

In relation to export facilitation, each of the three schemes in operation has been extended in slightly different ways to ensure that they continue to play a significant role in promoting rationalisation and helping the industry gain a foothold in major export markets. They are an important adjunct to the other mechanisms of the plan and the Government wants to ensure that the momentum they have created is not lost.

In conclusion, the changes outlined in this Bill form part of a package of measures introduced by the Government to reinforce the original plan framework and maintain progress towards the objectives agreed upon by industry and Government in 1984. While considerable progress towards most of these objectives has occurred, the Government believes that the changes it has made are necessary and appropriate to accommodate the changed circumstances and build on the emerging strengths.
Financial Impact Statement

The revenue implications of the tariff changes cannot be estimated with any satisfactory degree of accuracy because of uncertainties about price and market response and the effects of other economic factors on consumer behaviour in this market. Nevertheless, it is suggested that, in 1988-89, a net revenue gain will occur. The abolition of tariff quotas and the simplification of the local content provisions will reduce administration costs to government and the vehicle industry. Details of the amendments contained in the Bill have been included in an explanatory memorandum which has been circulated for the information of honourable members. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Connolly) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table directions under section 11 of the Aboriginal Development Commission Act 1980.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Beazley, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

I am presenting this Bill as the Minister assisting the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) and I must say that in a small way this embodies yet another of her achievements on behalf of the defence personnel for whom we share responsibility.

The purpose of this Bill is to make three small but important groups of amendments to Acts in the Defence portfolio. One group of amendments relates to the commutation of pensions by retiring members of the Defence Force under the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Act 1973. The Act enables retirees in receipt of retirement pay and some categories of recipients of invalidity pay to elect to commute a proportion of their entitlements to a lump sum. As the Act stands, the election cannot be made until after a person has retired, and it is not effective until it is received by the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Authority. There has been concern that if a retiree died before being able to make an election, no lump sum payment could be made. As a result, it is common for potential retirees, in order to protect the interests of their dependants, to take out short term insurance to provide a lump sum payment in the event of their death during the critical period.

In more common cases, the time necessarily taken for the processing of an election and payment of a commutation amount can cause complications for retiring members in their adjustment from service to civilian life. These substantial payments are an important part of post-retirement financial planning. As an example, delay caused by the inability of retirees to make an election until after retirement may require retirees to take out short term bridging finance to cover house purchases. The Bill amends the Act to enable retiring members to make the election up to three months before retirement to be effective on retirement, thus eliminating the necessity for taking out insurance. Timely payment will also assist members in their resettlement arrangements. It should perhaps be added that, if a member dies or is retired on invalidity grounds before an election becomes effective, no commutation payment is made.

Another group of amendments relates to the constitution of the Defence Housing Authority. Under section 12 of the Defence Housing Authority Act 1987, the Authority comprises nine persons, being the Chairperson, the Managing Director, three members of the Defence Force, a member of the Public Service and three appointed members, the latter being persons with expertise in housing operations, property development or management, business management and the like. It was announced in October last that, in recognition of the need for service spouses, as the people most affected by decisions regarding service housing, to have a direct input into the making of those decisions, the Act would be amended so that a service spouse could be appointed to the Authority. The Bill amends the Act accordingly and also provides for an extra appointed member who will bring additional financial expertise to the Authority. Subject to passage of the Bill, an announcement will be made later regarding the persons to be appointed.

The last group of amendments relates to the bringing into force of amendments made to the Defence Act 1903 and the Naval Defence Act 1910 by the Defence Legislation Amendment Act 1987. These amendments introduced the concept of open-ended or permanent enlistment to retiring age for soldiers and sailors as an alternative to the traditional system of successive fixed term engagements and re-engagements. Under the new system, permanent enlistees will be able to claim discharge short of retiring age by giving appropriate notice. This right is subject to certain constraints, particularly a return of service obligation where a member has successfully completed a course of training. Planning for the introduction of the new scheme in July this year has revealed a need to clarify the references to the courses concerned, and the Bill therefore amends these references. The Bill also includes similar amendments to corresponding provisions related to officers' resignations.

To avoid possible misunderstanding, I should emphasise that these legislative changes do not foreshadow a more restrictive approach to voluntary separations from the Defence Force. So far as soldiers and sailors are concerned, the change is one of fine tuning the new permanent enlistment scheme. This has been widely welcomed in the Defence Force for the greater certainty it gives to members in their career planning and the significant reduction it will bring in administrative effort. With regard to officers, the amendment will enable return of service obligations to be more clearly specified, particularly where initial training is concerned.
Financial Impact Statement

It is estimated that the fees and travelling expenses of the two additional members of the Defence Housing Authority will be $10,000 in the financial year 1988-89 and corresponding amounts in subsequent years. The other amendments have no direct financial implications.
I commend the Bill to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Connolly) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SUPPLY BILL (No. 1) 1988-89[COGNATE BILLS:SUPPLY BILL (No. 2) 1988-89SUPPLY (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 April, on motion by Mr Dawkins:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate Supply Bill (No. 1) 1988-89 concurrently with Supply Bill (No. 2) 1988-89 and Supply (Parliamentary Departments Bill) 1988-89. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating tonight Supply Bills (No. 1) and (No. 2) for 1988-89 and the Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1988-89. These Bills make interim provision for the appropriation of money out of the Consolidated Revenue Fund for the services of the Government for the first five months of financial year 1988-89. The Opposition will not be opposing these Bills, as they form an integral part of the budgetary process. But while we are not opposing the Bills, the coalition reiterates its dissatisfaction with the Government's continued refusal to curb Government outlays significantly. To highlight this I now move an amendment, which will be seconded by the honourable member for Bruce (Mr Aldred), as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House notes:
(1) Australia's $86.77 billion net foreign debt at the end of December 1987 and its continuing balance of payments deficit on the current account which increased by $1185 million during March 1988;
(2) the Government's inappropriate response, which has been to increase taxation revenue collections to the highest levels in post-war Australia; and
(3) the urgent need to reduce public sector outlays as the major element of a Government policy response to Australia's current economic difficulties'.

I expect that shadow Ministers and other Opposition members will discuss detailed aspects of these Bills and their effects on individual portfolios. However, in line with this amendment, I wish to address my remarks to the state of the Australian economy.

This financial year, 1987-88, the Government is likely to run a Budget surplus of $1 billion. I project that the Budget surplus for 1988-89 will be at least $3 billion, certainly if there are no policy changes. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) constantly congratulates himself on this so-called feat of fiscal management. In reality, this feat is nothing more than a facade. As Senator Walsh commented shortly after the Budget was brought down in September last year-indeed, at the end of the very week in which the Budget was brought down-the Government lacked the political courage to cut spending significantly. This year's Budget surplus stems largely from the proceeds of asset sales, and particularly from revenue resulting from bracket creep. The Treasurer at his Press conference last week made it perfectly clear in stating the obvious: if we get a surplus on our Budget, we get it either by cutting expenditure or by increasing the revenue.

There has been precious little fiscal constraint-namely, cutting of expenditure-but there have been extraordinary amounts of revenue increases, particularly by PAYE taxpayers, who time and again have moved up because of bracket creep. Ask any Australian. One does not even have to ask them now. Just look at the result of every election that has been held this year and see the way in which the people have traduced this Government in the ballot box, in the only effective protest they can make. So there is a political need for the Government to change course, but it cannot see that; and there is an absolute economic need to reduce the crippling burden which is overshadowing the lives of most Australians, as they struggle just to keep afloat in any given week, and to deal with the current state of the economy and its impact on the average family.

Let us take an example. This is not mere rhetoric. In September 1985-2 1/2 years ago-the tax paid by a person on average weekly earnings, with a dependent spouse and two children, was 18.8 per cent of his income. By November 1987, with all this talk of the Government's tax cuts and how effective they allegedly were, the tax paid was 20.8 per cent of total income. Over this period the tax paid by a person on average weekly earnings increased by $22 a week. This Government, through its Treasurer, has the hide to say to Australians, `I personally, by a magic feat of statesmanship, have brought about this balanced Budget and indeed this surplus'. It has been brought about by screwing down the take-home pay, the money, the disposable income, of the majority of Australians. That is not something worth congratulating oneself on. It is worthy of the utmost condemnation. There is a wider issue at stake which I shall come to in terms of the whole macro-economic scene so far as Australians and their own economy are concerned. Despite the so-called tax cuts of December 1986-can honourable members remember them?

TALK.START.PARA: —Hardly.

—And of July 1987, the tax burden for many average families has actually increased by $22 a week in the last couple of years. Yet at the EPAC meeting last Friday the Treasurer described his changes to the tax system as `landmark reforms'. Tell that to the marines. Labor's recent electoral disasters I have just touched on. They provide ample evidence that average Australians are feeling the squeeze. I am now into my twenty-third year in this Parliament-I have been here longer than any other Liberal-and I can tell the House that in my period representing what is frankly a middle class but generally affluent electorate, my electorate office has never before been filled with so many people who are finding it damned hard just to stay afloat.
—The same here.

—I am very grateful to the honourable member for that interjection. As I discuss this, even in casual conversation, with my colleagues I discover that their offices also are inundated, and that is corroborated by the way in which people are voting. Of course we get some pleasure out of doing well electorally, but I would rather be getting that pleasure for some other reason than the fact that the Government is squeezing Australians in a manner that has not occurred before, certainly not in my nearly quarter of a century in this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think honourable members opposite are aware of it at all. I do not think they comprehend what they are doing to people. Notwithstanding the fancy rhetoric that some people go on with about the progress that is being made in this nation, it is progress for only a few people. Improvements in life are at present being experienced by a very few people. There is no doubt that the Government is dividing the Australian community even more into the categories of those who are getting wealthier and wealthier, those at the other end of the spectrum, the poor, who, while being crushed, are nevertheless being helped by various welfare handouts, as ought to be the case if they cannot cope, and then the great bulk of people within this great country of ours, in middle Australia, the overwhelming majority, who are finding it difficult just to cope with their daily lives, due to the heavy imposts. The Government has looked after the extremely wealthy, who have been able to thrive at the expense of the bulk of Australians.

Two weeks ago the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said that Australians could now expect improvements in wages, in taxes and in the inflation rate. Last week the Treasurer suddenly became rather vague about tax cuts. He berated me, the Opposition and the Business Council of Australia, for pointing out that we must exercise fiscal restraint, that we have to cut down our spending so that we can give some tax cuts to the majority of Australians. We were berated for saying that, but by the end of the week, when yet another disastrous month's trading figures came out, the Treasurer resumed his more meek and mild mould, which is rarely seen, and adopting that pose he said, `Well, we will have to be fiscally responsible.'

The Treasurer became vague about the tax cuts, saying that scheduled tax cuts would not be announced in the May statement. The verbiage that is used about tax cuts is to the effect that Australians will get their tax cuts in the life of this Parliament. However, what does that mean? It means that the Government will not deliver the tax cuts now, when they are needed, near the end of this financial year, and it will not announce tax cuts in the next financial year in the Budget-or foreshadow them in May. It is more than likely that the Government will apply them at the end of the next financial year or early in the following one-just as the man who would be king, the current Treasurer, replaces the present Prime Minister, becomes Party Leader and Prime Minister, and contemplates an election at the end of 1989. So, there is this extraordinary vision in the Treasurer's mind that the tax cuts can be given some few months before he calls an election at the end of 1989.

That will not rub. People are not mugs. They will not be duped by this sort of political fancywork. They are hurting, under a government that promised them a reasonable deal, although it has simply shovelled out opportunities for people at one end of the spectrum, and not for the bulk of Australians. Members opposite pulling that little act will not remain on that side of the House. I think it is fairly certain that they will not be, in any case, but what would be a disaster for them at present would turn into a rout. I do not want to dwell on the political consequences of it, as that is down the line, but it is the economic consequences that will bring about that political disaster on which we ought to be focusing and which I am seeking to draw attention to in speaking to these Supply Bills presently before the House.

Referring again to some quotes, last weekend the Prime Minister promised significant personal income tax cuts next year in the context of a wage tax trade-off. I think that the Prime Minister, in talking along these lines, is missing the point altogether. It is imperative in the view of the Opposition that the tax cuts be introduced without further delay. It is imperative that the Treasurer announce and seek to implement those tax cuts under the May statement to redress the insidious effects of the tax system as it operates at present and to provide significant real cuts in the tax burden. What do we see apart from what I have referred to? We see the Government busily negotiating deals with the trade union leadership. The Government's total confusion in relation to tax policy was illustrated once again on the weekend when the Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan) in a speech to the National Conference of Young Labor said:
I believe we must face up to the hard issue of increasing tax revenue . . .

Let me remind those who are listening to this broadcast what the Minister, who will hold a seat in Adelaide for the remainder of this Parliament and no longer, advocated in a climate of oppressive tax burdens. He said that the tax revenue ought to be increased even further. We have questioned the Minister in the House about that statement and he simply says that the Prime Minister has talked to him about the issue and that he will say no more. He has not negated; he has not stepped back from what he has called for and yet again we see that element in the Labor Party that wants to soak more and more out of the majority of Australians. This is leading to a state of chaos within the Australian Labor Party, and that is hardly encouraging for most Australians who have seen and felt their living standards eroded over the past few years. Indeed, they must be asking, `Where is the Government's tax policy?' I have listened to the Orwellian chant of `four legs good, two legs bad' from honourable members of the Government side who ask, `Where is the Opposition's tax policy?'.

TALK.START.PARA: —A good question.

—We went to the election with a tax policy, brother, which is more than the Government did. The only time the Government had a tax policy was when the Prime Minister was confronted by a Perth radio announcer in the 1984 election campaign who suggested that there be a tax summit. So desperate for something to hang on to, the Prime Minister picked up the suggestion. Since then the Government has not had a tax policy. Honourable members opposite would not know what the Government is going to implement. Not only is there no policy in place but there is an oppressive effect of the Government's administration at present. Honourable members opposite have waffled, shuffled and moved about with various undertakings as to who will benefit. Will it be business? What will be the level of cuts? Will personal tax cuts be implemented at the same time? We do not know the answers.

SPEECH.PARA: The only thing Australians know about the Government's tax policy is that it is bleeding them, and bleeding them hard. And for what purpose, I ask. I do not see that people are gaining as a consequence of the soaking in which the Government is indulging at present. As I said, people must and should ask and understandably are asking, `Where is the Government's tax policy?' The bottom line is that Australians deserve tax cuts now. They do not deserve the deceit and the camouflage of the verbiage they hear when the Government says that there will be tax cuts some time in the life of this Parliament. They deserve tax cuts now, and they are demanding them as effectively as they can.

As I have emphasised in previous speeches to the House, the fall in living standards that the great majority of Australians are suffering is the direct result of two factors, which are entirely within the Government's control-low productivity and high taxes. Last year productivity in this nation actually decreased. The Government intended to negotiate part of the wage increases on the basis of increased productivity. Wages have increased all right but those increases have not been offset in terms of productivity. Productivity actually fell, and this year it might increase marginally at best. I wonder whether honourable members opposite know what is the estimate for increased productivity for the nation. It is 0.5 per cent.

Low productivity is directly related to the dismal level of investment in plant and equipment that has caused our capital stock to deteriorate. Consequently, much of our labour force is working with depleted and outmoded equipment. It is hardly surprising when we consider that labor's high taxes reduce the incentives both to work and to invest, thereby limiting employment opportunities. Yet on top of the disincentives caused by its tax regime, the Government persists and persists in supporting a wages system which blatantly disadvantages the unemployed and which results in dangerously high rates of growth in unit labour costs-far above those of our major trading partners. The damaging effect on our international competitiveness is clear. Although nominal wages continue to grow, they are eaten away by high inflation. One is on the escalator: up goes inflation, up goes the wages; as the wages go up, the benefits are eaten away again by further high inflation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bracket creep.

—I am glad that my colleague refers to bracket creep. As I remarked some weeks ago-the honourable member may not have been here-I always used to refer to `tax creep', until one day someone said, `Stop referring to the Treasurer in that personal manner. Stop calling him a tax creep'. So we will get back to bracket creep all the time, but it is creeping away and eroding real wages.
—You eroded them.
—How long has the honourable member been in this Parliament?
—Long enough.

—However long that is, I think that this is the first time I have heard the honourable member utter a sound. I welcome that interjection. The only reason I respond to it is that, apart from the fact that the honourable member is hardly a statesman-like character whose name is on the lips of all Australians, I wish that his contribution would be additional to mere interjections in my speech. Maybe the honourable member can give some support to a depleted government at this stage.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's support for flat across the board wage increases has resulted in a narrowing of wage differentials, and therefore has further inhibited the responsiveness of the wages system. Obviously that means that it is more difficult for young people and apprentices to find work. On the subject of wage differentials, in every international study that has been done one finds that the closer the relationship between the adult wage and the junior wage, the greater the degree of youth unemployment. It is a harsh reality. Unless one can start to break this crazy concept of narrowing differentials, the young, in terms of unemployment or apprenticeship, will find it too difficult to find work. The youth unemployment rate, as proof of that, is up around 20 per cent. This Government, this political party, sought to pitch its appeal to young people and put them in the work force. Yet in this nation of ours 20 per cent of the young are unemployed-that is, one in five young Australians in the labour force simply cannot get a job.

If one adds these factors to our huge and growing foreign debt, which has quadrupled since Labor has been in government, it is clear, to put it mildly, that the economy is in appalling shape. This is the economy which, nearly two weeks ago, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer were happy to describe-glory be!-as an `economic miracle'. We had our friends from the Confederation of Australian Industry on the loaves and fishes job talking about Lazarus. Lazarus has been looking a bit sick again-he has been recycled into the other state-since those trade figures came out, but it was referred to as an economic miracle. When accurate analyses are given, such as that which I am giving tonight, one is constantly amazed at the hyperbole which is injected into the Prime Minister's and the Treasurer's rhetoric. But there was that remarkable turnaround late last week when the trade figures came out and the Treasurer had to concede that the economy is, to quote him, `running just a little too fast'. What does that mean? It means that the pace of adjustment of our domestic policies in the face of these external imbalances is just too slow. It is worth remembering that in this year's Budget Papers the Treasury acknowledged that. The Treasury said:

. . . the longer the adjustment period, the greater is the build-up in foreign debt and the greater the call on future income to service that debt. Prolonging the adjustment period also means greater vulnerability to further shocks that are adverse to Australia's external performance.

The Treasurer, in talking about the economy either being overheated or running just a little too fast, is joining the ranks of the Opposition-which has constantly called for a faster pace of adjustment-Moody's Investor Services, Senator Walsh and the Treasury in his concern about the inadequate pace of adjustment. As yet, the Treasurer is all talk and no action. By refusing to force the pace of adjustment and adopting what Moody's has described as a `gradualist' approach the Government has imposed huge economic and social costs on Australia, and the tragedy is that these costs could have been significantly reduced.

Reductions in government spending are not being called for as some debating point. They are not only being called for to provide tax relief for millions of Australians; reductions in Government spending will also move resources from the public sector to the tradable goods sector-our exports and import substitutes-thereby providing scope for us to trade our way out of our huge foreign debt. That axiomatic point seems to be overlooked constantly by so many members of the Government. Not only does a small public sector result in the more efficient production of goods and services throughout the economy, but smaller government clearly means less tax. Tax cuts increase the incentives facing individuals and businesses so that work effort and investment, and hence productivity, are increased.

Labour market deregulation offers scope for substantial improvements in the flexibility and responsiveness of labour markets through enterprise level wages negotiations so that wages are determined by economic factors. It is about time we started to remind ourselves that wages ought to relate in some way to economic factors-not to deals worked out in the back rooms of Parliament House or trade union headquarters between the Treasurer, the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) and the trade union movement. In this way, employment opportunities can be significantly enhanced, particularly for youth and the unskilled.

Honourable members opposite know the deals done on the wages system. They know how figures are peddled around here and worked out as a deal. They know as well as I do that the leadership of the trade union movement could not give a wit about any unemployed in the community. They are not voting for the trade union movement. The trade unions are interested only in their constituency-the shrinking number of employed in the trade unions. The unions stitch up a deal with the Labor Ministers that will be a politically acceptable package to roll before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to get endorsed, instead of those wage increases being related to increases in productivity so that we can see some real advance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you believe that?

—Not only do I believe it, I see it being acted out. What I am saying is quite apart from the reforms that the Government has hinted at in terms of the micro-economic area, which I could have dealt with in some detail. After the last election we were told that the third term of the Hawke Government would be the term of micro-economic reform. The micro-economic reform we have seen to date has been the rhetoric emanating from various factions that cannot even get together on a concept of privatisation. The Government's privatisation program is chaotic. Deregulation in other areas cannot be agreed upon, and we are still waiting for details elsewhere.

SPEECH.PARA: Genuine-and I emphasise that-micro-economic reform, including what I was touching on a moment ago, namely, labour market deregulation, the abolition of rationalisation of business regulations, the privatisation of certain government enterprises and improvements in providing infrastructure can significantly increase the productivity of the nation's resources. These policies together would offer the potential to increase investment, increase productivity, and increase employment opportunities in the economy. They would improve the efficient operation of the economy and-and this is the bottom line with which I commenced my remarks- they would increase living standards for Australians. The bottom line is that forcing the pace of adjustment reduces to a minimum the huge economic and social costs imposed on the Australian community by our foreign debt. Adopting a gradualist approach, as Moody's describes the Government's approach, only serves to prolong these costs unnecessarily.

For these reasons, I urge honourable members to support my amendment, which will be seconded by the honourable member for Bruce. I reiterate that the Opposition will not be opposing the Bills, because they are an essential part of the Government's budgetary process; but I point out to the Government that unless it takes a line through the measures pointed to in the amendment and starts to get the macro and micro scene right it will not only continue to impose appalling difficulties on average Australians but also reap the consequences at the next election.

Oft times it is said in this chamber that the economic difficulties that the Government is creating will cause offsetting political problems. But from me this is not mere puff because it has been evident in every election that has been held to date, and it has occurred because the Government is hurting so many people, some of whom viewed the election of this Government as something that would give some of them great hope. Some of them voted for the Government but they are now leaving it in droves and voting for us because they and their families are finding that they just cannot cope. If the Government introduced the measures to which I am alluding tonight, not only would it be doing the right thing by the Australian economy but it would certainly be doing the right thing by the overwhelming majority of Australians who at the moment just cannot cope.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment, and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again it is an honour and a privilege to follow the Pied Piper of Kooyong in the debate tonight. Obviously he has taken the opportunity to read Bob Brown's book Student Economics for years 11 and 12 because in this debate and in a number of others where I have followed him he has used terms like micro-economics and macro-economics. He is still interchanging them so I am not certain whether he fully understands them, but if he can get past the preface to the book I am sure that he will be on the right track. I will address a few remarks to the amendment moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock). I think it is important that we on this side reiterate some of our concerns about the obvious nonsense that is uttered periodically in this place when the temporary Deputy Leader of the Opposition debates taxation legislation, Supply Bills and other legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Deputy Leader talked about Australia's net foreign debt, how it is growing, and so on; but he continually neglects to mention that most of it is created because of private capital. It is not public capital flowing from this Government or State governments; it is private capital. When we look at the net terms of trade figures recently announced for March, for example, we see that the increase in the volume of imports has come about simply because we are seeing the famous J-curve approach whereby capital is imported into this country so that capital replacement takes place to improve the economic efficiency of Australia's industries, which is something that is long overdue.

We have heard the Treasurer (Mr Keating) talk in this place about the fact that when the Opposition left government after many decades it had completely let run down the economically productive elements of the Australian economy, particularly in secondary industry. Import replacement is taking place because the macro scene is such that producers in Australia can now replace some of their older equipment and can compete far more effectively and efficiently in the broader economy. Of course, this will be to the benefit of Australians, and particularly Australian workers. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition always forgets to mention that.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has no vision.

—Vision is something that is not in the lexicon of the Liberal Party. He talked about the increase in taxation revenue. We heard once again the tired old furphy that this is the highest taxing government in the history of Australia, and all the rest of it. We must remember, of course, that this has been said by a man who has referred to the recommendations of the Business Council of Australia (BCA). For the benefit of honourable members I will remind them of what it said. It said that there should be further cuts in Government expenditure. It listed a range of options. It mentioned cuts in pensions and in veterans' affairs. It mentioned not only cuts in veterans' affairs but the total elimination of the Department of Veterans' Affairs. I ask the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys), who is at the table, how Bill Keys feels about that.
—And on the eve of Anzac Day.

—And on the eve of Anzac Day, as the Minister rightly says. I cannot believe that. Cuts in education and in road funding were mentioned. Honourable members opposite must have received as many letters as I have from shire councils, local councils and other groups saying, `Don't cut the road funding any more, fellows, we cannot live without it'. The BCA report says that there should be cuts in road funding. So I take it that members of the Liberal Party-I do not know about the Nationals; they would probably disagree-would say, `Go for it in a big way and cut road funding'. What about nursing homes?
—They don't care about old people.

—They do not care about old people, they do not care about young people and they certainly do not care about the people whom they purport to represent. The honourable member for Kooyong is on the record as saying, `They didn't go far enough'. So we should hack, hack, hack a little bit deeper! Peter Walsh, come on down, this is your chance; go for it in a big way, hack into all of these programs so that there is no Commonwealth financial assistance for any of them! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable gentleman who just spoke in such impassioned terms, pleading for living standards of Australians to be raised, has talked about cutting all of these things for average Australians and getting rid of them. He says, `Kick the old people when they are down. Kick the young people. Don't provide any further opportunities for education. Get rid of Austudy and all the rest of it. Come on, let's get into it. You haven't cut enough'.

SPEECH.PARA: He went on to talk about the fact that he represents-and I love this-the middle class, but mainly affluent, electorate of Kooyong. He talked about the fact that people were coming in to see him because they were finding it hard to stay afloat. I say to the honourable member that the solution is for them to sell the yachts, the Volvos, the Mercedes and a few other things, and they will stay afloat. He can then come over here and talk to people who represent the real Australians, the real working class of this country, and see what has happened. This Government, to its credit, has paid due respect to the people of Australia, the average workers, who have been prepared to make sacrifices because they recognise the economic difficulties which this Government inherited from the Opposition. They were prepared to forgo some wage increases in real terms. In regard to the macro-economic effects they are now saying, `We have got it under control; let's see some benefit'. This Government has rightly said that they will see some benefit. They have made that sacrifice and now they will see some benefit from it.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition-this great spokesman on economic matters-is saying, `We have to have significant real cuts in tax now to pick up these problems'. I am pleased that my colleague the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) has come into the chamber because we discussed this issue at lunch time today. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition has forgotten that when the Opposition was thrown out of government and rejected by the people in 1983, it left this country with a 60 per cent marginal tax rate in the highest bracket and a whole series of others. They have all been reduced progressively downwards. At the bottom end of the scale a range of assistance packages, such as the family assistance scheme, have been put into place. Yet he has the hide to tell us that we now have to start making real tax cuts without further delay. He used terms such as `significant real cuts in the tax burden of every Australian'. The honourable member has the hide to come in here and, with all his cheek, talk about this Government not having a tax policy. He levelled a bit of abuse at me. When he said that the Opposition had a policy I asked him, `Which one are you talking about? Are you talking about the consumption tax policy of John Elliott or are you talking about the tax policy that the Liberals went into the 1987 election with?'. I remind honourable members what that policy was all about-$8 billion of unfunded cuts which would have absolutely wiped out the gains this Government had made. What would have happened to the deficit? Did the honourable member for Kooyong mention that? No. He has not yet reached page 2 of Bob Brown's book Student Economics so he has not quite defined the terms.

The honourable member then went on to talk about the fact that the Liberals have a taxation policy. When he first came in here he reminded us that there was a very pressing meeting of the Liberal Party to discuss the present version of the tax policy. I ask the House! If the Liberal tax policy is anything like its media policy, we will see so many versions of it that it will be like a Dutch auction. We can take our pick. Will we have a consumption tax? Whatever happened to the phrase `lock stock and barrel'? That was a great phrase. The old capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax were to go out the window. That was before the honourable member's mate at the table, the present temporary Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), looked at the figures and saw that people were starting to pay their fair share of tax for the first time in their lives. He realised that a good bit of money was coming in; it had helped the Government to stabilise the deficit and enabled it to pay for a range of socially and economically desirable programs in the community to help average Australians. So he has gone very quiet about the whole thing. I just ask: what happened to `lock stock and barrel'? Is it still with us or not?

The third matter that the honourable member for Kooyong raised was the question of the urgent need to reduce public sector outlays, and that goes back to the question of the Business Council of Australia response which I have already mentioned. I also found the comments of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition intriguing when he said, `Up go the wages, up goes inflation, and so everyone is immediately forced into bracket creep'. The interesting point is that through consultation processes with the trade union movement, this Government has been able to achieve increases in wages which have been economically responsible. On top of that, this Government has supported wage rises which have discounted below the inflation figure for a period. As the honourable member for Kooyong and I have said, people have recognised that they have been making those sacrifices and, as I have said, the Government has recognised that and has indicated that something will be done about it in the life of this Parliament. The honourable member for Kooyong said, `Up goes inflation'. Let us look at the figures again. When his mate the Leader of the Opposition walked out of here he left us with double digit inflation. It will be 6 per cent or less this year, yet the honourable member talks about inflation going up. It is probably on page 4 of Bob Brown's Student Economics-I hope he refers to that as well. Incidentally, Brownie, is writing a new book and it will probably be a best seller.

The honourable member for Kooyong then went on to talk about wage increases and how average workers should have a fair suck of the sauce bottle. I put it to honourable members: which party has consistently opposed every national wage increase, with one exception, for the workers of Australia? It is not the Party sitting on this side of the House. It is those opposite. The Liberal and National parties have consistently opposed increases in wages for every hard-working Australian. Yet the honourable member talks about the fact that wages have not been going up enough or that, when they do, inflation goes up. What absolute nonsense. It quite clearly demonstrates that he has no idea of the substance of his subject.

A number of people on this side of the House will be addressing more specific issues associated with these Supply Bills. Quite honestly, I suggest that even to consider supporting this tired old amendment that keeps getting trotted out every time there is a debate on taxation issues, appropriation, Supply or anything dealing with economic matters we should certainly think about consigning it to the dustbin where it belongs. It is rubbish. It is written with no thought for what has been done to date. It has been written in the total absence of any Opposition tax policy, or any policy at all.

This Government will continue to look at the whole issue of taxation in a business review later this year. The question of personal tax cuts for the average working Australian will also be reviewed. I suggest to the honourable member for Kooyong that he should go back to his office with his speech-writers, who put that stuff together, and perhaps he would do better if he found someone who knows what economics is all about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with great pleasure that I rise to speak in this debate and to second the amendment moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, my colleague the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). Quite obviously from what the Deputy Leader had to say in this debate, we on this side take far more seriously the fact that today we have a gross foreign debt of $115 billion. It is a pity that the people on the Government side of the House do not attach the same degree of importance to that.

SPEECH.PARA: In addressing Supply Bill (No. 1), Supply Bill (No. 2) and Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill which are now before the House, I have to express a particular deep concern about the way in which the Hawke Labor Government is handling a major aspect of the administration of the Australian Capital Territory. There is, without doubt, a concerted and orchestrated campaign, particularly by the New South Wales right wing faction of the Government-I am glad to see that there are so many of them here tonight-to get a casino established in Canberra at any cost. The House will recall that last week, in respect of the Casino Control Ordinance, I asked the current Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Punch) if option 3 had been adopted. Option 3, as outlined in a departmental ministerial submission dated 26 November 1987, proposed introducing the Ordinance simultaneously with the casino opening so as to avoid parliamentary scrutiny. For the information of the House, option 1 involved bringing in the Ordinance before last Christmas and option 2 suggested tabling it at the commencement of this current autumn session. In relation to option 3, the Minister said to me in his written reply of 26 April:
The option to which you referred was not adopted by the Government.

Earlier, on 23 April, a Government spokesman is reported in the Canberra Times as saying that the Ordinance authorising the casino would be tabled before the project began. I think it is important to note that the Minister has not said when the Ordinance will be tabled. In fact, he seems very keen to avoid doing just that. Perhaps I can suggest a reason as to why he is so determined to avoid this matter. In an undated document entitled Structure of the Legislation, Mr K. T. Lyon, a Deputy Secretary in his Department, canvasses the ways in which the Minister can assure the community that satisfactory controls are in place. He stated:

If a decision is contemplated whereby a casino will precede the Casino Control Ordinance GALA may provide a vehicle for a lawful A.C.T. operation. Sub-paragraph 5 (1) (b) of the GALA ordinance provides power for the authority to conduct lotteries . . .
I will quote again from the same section:
This definition would appear to be wide enough to cover all casino table games.

GALA is, of course, the Gaming and Liquor Authority of the Australian Capital Territory. The fact that Mr Lyon felt obliged to present to the Minister advice of such a devious nature highlights the lengths to which the Government is prepared to go in its ruthless campaign to get a casino into Canberra. Given that the current Minister has categorically ruled out option 3, as referred to earlier, the fact that option 1 cannot now be adopted and the fact that the time factor specified in option 2 has lapsed, the GALA option seems to be the only method left open to the Government.

The bottom line is: do we believe an anonymous Government spokesman, or do we accept that the Minister's aversion to formally stating the Government's method of bringing in the Ordinance is because there is in fact a hidden agenda? The Labor Government puts itself forward as the champion of the environment movement in Australia, yet it has shown not a moment's hesitation in attempting to subvert the provisions of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act as it relates to this casino development. In a file note dated 19 November 1987 concerning a meeting with the former Minister, the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown), Mr Lyon records:
The Minister noted . . . that an EIS-
that is, an environmental impact study-

could not be avoided in relation to this development and that it could take a minimum of 13 months to complete. It was agreed that the Department would provide further advice on this matter particularly concerning the relationship of the provisions of the NCDC Act to those in the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act.
Later, on 26 November 1987, in a minute to the former minister, Mr Lyon says, in part:

. . . the requirements of an EIS need to be met either formally, in terms of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act, or informally, via the NCDC policy plan process and an independent social impact study . . .

It can thus be clearly seen that this self-proclaimed environmentally conscious Government obviously found the provision in the NCDC Act it was looking for. The provision it found has enabled it to subvert the requirements of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act, hence the establishment of an informal social impact study rather than a formal EIS. The decision to proceed with the informal process was made despite the recommendation of the Department's Environment Assessment Branch, the experts on such matters, which recommended the more formal approach `since this would better demonstrate an independent assessment'. The reason for the informal process is spelled out clearly in a minute to the former minister from Mr Lyon dated 2 December 1987. Mr Lyon said:
It would provide greater flexibility in relation to the structure and management of the inquiry, while maintaining the substance of the legal requirements.

In other words, the purported environmentalists of the New South Wales right wing are concerned only with being seen to be maintaining the substance of the law on environmental issues, something they have done throughout their black propaganda campaign on environmental matters whilst in office. As late as 28 January this year, the Department's Environment Assessment Branch, obviously concerned with more than just the substance of the law, was still voicing concern over the informal study. In an attachment to a ministerial submission, it said:

. . . at the end of the study, a ministerial decision will be required as to whether the object of the impact of proposals act has been satisfied with respect to the development and casino proposal or, presumably a separate EIS is required.

Quite evidently the thought of at least 13 months for a formal EIS, over which the Government had no hope of controlling the management of the inquiry and which would comply with more than just the substance of the law, was enough to discourage it from undertaking this correct course of action. Furthermore, a formal EIS ran the risk of the probability that it would recommend against a casino and the 13 months does not fit in with the very short timetable the Government has for getting the casino up and running.

In its arrogant attitude towards the environment protection Act, it seems that nothing has been left to chance in the Government's efforts to get the casino established. The informal social impact study itself has a partisan head, Dr Geoff Caldwell, ostensibly an academic expert on gambling, but, in reality, an overt lobbyist for the gambling industry. On Tuesday last the current Minister told the House that Dr Caldwell had acted as an `independent expert' for the poker machine lobby in Victoria. This is not a true representation of the facts. During that unsuccessful lobby campaign, Dr Caldwell was a member of the poker machine lobby's delegation on 12 May 1981 to the then Victorian Premier, the Hon. Rupert Hamer, which was later severely criticised by the 1983 Wilcox report for presenting the Premier with misleading information. The fraudulent information was actually presented by Mr Vibert. However, if Dr Caldwell was the independent expert the Minister says he was, surely Dr Caldwell would have corrected the information either at the time or within a short period afterwards. Mr Justice Wilcox, in his 1983 report, describes Dr Caldwell as:
The principal witness of the Licenced Clubs Association of Victoria (LCAV) in this inquiry in relation to the operation of poker machine clubs.

The LCAV, through a front known as the Australian Club Development Association, established by Ainsworth lobbyist, Mr Ted Vibert, was acknowledged as the major proponent for poker machines in Victoria. Indeed, Justice Wilcox says that funding for the poker machine campaign was provided in large part by the Ainsworth organisation which contributed at least $260,000 in the period January-September 1981 alone.

TALK.START.PARA: —Disgraceful!
—Yes, it is disgraceful. Describing the poker machine lobby's campaign, Mr Wilcox says:

SPEECH.PARA: Overall probably a score of seminars was held. Mr Vibert was the main speaker, usually backed by Dr Caldwell . . .

On Tuesday last the Minister told the House that there was no evidence to suggest that Dr Caldwell should not have been appointed to head a study into the impact of a casino. In the light of the evidence demonstrating Dr Caldwell's close partisan links with the gambling industry, the Minister's statement is a mockery. In fact, the whole casino project is a mockery. It is not something Canberrans have sought; it is something the grubby New South Wales right wing of the Hawke Labor Government has sought to impose upon them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just witnessed in the contribution of the honourable member for Bruce (Mr Aldred) some imaginative and rather creative uses of freedom of information, but I am sure that the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Punch) will well and truly deal with the way the honourable member is conducting a campaign around the issues of the Australian Capital Territory and the proposed casino. I join the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) in making some comments about the contribution of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) who had the temerity in here today to talk about this Government being in some crisis over taxation. What a cheek. The coalition's tax policy is in great chaos. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition admitted in his speech tonight that the parties that make up the coalition are still trying to work out the toing and froing that is going on between them.

SPEECH.PARA: The Deputy Leader of the Opposition also talked of the effect that he had noticed on his electorate of Kooyong. Let me tell him something. I think about the effect on my electorate of Scullin, which is a working-class electorate, of some of the expenditure cuts that the coalition is toying with, along with its co-called taxation policy. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition last week indicated that he supported the general thrust of the submission of the Business Council of Australia-a submission that dealt with something like $11 billion-worth of cuts. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition now says that he will be looking at $13 billion-worth over three years. Does he really think that cuts of that magnitude can be delivered without causing any pain to the electorate?

He then went on to dismiss the contribution of the union movement to current economic planning. He talked about deals in back rooms of this place and went on to say that these deals had nothing to do with decreasing unemployment. I refer the House once again to a letter in the Australian Financial Review of Tuesday two weeks ago in which Philip Lewis, a senior lecturer in economics at the Curtin University of Technology, referred to a study undertaken by himself and Michael Kirby. He indicated that the accord had helped to increase employment by 8 per cent or 600,000 jobs. As I said in the appropriation debate last week, it can be seen that the economic turnaround has been paid for largely by workers through the trade union movement under the accord.

That brings me in this Supply debate to talk about proper economic planning. Since the election in 1983 the Government has developed industry plans in a number of major areas of the manufacturing sector-the steel industry, the passenger motor vehicle industry and the textiles, clothing and footwear (TCF) industries. In many ways, these industries have been the most difficult to restructure. For instance, the textiles, clothing and footwear industries and the car industry have enjoyed amongst the highest levels of protection of any industries in Australia. TCF industries employ between 110,000 and 120,000 people. This constitutes 10 per cent of employment in the manufacturing sector and 2 per cent of total employment. TCF industries contribute approximately 1.4 per cent of gross domestic product. There are approximately 2,500 TCF operators in Australia. While the 11 largest of those provide nearly 30 per cent of employment in the industry, the remaining 70 per cent are generally employed in smaller manufacturing concerns.

Since the mid-1970s, the TCF industries have operated behind enormous trade barriers imposed in the face of competition from newly industrialised countries, particularly in Asia. As my colleague the honourable member for Sydney (Mr Baldwin) has observed, the competitive edge achieved by overseas operations is often at the expense of the living standards of those countries' populations. The Government's approach to the TCF industries incorporates a phased and predictable exposure to overseas competition in conjunction with a range of structural adjustments and a cushioning of the short term effects. Specifically, the industry's development strategy combines four programs of support-a raw materials processing program; an industry efficiency program, including programs for increased access to the national industry extension service; plant and equipment modernisation; and international competitiveness incentives. It also provides an infrastructures program and an export development program. These measures are in conjunction with the labour adjustment measures which took effect in January this year which aim to minimise adjustment difficulties by assisting workers to find employment outside TCF industries.

The adjustment package includes access to training allowances, vocational training wage subsidies and relocation allowances. The TCF strategy is a success for cooperative economic planning. It highlights what can be achieved when a tripartisan approach involving government, unions and the industry to economic reform is adopted. The Government, industry and TCF unions should be congratulated on their foresight. Let us contrast this approach with the Industries Assistance Commission recommendations last year of a 50 per cent tariff cut after seven years, no labour adjustment measures, no investment incentives, no monitoring authority, and no review of the effects of those recommendations. The Government rightly rejected those recommendations.

Central planning is the only means by which the varied interests can be accommodated. Similar outcomes are not achieved by the invisible hand of market forces. The prices and incomes accord is another example of an effective planning and consultation structure. The accord has contributed to an industrial relations record for this Government which is far better than that of the previous Government. Under Labor there has been a 60 per cent reduction in man hours lost when compared with the dark Fraser- Howard years. The Opposition not only would be unable to negotiate an accord with the trade union movement but also it seeks to abandon any form of centralised wage fixing system. Effective economic management would be exchanged for failed ideology. The Liberal Minister for Industrial Relations under Fraser-the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee)-recognises this to be the case, as he stated to the Melbourne Herald yesterday:
I frankly am in no doubt that the wages outcome which has been delivered so far by the Government could not have been achieved by a coalition Government . . .
He went on to say:

. . . a coalition Government would not have been in a position to benefit from the union movement's improved economic understanding and its willingness to work with Labor in achieving a lower wage outcome.

What did he get for his troubles? Today in the Melbourne Age he got a rebuke from the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Chaney. I quote some of the words of Senator Chaney as reported in that article:
Union leaders now pressing for guaranteed across-the-board wage rises of the order of six per cent plus undefined extras must be regarded as people who have learnt nothing at all.

That was the attitude of the Opposition Leader in the Senate-an attitude of confrontation that so epitomises the coalition's indicated policies towards industrial relations matters. Perhaps we should look at a joint statement on participative practices by the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) put around last week. That document said:
If Australian enterprises and their employees are to meet the challenges which confront them then the emphasis must be on consultation and co-operation and not confrontation.

So there we have it from a peak employer body and the peak union body. That is what this Government's attitude has been about-consensus and cooperation. I think that the admission by the honourable member for Goldstein is in marked contrast to the scarcely hidden New Right agenda which dominates the coalition.

The approach to economic planning that is evident in the Government's industry plans and in the accord can be extended further. The ACTU-Trade Development Council mission to Western Europe highlighted the general commitment to tripartism, particularly in Austria, Sweden and Norway. Tripartism promotes communication and genuine understanding between parties which facilitates common purpose and cohesion and minimises the adverse consequences of conflict.

Compare the industrial relations outcomes in those countries with the dark Fraser-Howard years in Australia. In 1979 Australia lost 780 days per 1,000 employees while Sweden lost 10 and Austria and Norway less than five. In fact, as the mission's report stated, Austria calculates in seconds rather than days the annual average time per worker lost in industrial disputes. Dramatic reductions in the level of industrial disputation are not the only advantages of tripartisanism. As Australia Reconstructed makes clear, the unions have positive attitudes to industry development and industry rationalisation and ensure that the Government pursues active labour market policies to provide a safety net with the emphasis on retraining and education to absorb technological and structural unemployment. It should be noted that the process of tripartisanism itself has reinforced this high degree of reorganisation and sophistication and it has also functioned as an educational and developmental process for all countries involved.

Fundamental macro-economic performance has also been better. At the peak of the Fraser-Howard recession in 1982-83 inflation in Sweden and Norway was lower, and in Austria markedly lower, than in Australia. While Australia's unemployment rate soared to nearly 10 per cent, Sweden, Norway and Austria had between 2 and 4 per cent. It must not be forgotten that economic planning is not an end in itself. The fluctuation of macro-economic variables has a real impact on the day to day lives of average Australians. Some 8 per cent of the work force of the electorate of Scullin is employed in the TCF industries. That is the highest percentage of any electorate in Australia. A number of the people there have to go to factories outside the electorate. In absolute numbers, the top three electorates in those industries are Scullin and the neighbouring electorates of Batman and Wills. When I speak in favour of economic planning along the lines of the TCF plan and the passenger motor vehicle plan it is not only a theoretical preference; I know that without economic planning thousands of hardworking Australians in my electorate would have been the first victims of the invisible hand of market forces.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australians are very uncertain at the moment about their future and that is one of the reasons why the Australian Labor Party is suffering such adverse results at the polls. The remoteness and the unconcerted attitudes of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) further exacerbate the concern of people in the Australian community. When one tries to examine the cause of their concern one only has to start with simple matters such as interest rates and to make a comparison between interest rates in Australia and those in the rest of the world. Interest rates are the driving factor for most community activity, whether it be operating a bank account or Bankcard, purchasing a home or raising a loan to operate a small business. The Government bond rate in Australia at the moment is running at around 12.5 per cent and in New Zealand it is 14.3 per cent. We head the world with high interest rates. If we look at comparable countries which are trading into similar markets to ours we see that the bond rates in Japan are 4.2 per cent, in the United States of America 8.4 per cent and in the United Kingdom 9 per cent. So Australia is really 50 per cent above the rest of the world in the cost of money, the cost of doing anything. If one must borrow money in Australia, the cost is 50 per cent above that in any other comparable country.

SPEECH.PARA: The rise in the cost of goods in Australia, the rise in the consumer price indexes, is running at about 7 per cent. In the United States it is 4 per cent, in Japan 0.7 per cent and in the United Kingdom about 3.3 per cent. So on another key factor we see that Australia has a rate double that of comparable countries for the annual increase of the cost of goods and services. Our interest rates are 50 per cent above those in comparable countries, the increase in the price of goods as measured by the consumer price indexes is double that in comparable countries, our foreign debt is $115 billion and we had an adverse balance of trade-we are buying more than we are selling-last year of $1,770m. So far this year our adverse balance of trade is $333 million.

We are not earning enough in foreign trade to pay our way. We are borrowing heaps of money. We have a consumer price index which is double that of comparable countries. We have interest rates which are 50 per cent above those of comparable countries. It is no wonder that Australian growth looks like being the same as in comparable countries. However, that growth rate is falsely high because of the huge amount of money we are borrowing and the heat generated by slack Government policies in administering our economy. The Australian growth rate is running at about 4 1/2 per cent. That is falsely high because it is costing more to do things in Australia. We are stoking money into our system which we have borrowed from overseas. The balance of trade is bad news. Put in family terms, what we are doing is living on the never-never. By going into hock to the bank we have decided that our family cannot produce enough from the wages earned by the family and that we need to borrow as well. We have got our groceries on tick down at the store. In fact, we have borrowed for the house, the car, the washing machine and all the rest. We are in an impossible position unless radical changes are made in the May economic statement by the current Government.

I do not believe that the Treasurer has the stomach to understand how Australians are really hurting. He does not go to Bankstown very frequently but when he does he goes in his own Mercedes. Members of the Australian Labor Party are not very impressed by his attending branch meetings in a car of that calibre. That just demonstrates his remoteness. He is a silvertail and behaves like one.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is this? Who are you talking about?
—I am talking about the Treasurer. I am not talking about the honourable member for Parramatta, who is sitting at the table, but the Treasurer. That is the way in which the Treasurer behaves.

SPEECH.PARA: If we look at what it costs to buy homes around Australia that will give us some indication of what people are facing. We had the share market crash after which people decided to invest in real estate. We are right in the middle of a real estate boom, which I do not think is going to last too much longer. Currently, developers of whom I know can make so much profit on their raw land that they are selling it undeveloped because it is too expensive to build homes on which they can sell at realistic prices. The market is overheated. One only has to look at various capital cities around Australia to see why.

In Adelaide housing rents have outstripped those in all other capital cities, bar Melbourne. Rents have risen at twice the inflation rate. The average weekly asking rent for a three-bedroom unfurnished house in Adelaide in December was $134. If we look at Melbourne we see that rents there have shot up at twice the rate of other capital cities. Recent surveys indicate that the asking rent of a two-bedroom apartment has risen by 21 per cent. The rent for a three-bedroom house has risen by 14 per cent. The 16 per cent increase in the price of new dwellings in Melbourne in the last year has meant that many prospective home buyers cannot afford to buy into the Melbourne market.
