In Sydney, a single income family with two children on average weekly earnings of say $450, after the deduction of tax and the average rent of $267, has to try to live on $94 a week. This is a family on an average income paying an average rent. Any member who represents a Sydney electorate knows that to be the case. It is impossible to pay one's way in Sydney under the policies that have been introduced by this Government. The average rent for an unfurnished three-bedroom house in Sydney is $267 a week.

People are forced to pay these exorbitant prices because of the policies of the Government which have created such circumstances as a result of borrowing long on foreign markets and not producing enough to trade out of our terrible trade deficit, by a consumer price index which is double that of the rest of the world and interest rates which are 50 per cent above those anywhere else. That is the result of the Labor Party's policies on the average family. For a person buying his first home in Sydney the lower interest rates over the last few months have helped, but they are being wiped out by the record new home prices that are 27 per cent higher in Sydney today than they were a year ago. Sydney's rents are the highest in Australia. As I said, the rent for a three-bedroom house in Sydney is $267 a week-about $100 a week more than in any other capital city. Other capital cities also have massive rental accommodation costs.

The Labor Party has lost its way for the people it is supposed to represent. That is a great shame. In this chamber there is no discussion or debate about what direction Australia should take. The Government has a remote attitude that likes to fiddle with the figures, that looks at the macro-economics-the cigar-smoking syndrome, if I could put it that way. The Opposition knows that syndrome. We have suffered from it. We know how it can destroy a government. This Government is in the process of self-destruction because of its attitudes. The remoteness of the Government from its constituents and their real needs will mean that it will face great difficulty at the next election.

Let me recapitulate. The Government's management of the economy has meant that we have borrowed far too much. The cost of goods in Australia has increased by 100 per cent more than the cost of goods in similar countries. The cost of money, which the economy needs to expand, is 50 per cent more than in other countries. No wonder we are uncompetitive. No wonder we are going backwards. No wonder there is deep concern. No wonder the Government will be thrown out at the next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seem to be destined to follow the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) on a number of issues. I am now following his pretty meagre contribution to economic discussion. Let me say something about the speeches we have heard from the Opposition. All we have heard has been negative and carping rubbish. We have not heard a single positive suggestion about what needs to be done in this country in terms of development. No positive ideas come from the Opposition; there is just carping, negative rubbish. The Opposition will never get into government until it learns something about formulating policies and putting forward positive, constructive ideas about how to resolve whatever problems exist.

SPEECH.PARA: Any government in any period of history has problems. In this part of the twentieth century in particular all nations have problems, no matter what their political complexion. What we ought to be about is making constructive and positive suggestions about what needs to be done. Instead, we hear negative, carping rubbish from the Opposition. We ought to be putting forward positive ideas about the future of this country. The Parliament should be doing that in a constructive way, prevailing upon the Government to adopt such ideas. That is what we would be doing if we were playing a proper role as a parliament. We would not be hearing the sort of negative, carping rubbish we have heard from the Opposition.

In the last five years the Hawke Labor Government has embarked on a program for the reconstruction of Australia. We have been substantially successful. There are some areas of difficulty. But if we look at the Government's record-for example, the creation of over a million jobs in five years, what has been achieved in terms of helping the poor and the needy, and what has been achieved in terms of redistribution and general economic strategy-we see that we have succeeded in a reconstruction strategy. But that does not mean that the task ends there. Now that we have rebuilt the nation up to a certain level after its massive destruction in the last two years of the Fraser Government, which were particularly outrageous in their destruction, we need to look at what needs to be done from here on. We need a constructive development strategy to take us off in the next 20 years. We need constructive ideas from all sides of politics about how such a development strategy should work, and not, as I said, the negative carping that we have heard.

I want to talk about elements of such a development strategy. Firstly, there is economic development. Due in part to the negative criticism that we keep hearing, we tend to lose sight of the fact that we are a resource rich country, that we are a nation with a future, and that we can have a lot more economic development than we have at the moment. We can have development in all areas: in resources, in agriculture, in industry, and in services. We have all this potential for the future. Let us talk about those positive possibilities and develop a strategy to achieve them.

Secondly, in addition to those positive economic possibilities, we also need a development strategy in human terms. I speak here of the need to develop the population of our nation. We need a population strategy, that ties in with our economic strategy, our industry strategy and our infrastructure strategy. That is possible. Instead of the carping criticism and the negative comments that we keep hearing from the Opposition, we should be hearing constructive ideas about how such a strategy can be developed.

There is no question but that we need more people in this country, and in particular, more young people, because the population is ageing very rapidly. In the next 15 years the number of old people will double, and we will have to find more revenue to provide pensions and benefits for them. It is very important in that context that we develop a population strategy. The other reason why we need a population strategy is to help us to develop our undeveloped regions, the vast northern areas that are underpopulated.

It follows from that, obviously, that we need a regional development strategy. We need to focus on how we can develop the different regions of Australia, not only those regions where we need people, such as in the north of Australia, but also those regions where we already have people and infrastructure but where jobs have been lost and there is unemployment. We need to direct economic resources to those depressed regions to help employment and to boots infrastructure.

Concurrent with that, we need to develop an industry restructuring policy. We need to restructure our industries in such a way that we can export more value-added products, especially high technology goods but manufactured goods generally. We need to ensure that we are importing less by providing import replacements from more and more of our industries. These are real possibilities, and we are working at them. Manufacturing industry, which was decimated under the conservatives-especially in their last two years-has picked up, but we have a long way to go. The Government is aware of this. The Government is putting into place an industry restructuring program, and in the next few years we will see that program being put into place in a dramatic way. It will involve some changes, to establish habits, but it is important that we get industry restructuring going and get these new industries developed. All Australians should come together to assist in ensuring that development and restructuring does take place, because without such structural adjustment we will not be in a position to face the challenges of the future. We have the basic resources, both human resources and natural resources, in order to have that development, but we need to take steps along that road.

Together with population development, we need to look at infrastructure development. The honourable member for Mitchell mentioned housing. Of course there is always a need to do more in housing, but we have done a tremendous amount in the last five years in that area and the fact of the matter is that we are prepared and ready to do more in housing but we need the support of those institutions that are funding housing, especially the banks, and we need the support of State governments and the housing associations to help boost housing even further. In addition to that we need to look at infrastructure requirements, such as roads as well as sewerage requirements in the cities and providing basic infrastructural services such as public transport in the cities. Those things are necessary if we are to get development going in the way we require.

As I said at the beginning, we need a coordinated development strategy, one which looks at the economic issues, the industry development issues, the population issues and the infrastructure issues. If we put forward such a strategy, we can get the support of the overwhelming proportion of the Australian people. This nation has been based in its 200 years on the concept of development, and that concept needs to be carried further. I believe that it ought to be carried further.

Let me say something about a matter with which I am most intimately involved at the present time-population policy and immigration. In the past year we have had the extraordinary phenomenon of a huge boost in the number of people wanting to come to Australia-an increase in demand from one million people in the previous year to 1 1/2 million wanting to come to Australia now. Obviously given that external pressure and given a strategy of development internally, our immigration policy needs to be generous and we need to open our arms. Obviously we cannot allow the whole 1 1/2 million in, but we need to be generous. If we could achieve 10 per cent of that figure and get in 150,000 people a year, that would be the minimum required for a development strategy to really get going.

We need this increase not only for the development reasons that I have put forward but also for population reasons, with the ageing of our population as I have mentioned. While our reproduction rate is below zero population growth, we need people and if we are going to get people here, we need to support a balanced and fair immigration program. Finding such a program is not an easy process, especially when we have 1 1/2 million people wanting to come here. It is very difficult. But find such a program we must, and we need to try to work together, to try to sustain as far as possible a bipartisan approach to ensure that we can convince the community as a whole that all these people ought to come here. In order to ensure such an approach we need to balance the various criteria and demonstrate that we are being fair to everyone concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is taking its time tonight on what are normally called Supply Bills, which appropriate some $10.7 billion in expenditure towards carrying on what we call the supply requirements of this Parliament and this Government. When we are talking about expenditure we must always realise that, on the other side of any budgeting that we do, there is a need for us to raise those funds by means of taxes or in other ways. Over the last five years, until this year's Budget, this has meant that the Australian Government has borrowed considerable amounts of money to put itself further into debt, to assist in increasing the foreign debt that we hear so much about these days.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that tax reform in any sense must involve an element of looking at expenditure to see what is real and necessary. The honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins), in his address, challenged the Opposition to say where these expenditure cuts would come from. I do not think it is up to us, as an opposition, to indicate where the expenditure cuts would be made. But it is fair enough to indicate to the honourable member for Scullin, and to the Government, that within the framework of the last five Budgets there are considerable areas that we could look at in order to effect those expenditure savings.

What I would like to do tonight is indicate that over the years of the Budgets of the present Treasurer (Mr Keating), and based as a comparison on the 1982-83 Budget which was delivered by the Fraser Government and the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), the expenditure of the Commonwealth has gone up 63 per cent. Over those five years, the element of inflation has been 36 per cent which means that, in real terms, expenditure under the Hawke Labor Government has gone up by 27 per cent. So when members of the Government say to us, `Where would the areas of expenditure cuts be?', I just go on record to say that, had we achieved a 27 per cent reduction in the expenditures of the last five years, we would have been able to compare one with the other, to indicate that some expenditure reductions were possible.

It would not be so bad if we had been able to fund these expenditures that the Government has committed the Commonwealth to with taxes, indirect or otherwise, or any other sources. But we have had to borrow funds overseas for four of these five Budgets, eventuating in a cumulative debt of $23 billion. I worked out some figures for the purpose of speaking on the 1987-88 Budget. They indicate that, had the Government in its time maintained expenditure at just on inflationary rates and picked up those items where expenditure reductions were not possible so it had to inflate, it would have been possible for the Commonwealth, instead of ending up being $23 billion in debt, to have been $21 billion in surplus.

So when the honourable member for Scullin comes in here, challenges us and then moves out of the chamber before we can answer, I would like to suggest to him that, had a government, of necessity or otherwise, wished to make expenditure cuts, there was a lot of fat in those Budgets of the last five years where that could have taken place. When one has to borrow to cover expenditure one falls into the trap of raising loans and raising the amount of interest on the borrowings, to the extent today that the Australian Budget carries about 10 per cent of its expenditure by way of just paying the interest on the debt. That is not repaying the main funding arrangement, because what the Commonwealth does is turn it over. But in its own way the Commonwealth has been a major contributor to the $115 billion foreign debt that we have today. What I also have been able to pick up through the appropriation is an additional amount going to the Department of the Treasury and also to the Australian Taxation Office. One of the books published by the Treasury Department, which was made available in December 1987, was Tax Expenditures Statement.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr BRAITHWAITE

TALK.START.PARA: —The Tax Expenditure Statement indicates that quite apart from the appropriations that we are approving tonight, within the taxation system is an element of delivery of services other than the main ones the Income Tax Assessment Act proposes, namely, to make a tax on incomes. This book shows that the additional expenditures that went through as tax expenditures for the year 1985-86 were $8.354 billion, which is over 10 per cent of the Budget outlays. In a committee only last week we were able to question the Treasury officials who presented this. The question is not the necessity of this document-because I think it is a very good document, depending on how one assesses the benchmarks-but how it highlights what these expenditures are.

INTERJECT.PARA: For instance, through the tax system we deliver social security and welfare to the extent of over $5 billion, and industrial assistance and development to the extent of $2 billion, and so it goes on. At least they are accountable. but one must ask whether it would not be more accountable if those programs themselves were set up to deliver the services through a funding arrangement which could be properly scrutinised by this Parliament. I mention that because there is a feeling that perhaps we should look at some of these expenditures to determine, first, whether they are tax expenditures. I do not really believe that, for instance, a spouse rebate is a tax expenditure. It is an attempt to deliver a little bit of equity and fairness in relation to a tax system that does not allow a single income family to split its income, whereas in dual income families that can be done. So I think we must keep these figures well in mind.

The honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) said in his speech that Australia is resource rich. No-one is denying that. Then he threw out the challenge that we should plan and plot the future for the next 20 years. But in assessing the honourable member's comments one would have to take into account the fact that he and other members of the Government would tie up the nation's basic resources. I mention uranium as just one example. It is a philosophical hang-up of the Left that uranium should not be mined or tinkered with. Yet uranium could provide Australia with a sizeable income and economic achievement to redress some of the trade imbalance. That is a basic fact. It does not matter how we feel about it or how members on the Government side feel about it.

The honourable member for Burke was talking about resources. He and his Government have tied up a basic resource of uranium. Earlier this year they tied up a basic resource of timber in the rainforests of north Queensland, with the result that the new Parliament House, which we are going to occupy at the end of this year, is going to cost considerably more. Yet the honourable member for Burke had the hide to say that we are rich in resources and we should plan what we are going to do about them. Another resource that we are wasting is labour, while we have an unemployment rate of 8 per cent. That is another resource we could use. I suggest that it is the dead hand of the Government on the economy that is causing the nation's trade imbalance. It amazes me that every time the monthly trade figures discloses a moderate deficit decrease, from, say, $700m to, say, $500m, the Treasurer trumpets that as a fine achievement.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr BRAITHWAITE

TALK.START.PARA: —Joy unconfined, and the journalists in the economic sections of the newspapers blaze it as a tribute to the Treasurer and also the glory of an economy that has turned the corner or the J-curve. Yet, in all of this we know that we are steadily ticking up a foreign debt and incurring interest.

INTERJECT.PARA: I suggest that there is a lot that the Government could do. I do not mean to carp, but the Australian business man who wants to trade overseas is not competitive in the face of our inflation rate and interest rates.

Our costs are not competitive, nor is our dollar. Our labour market is not competitive with those of other nations. When it comes to corporate taxation and other taxes on business, there is joy unlimited for the Treasurer because he catches more in his net then is caught by those in the countries with which we compete. I think that Government members should look at these matters and perhaps comment on them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great pleasure to participate in this debate on Supply Bill (No. 1) 1988-89, Supply Bill (No. 2) 1988-89 and Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1988-89. With the approach of May Day this coming Sunday, the day on which workers throughout the world celebrate their solidarity and their struggle for their hard won rights, I want to raise some important considerations that reflect on the state of our national economy, the economic and social well-being of the Australian people and the importance of this Supply legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: As I stated last week, and as I would now like to reiterate, it is quite fashionable in some circles, not least the Opposition benches, to blindly attack the Australian trade union movement and to blame workers for every real or imagined industrial problem. While it is quite easy and sometimes downright convenient to make the unions into a national scapegoat, frequently such attacks are without substance, ignore the reality of the situation and present a very one-sided view of a conflict.

I would certainly not claim that in each and every dispute the union is always in the right, but contrary to what many people-especially honourable members opposite-would like to think, it is my experience, as a member of the Australian Workers Union and a former delegate to the South Coast Labour Council, that the trade union movement is largely made up of responsible members and leaders who care not only about their own wages and conditions but also about the state of the economy of our nation and the well-being of its citizens, especially the battlers and the disadvantaged.

Under the leadership of, first of all, Merv Nixon and, more recently, Paul Matters, the South Coast Labour Council has had a long tradition of being actively involved in a whole range of worker related issues that extend well beyond the customary role of seeking better wages and improved conditions. I find it most significant that a local opinion poll conducted in 1986-to the best of my knowledge, the only one of its kind conducted in the region-indicated that 74 per cent of the population of the Illawarra thought that the South Coast Labour Council was doing a good job and had the best interests of the region at heart.

It is most certainly my experience in the Illawarra region that trade union leaders and members are generally prepared to sit down and talk before considering stronger industrial action. They see strike action as a last resort, to be used only when all other avenues have been exhausted. Today, however, they are taking the initiative in seeking to develop structures and approaches which, on the one hand, will facilitate better worker-management communication and shared decision making and, on the other hand, will reduce industrial disputation. However, they are most certainly not prepared to sacrifice hard won wages and conditions without getting some tangible returns. The Illawarra has a strong tradition of workers standing up for their rights, and it is only the most prejudiced of people who cannot-or will not-distinguish between what they are determined to see as pigheadedness when, in fact, it is legitimate trade union militancy.

The history of the trade union struggle is one of a long and hard fight to achieve the wages and conditions that Australian workers enjoy today. However, the unions of the Illawarra well know that the price of maintaining decent wages and conditions is that one must be eternally vigilant. That is not to say that the trade union movement is not prepared to change with the times. It is quite the reverse: Illawarra unionists have long recognised that we now live in very different economic circumstances from the boom period of the 1950s and 1960s. They understand quite clearly that they must respond to changing conditions and, by and large, they have sought to do so.

The South Coast Labour Council and its affiliated unions have, for example, accepted the major thrust of Australia Reconstructed and have taken the initiative in seeking to enter into tripartite agreements involving trade unions, management and the various tiers of government. The advantages of such tripartite agreements are clear. Each of the parties makes a number of trade-offs in terms of improved work practices and management practices, including a greater emphasis on communication between equal partners and negotiation rather than confrontation, and the end result is industrial harmony and improved productivity.

The puzzling thing in the Illawarra at the moment is that it is the trade union movement that is seeking the initiative in seeking tripartite agreements and business management that is reluctant to enter into such agreements. The impression I am getting is that management is still reluctant to accept the trade unions on an equal footing and is finding it more difficult than the union movement to accept the challenges of the times and the need for a fundamental change of attitude.

Late last year, the South Coast Labour Council began work on a proposed tripartite organisation, a regional consultative council made up of representatives of local industry, government and the Labour Council. It was envisaged that the consultative council would become a central organisation bringing together a number of disparate local employment and industry development organisations and would coordinate and facilitate such development within an overall regional development plan. The proposal met with only lukewarm response from the business sector. The former New South Wales State Government was enthusiastic but the present State Government is, quite predictably, yet to express an opinion. The Labour Council is now looking to the Federal Labor Government for support and a meeting is scheduled for next week with local Federal members of Parliament.

Undoubtedly, the most successful tripartite organisation to date is the Port Kembla Harbour Task Force. This was formed in 1981 on the initiative of the maritime group of trade unions which had identified as a serious problem a steady decline in regional maritime activity. The unions commissioned the Wollongong Workers Research Centre to investigate the problem. The Centre's report, The By-Passing of the Port, analysed the decline in activity and proposed a counter-strategy, out of which grew the Port Kembla Harbour Task Force.

The efforts of the Task Force, under the leadership of its Chairman, Peter Morton, were instrumental in placing the New South Wales Grain Handling Authority's third grain terminal in Port Kembla. The terminal, due for completion in 1989, is the largest development project currently under way in any New South Wales port. The objective of the Port Kembla Harbour Task Force is to facilitate the diversification of the port. Currently it is working on developing exports of horticultural products, live animals and frozen meat. Just 12 months ago, the Task Force organised a forum at Orange entitled `Industrial Understanding-the future of Australia', which I was privileged to attend. The forum established the Central West Task Force which consists of government, farmer, trade union, industry and small business representatives. It is through such practical initiatives and cooperative structures that many of the mutually held misconceptions and artificial divisions between farmers, small business and trade unions will be overcome.

Another tripartite agreement was recently reached involving the South Coast Labour Council and the Shellharbour Municipal Council which embraces much of the Throsby electorate, including the economically depressed area of Warilla. The two councils are committed to working together in promoting industry and employment development in the municipality, in promoting training and skill development programs, in ensuring industrial harmony through accepted dispute settling procedures and, finally, in safeguarding the natural environment. On the face of it, it would seem that the Illawarra union movement is far more willing to modify work practices than business is to modify management practices.

Much of the problem seems to lie in the area of middle management where we find some superintendents with a very fixed view on how to relate to workers and union delegates. For example, the recent very costly strike in the slab casting section at the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) might well have been avoided had the foreman followed recently established dispute settling procedures. The problem became worse when management refused to accept the recommendation of the New South Wales Industrial Commission that the sacking of a particular employee was too harsh a response to his refusal to handle a ladle he claimed to be unsafe.

In recent years, there has been much talk of the need to implement total quality control, an approach pioneered years ago by Japanese management. A large part of the problem in developing this approach in Australian industry is the inability of conservative middle management to involve workers on the shop floor in honest discussions on ways and means to improve quality and productivity. Management, it seems, dabbles with the idea and then shies away. Ultimately, of course, the responsibility rests with top management, which has the responsibility of implementing improved managerial practices.

At the heart of this problem, and many related industrial problems, seems to be the extreme reluctance of Australian management to move towards a greater level of industrial democracy and genuine worker participation. Illawarra unionists point, for example, to the practices in large steel mills in West Germany and other Western nations. In a modern steelworks with its sophisticated technology and multiskilled work force there is, they say, no alternative but to introduce a form of industrial democracy commensurate with the workers' enhanced skills and responsibilities. Management in West Germany sees this as an important component in ensuring increased productivity and competitiveness. Australian management apparently does not. They say that, especially in the case of BHP, recent changes in the consultative process have been largely cosmetic. While the lines of communication have certainly improved, the effect has been simply better to communicate managerial decisions to the workers on the floor who are asking when they are going to have the chance for some genuine input.

One unionist with whom I spoke recently said that not only does BHP have a managerial crisis on its hands in handling its technology; it also has a crisis in handling its work force. The West German experience would seem to point to the two problems being very much interrelated! To quote from the 1987 annual general report of the South Coast Labour Council:

Essential to a constructive program of industrial democracy is the two-way flow of information. Two major factors have been identified as contributing to high industrial disputation levels; first, the lack of job security due to unclear management strategy and, second is the lack of constructive consultation and negotiation between workers (their unions) and management.

Last week I was accused by a BHP spokesman of not looking at the facts behind BHP's decision to shed 2,600 jobs by the end of this year, with an overall loss to the Illawarra of between 5,000 and 7,000 jobs. I presume that the facts to which he was referring were, firstly, the decision-made in BHP Melbourne head office-that BHP Australia will not subsidise the expansion and modernisation of its steelmaking division at Port Kembla; and secondly, that BHP Port Kembla cannot afford to pay the interest on the money it would consequently have to borrow from an external source in order to build a new No. 4 blast furnace and thereby increase productivity.

I said last year, and I repeat it now, that I am appalled at the decision of BHP's head office in Melbourne that leads inevitably to the loss of so many jobs in the Illawarra. The BHP empire has made enormous profits in the past from its steelworks at Port Kembla. Those profits have gone to finance the further expansion of that empire within Australia and overseas. Now the people of the Illawarra are being told that BHP profits today will not be used to expand and modernise its Port Kembla steelworks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although I wish to talk of matters contained within the Supply Bills that are before us tonight, it is worth reminding the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) that it does not seem that long ago that there was a major strike in the district to which he referred which was to do with State workers compensation arrangements.
—I did not mention that at all.

—The honourable member did not mention it, and he failed to point to the sort of effect that would have had on the viability of the employer. Many of those people would have been on strike without being willing to be there and because of the pressure of their union bureaucrats.

SPEECH.PARA: I notice that in schedule 1 of Supply Bill (No. 2) there is reference to expenditures within the responsibility of the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), and in particular expenditures relative to the public hospital system for which I have responsibility in the Opposition. One of the interesting things is that we are spending some money on `waiting list assistance programming'. This amount was earmarked last year primarily when the Government promised over a three-year period a matching $50m grant which in some way was to address the problems presently facing about 100,000 Australians, who under the Medicare system can no longer get into a hospital when they have severe health problems. These problems might not kill them tomorrow, but certainly they will affect their lifestyles and their opportunity to enjoy a proper life as others are able to do.

There are people who, for instance, have arthritic joints and need hip joint or knee joint replacements. From the Newcastle area, an area which recently indicated to this Government its dissatisfaction, a gentleman wrote to me some time ago pointing out that the Government now provides him with an invalid pension because hospitals are unable to find the time to operate on his injured leg. The whole point is that these people are also suffering--

TALK.START.PARA: —Were the surgeons on strike?

—I hope that the honourable member is not being flippant about the worries of these people. I am sure that even he knows that waiting lists have become a scandal, because in the Government's own schedule of expenditure some money is provided to deal with that problem. Consequently, the Minister for Community Services and Health is writing to State Health Ministers, telling them of some proposals he has for next year. Such proposals are of great interest because he suggests an additional $1,989m will be addressed to Medicare compensation grants. That is nearly $2 billion additional money, but then the Minister points out that the total expenditure will be $3,063m. I added up what the Government has in this year's Budget for expenditure on hospitals, and I find that there are identified health grants tucked away in the general purpose funding for the States of $1,783m, and within the actual health budget the payment for hospital services is $1,685m-a total of $3,478m, which is about $400m more than the Minister is suggesting that he will pay this year.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not sure whether the Minister is suggesting that he will maintain the identified health grants that are hidden away in the general purpose grants. By hiding them in that way, health expenditure, which appears to be about 10.5 per cent of Budget expenditure, is closer to 12.8 per cent of Budget outlays this year. I do not think the Minister proposes to leave that other money where it is. I am interested to know just what he will in fact do for the hospital system.

Furthermore, whilst the Minister carries out this program, he also tells the people in his communication that, unless they are prepared to take 53 per cent of Medicare patients, he will deduct money from those States. That is laudable in one respect, but it only identifies the problem of the Minister. Also published in the Age yesterday was a copy of a letter that also came into my hands from a hospital administrator, saying, `You have to cut back on accepting any more Medicare patients because the State Government does not have any money to look after them'. Hospitals will have to take more private patients because at least they pay between $130 and $150 a day towards the $300-plus a day that it costs on average to run public or private hospitals.

The problem is that the Government continues to avoid the real situation. Medicare has failed to look after people who have a low standard of living. In fact, Medicare has created two classes of Australians. There is that class of Australian who can afford to pay the levy and has sufficient other resources to pay for top private health cover. Then there are the rest of the people, and they have to queue up on waiting lists to get into public hospitals because they are either Medicare patients or patients who have the basic private health cover, which only provides rebates roughly equivalent to the cost of admission to a subsidised public hospital. However, the public hospitals are now desperate for this revenue and are putting people further down the list.

The other day I quoted to the Parliament-and it is worth repeating-the words of Dame Dorothy Fraser, a highly regarded health administrator in New Zealand. She was one of the three members of the recently concluded Gibbs inquiry into the public hospital system in New Zealand. At page 5 in her prepared address delivered recently in Sydney, for which I was present, she states:
The public will identify access as the greatest failing of the present system.
She is referring to the New Zealand public hospital system. She continues:
Unless you are an accident victim, covered by Accident Compensation or develop an acute condition such as cancer, you join the 50,000 people on waiting lists who need hospitalisation.
That is about half the number on waiting lists in Australia. She continues:

Waiting lists vary between regions and according to the operation. On average last year the waiting time for hip replacements, kidney stones, cataracts, heart by-pass operations, osteoarthritis, was at least two years.
That is exactly what it is here in Australia. She then states:

The NZ public hospital system uses waiting lists to ration its services and encounters great difficulty in determining patients' priorities. It tends to respond to pressure from patients, family doctors, politicians or the media rather than develop criteria for priority. Uncomplaining, less articulate and poorer members of society tend to gravitate to the end of queues.

Take it from me, that is exactly what is happening here in Australia. It is a perfect explanation. The only difference in Australia is that the Government is not as honest as Dame Dorothy Fraser who says that New Zealand has deliberately rationed health services through the waiting list process.

In this country the Government says that it is everyone else's fault. The reality for people who cannot get into hospital is instanced in a letter that one lady sent to the Minister for Community Services and Health; she sent me a copy. She states, `By your process I am compelled to grope around in the dark for the next two years because you cannot address my cataract problem'. It is ironic that Dame Dorothy Fraser also mentioned that problem. It is a problem that the Government appears unable to address.

The Government will now try to again put pressure on the State hospital administrations in an attempt to avoid the fact that it has failed dismally to keep the promise that it made in 1983 that it would introduce a universal health program to provide free health services to all Aust- ralians. The Government is now trying to put an additional burden on the States by telling them that they must take on more public patients. It is mainly the Medicate patients, the poor devils who carry a green and gold card which identifies them as poor, who have no choice and very little chance to get out of the system. They must pay a levy to the Government and they have no additional resources to buy private insurance.

The Government is trying to force these people into public hospitals by removing some of the private patients. That is not a bad idea in some respects except that the private patients, because of the Government's past policy, can no longer afford the price of a private hospital. How long do we intend to let that go on because, unless private hospitals can attract substantially more clients, their prices will continue to rise. That is not the solution.

A well-known trade unionist wrote to me on behalf of his son, complaining bitterly that, firstly, he could not get into a public hospital and, secondly, because he had some private cover, he went to a private hospital. However, it cost him $600 to get out because the fund was not sufficient to cover the cost. The Government's Medicare system has created these sorts of problems and many people are suffering. There is a Commonwealth car driver-and he is only one of a number of examples-who recently borrowed thousands of dollars from a finance company so that he could relieve his pain and suffering. That is the latest phenomenon-people of pensionable age are borrowing money from finance companies so that they can relieve the pain and suffering to which the Government has consigned them through a promise that it could never keep. It is amazing to see the health administrators and others coming forward to tell Australians, not just the Government, that the Government can never keep that type of promise. I thank the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffiths Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —An old colloquialism in Australia goes something like this: `You could have knocked me over with a feather'. I must say that that was my response when I listened to the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), who waxed lyrical and with some outrage about the supposed and inaccurate impact of some of our legislation, in particular on elderly people. My mind went back to the recent endorsement by the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), of the Business Council of Australia (BCA) document that indicated a whole raft of potential spending cuts. I will outline some of those that are of greater concern to me as a member of this House because I believe they will have a significant and adverse impact upon, particularly, the elderly people in my electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: Before going into details, honourable members will be aware that socio-economic and demographic changes in a number of capital cities have inevitably resulted in a significant impact on housing prices. In some parts of my electorate-most obviously Essendon, but not confined to the City of Essendon-there has been a phenomenal increase in the cost of housing, with the average cost of homes in that area increasing dramatically over a relatively short time frame. Of course, this causes obvious problems in that many elderly folk in areas such as this become asset rich whilst remaining income poor.

It was in that context that I was very concerned to see the members of the Opposition had argued explicitly that the spending cuts proposed by the BCA `did not go far enough' and that they were `falling short of the mark'. Let us look at the general impact of a couple of those areas, particularly the abolition of the family allowance. There are many people in my electorate who would be very adversely affected by the abolition of the now means tested family allowance. It is a considerably important component of household expenditure for the middle income earning bracket. The document endorsed by the Opposition also proposed a cut in the Medicare rebate to 75 per cent, a move which would eliminate bulkbilling and mean that people would be charged for every visit to the doctor. That measure would be confined, of course, not only to ordinary wage and salary earners, but to a range of others. The waxing of outrage by the honourable member for O'Connor is thrown into stark relief when we realise that this endorsed document by the BCA also proposes to make pensioners pay more for their pharmaceuticals. Obviously, this is an area that causes great concern and worry, not only to elderly folk but to those who are not in receipt of a regular income but who have a large number of children, and so on.

The other point that was raised was a quite cold-blooded one. I know that there are countries around the world that are moving away from the indexation of pensions. This Government has a significantly improved record compared to that of its predecessor in terms of the indexation of pensions to the extent that there has been an 8.3 per cent real increase in pensions over the life of this Government. The proposal to stop the indexation of pensions is a particularly heartless proposal and one that I am sure most members, at least on this side of the House, will ensure does not come to pass.

Most honourable members would, of course, have attended perhaps one or more Anzac Day celebrations. I attended probably five or six over the course of the weekend, including the dawn service at the Shrine or Remembrance in Melbourne. Be that as it may, the proposal to abolish the Department of Veterans' Affairs seems to me to be a particularly untimely one, coming as it did contemporaneously with Australia-wide acknowledgment of the contributions of former airmen, soldiers, and Navy personnel and women.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the eve of Anzac Day, as well.

—On the eve of Anzac Day, as my colleague has indicated, it was particularly heartless, and is certainly not endorsed by this side of the House. The other proposals, of course, concerned the introduction of tertiary fees and a cut in road funding by $80m. I wonder what the National Party of Australia has to say about the proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason that I rose to speak tonight relates specifically to the proposal to take into account the place of residence as a component of income-that is, assets-for the purpose of prescribing eligibility for the ordinary pension. Over the past five to 10 years in suburbs such as Essendon and Moonee Ponds there has been a massive increase in the average price of homes but the time frame involved has left many people living in their usual place of residence. Many elderly folk have lived in these houses for 30 to 40 years. Many rely solely on the pension for their income, but, of course, they are sitting in a house which, in some cases, may be worth up to half a million dollars. Yet the BCA proposals indicate a possible level of $200,000 for a house. In Essendon, for example, the $200,000 limit would probably include 30 or 40 per cent of all residences in that area. Because those elderly folk have lived in Essendon for a very long time, they tend disproportionately to own those types of houses which attract the largest prices.

We now have a median house value in these areas which is probably around the $200,000 mark-the mark which the BCA has proposed as the cut-in point for taking account of the value of a person's private residence for the purpose of trying to reduce the amount of pension payable to that person. Regardless of politics, in a crude analysis of income and expenditure, it is quite clear that if we took account of such residences, as the BCA document has done-a document which has been described by the Opposition spokesman as not going far enough but which was implicitly endorsed by him-the end result would be to ensure that many people are asset rich, in the sense that they are living in a house worth hundreds of thousands of dollars, but income poor. Those people will have one of two alternatives. They can rely on handouts from relatives or from investments they may have. But if they do not have access to either of those fortunate resources they will be forced to contemplate selling that house after living in the area for many years. They will then have to buy a house in a price bracket sufficiently low to ensure that their pensions are not taken away from them.

In the five years that I have been in this House I have tried to ensure that I do not go around improperly scaring people in that vulnerable age group in our community, but this issue should be taken up in this House and debated. As far as courage will allow, Opposition members should dissociate themselves from any suggestions along the lines of those in the BCA document. Looking around the Opposition benches-packed as they are!-I do not see too many people who are prepared to dissociate themselves from the Opposition leadership's endorsement of this document.

When one takes the whole raft of these proposals into account-the abolition of family allowances, the cut in the Medicare rebate, which means that people will have to pay for every, and I stress `every', visit to their doctor, the increased liability on pensioners to pay for their pharmaceuticals, the removal of automatic indexation of pensions, the abolition of the Department of Veterans' Affairs, the introduction of tertiary fees and the cut in road funding of some $80m-one finds no great surprise in the fact that the Opposition has been running dead on these proposals.

I conclude on this point. The Opposition is continually wont to indicate in this House that the various spending proposals of this Government do not go far enough. I have waited five years to hear the Opposition put up a cohesive program of spending cuts, its own program of spending restraint, in order to ensure that its economic proposals hang together. They do not do that. If the way to achieve that objective is to pick on the weakest and most vulnerable component of our community, then I think that in itself is a damning indictment of the Opposition and its contemporary irrelevance in Australian politics.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would love to answer the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths). He clearly is not addressing the Opposition, but he is addressing his own Cabinet, which is on the point of making cuts in its May statement, the famous mini-Budget. In the 10 minutes available to me I do not have time to answer his tongue in cheek remarks about the Opposition. Instead, I want to address myself to the Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill, one of the three Bills before the House at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: We have allocated $1 billion to a new building for the Parliament. Australians will be very proud of it when they see it physically, but they must also recognise that there is a need for adequate funding for the functioning of the Parliament in that building. There is simply no point in having a building which is not functional. In some respects those of us who have worked in the impossible conditions here know that we are going from the ridiculous to the sublime. Fourteen years in this building has left me without one shred of nostalgia or happy memories, because while I have many memories of different parts of the building, some of triumph, some of frustration, some of good humour and some of bad, I can assure honourable members that the inefficiency with which we have been encumbered by the physical privations, by the invasion of our privacy and by the constant barriers to any kind of consistent, productive output on the part of members of this Parliament has outweighed any good things that I can recollect in it. I look forward with enthusiasm to working in the new building.

Having said that, there are some things on which I want to throw out a caution to members of this Parliament. There are certainly great features of this building which the public sees-the exterior, the chambers and King's Hall. Behind the scenes we have a very willing parliamentary staff. Every service department of this Parliament has been marvellous. I especially nominate the Parliamentary Library, which I think is outstanding. The Library of Congress is probably the best library in the world, but I think that the Library of this Parliament may be second. It is quite outstanding. Without the Library we could not possibly do the job that we have been elected to do.

I think that the new building presents a lot of challenges. Certainly the staff will be well housed. Their job will be less stressful and they may even improve their efficiency. But what about the role of the Executive arm of government? I have before me an article of which I will quote only a small part, but I commend it very strongly to honourable members. It was in the Times on Sunday, which is a fine production, not least because the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) did not like it. It is dated 8 March 1987. The article is written by Kate Legge. It is entitled `Behind Closed Doors', with the subtitle `Can the new Parliament change politics?'. As we now have a government which was once committed to open government, but which the more it is in power, the more it is committed to closed government and freedom of information becomes naught, we have a very major challenge to all of us who are striving to do our job as parliamentarians. I quote a little from what Ms Legge had to say:

But the building on the hill is more than a roof over the Parliament's head. The vital function of this design, invisible to the public and unexplored by the media, is to protect and entrench the executive: the ministers in general, the Cabinet in particular and, as a special case, in a manner more nearly presidential than all but a few Australians would credit, the Prime Minister.

For all the warmth of its welcome, our new Parliament House will contribute not to the responsiveness of government, but to its remoteness. It will have a profound effect on the institution of Parliament, the style of Australian politics, and the scrutiny of government decisions.

For the first time in the history of Australian democracy, the executive arm of government will have a home. Ministers and their staff will be housed, aloof, in a separate wing of the new Parliament House on Canberra's Capital Hill. The new wing is located deceptively, at the back, so that the modest back door, not the splendid front, will be the true portal of power.

Information-intelligence gathering-is the currency of politics: the door-stop interview, the corridor conversation, the art of sussing out what those in power would like to keep hidden from the public. Scrutinising the executive and its decisions is not merely the task of Parliament; in a democracy it is its raison d'etre.

This task consumes the Opposition, much of the government back-bench, and that third arm of executive scrutiny, the parliamentary press gallery. It is hard, grinding, never-ending work and in the new building it will become harder.
She goes on to say:

The new Parliament is huge. It covers 75,000 square metres, making the construction site the biggest in the southern hemisphere. Getting from A to B will be a hike. People will tend to phone rather than walk; chance meetings will give way to formal appointments. Even the custom of gathering to vote in divisions could be on the way out; provision is being made for the installation of electronic voting panels in members' rooms.

I put that to the House. I commend the whole article because it throws up a new challenge for this Parliament. What, indeed, will the impact of this new building be on the role of government? The old and bold like Fred Daly and Jim Killen tell us of the days when one had to have a drink in the members' bar because nobody had a fridge in their room. Members of parliament used to play billiards and travel by train instead of by plane and so on. None of us has time now to fraternise. We will have less time to fraternise in the new building. We are all guilty of this because we are all busy. We are all responsive to subscriber trunk dialling calls and to jet travel which enables us to go away at night to our electorates or to somewhere else. We know each other less and less and we are associating less and less. We are therefore proceeding more and more on paths of misunderstandings.

The Prime Minister's isolation in this building is alarming too. The Prime Minister, whoever he or she is, will be only two minutes from the Lodge and will enter the new Parliament House by a special door. At present we have a Prime Minister who launched his election campaign by travelling on the Admiral's barge across Sydney Harbour. Next time, no doubt, he will choose to walk. We have an astonishing situation of isolation. At present when we go down the corridors we can hail or bump into a Minister. We can say, `Look, I was going to write to you about so and so but I want to put it to you now'. It will not be possible to do this when we move to the new Parliament House. We will have to make an appointment to see a Minister. More and more we will cease to do that. We will be fobbed off by Ministers' staff and the Executive will be more and more remote.

I think one of the first things we have to do is assert the right of members of parliament to enter and leave Parliament House by the Executive door, by the door that is opposite the Lodge and protected for the Prime Minister, Ministers and staff who are not elected. Capital Hill in Washington is the scene of a constant tussle between White House staff, the staff of the departments and the Congress staff. Here we have a tussle between the Executive, which is the Public Service, the ministerial staff, which is almost the Executive, the back bench staff of both sides, the Parliament House staff, which effectively serves the back bench because it is not used by the Ministers, although it could be, and, of course, the media. These can be very creative tensions and the arrangement may work out very well, but I think it will work out well only if all members of parliament assert parliamentary independence. I think the solidarity pledge of the Australian Labor Party will have to go. It certainly will be under stress if we are to perform our role as parliamentarians.

I think we will have to change the Standing Orders of the Parliament, and we flirt with that proposal from time to time. Question Time will have to be improved. We will have to look at the role of House committees and, I suggest, there will have to be more joint House committees. The Parliament we know is under open threat from media magnates at this very moment. This will be resisted. But, increasingly, we will be under threat from an Executive more subtly influenced by other people who are less crass but no less greedy and no less manipulative than the media magnates. In fact, they will be more manipulative because of their skills in lobbying.

We have two options in this new building. One is for the Parliament to assert itself over the Executive and be supreme, as the people expect. The other is for its spirit to disappear into the tomb in which it will be physically housed. I cannot imagine any other country in the world building its Parliament House on the top of a hill but burying it inside the hill. It says something about Australia's cringe, but it also says a lot about our general unwillingness to come to terms with the role of Parliament and our capacity to lie down before steam rollers these days wielded by media barons and, through lobbyists, by the Executive, which is to be housed in Parliament House. In this building the head of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet has a small office, even smaller than that allocated to the most junior member of the Parliament. But in the new Parliament House he will be housed in all his glory in offices superior to those of elected members of this place.

I said last year that if the Government got its way in further concentrating the ownership of the media, the new Parliament House would be a mausoleum for democracy. At least for the present the Government's plans in that respect have been stymied, or at least arrested somewhat-although not as much as I would have wanted. However, that is another story. The more serious and subtle challenge to the Parliament is from the Executive and those who advise and lobby it. That challenge will be greatly accentuated in future. For years in Westminster-type governments people have spoken about the non-elected elite-that is, the executive. But in the new building we are giving Ministers total isolation. They will talk to each other, to officials and to the lobbyists who go to see them, with their official passes, but they will not be accessible to us let alone the media. That is a real challenge of which we have to be very much aware.

In discussing last year's Estimates, or it may have been the Estimates of the previous year, I spoke of the excellent report prepared by the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings with respect to the televising and radio broadcasting of both Houses of Parliament and their committees. I supported the recommendations of that Joint Committee, and I still do so. I do not care whether the programs are run on AM or FM frequency, but I support the idea of continuous broadcasting on a frequency which is set aside only for the Parliament. I do not care to interrupt Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) broadcasts. When there is concentration of media ownership, and of print and television in particular, even of the magnitude we now have, it is very important that people who want access to real information, to what is actually said in Parliament as opposed to the images presented through headlines or through 30-second grabs on television, have a chance to hear and see for themselves. Therefore, I support the parliamentary broadcast unit rather than the ABC preparing material and broadcasting on UHF for television and FM or AM on radio, so that people can hear continuous broadcasts. I support the idea of making available to commercial or publicly-owned stations film and sound so that they can use it as the print media does-that is, edited and open to scrutiny in its own context.

I support the report and will do all that I can to ensure that it is adopted in the new Parliament House. I am very glad that the fittings have been installed so that television can be introduced ultimately. The basic right in any democracy is the right to know. That right to know is threatened by the concentration of media ownership. If we can get to the point of actually broadcasting continuously, as well as providing excerpts on television and radio, we will partly overcome the poverty of knowledge which people will experience as the television moguls continue to try to get their way.

Finally, I draw the attention of honourable members to an excellent paper produced in the Parliamentary Library by one Greg McIntosh, entitled As it was in the beginning-the Parliament House in 1927. That paper bears reading to consider, as we move into the new building, how things have changed and what it is that impacts on the way we make our decisions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee) spent a considerable part of his speech talking about isolation in the new Parliament. He also mentioned the need to upgrade the Parliament and I would accept the points that he made about ensuring the supremacy of parliament. If he wants to talk about isolation I suggest he might spend some time in travelling around rural and provincial Australia because that is where the isolation exists. I take the opportunity in this debate to propose the need and seek the support of Government members for a rural provincial Australian strategy.
—In Rockhampton.

—Yes, in Rockhampton very shortly we will be holding a consumer conference and the Minister for Consumer Affairs, Senator Nick Bolkus, will come to Rockhampton to talk through with country consumers the problems that they experience. Whilst the honourable member for Goldstein is correct in his argument about the Parliament, I suggest there is need for greater emphasis by this Parliament on the problems that many Australians face. I am talking about not a few Australians but hundreds upon hundreds of thousands of Australians who live outside the capital cities who daily face the problem of distance. Distance creates additional costs. It brings about the absence of Commonwealth and State services. Those costs are also seen in travel, be it the cost of fuel or the cost of purchasing a car.

SPEECH.PARA: Isolation and distance affect the quality of life in country areas. The quality of housing in many country towns shows that people are not prepared to spend considerable amounts of money regularly to upgrade housing as we do in the cities because there is always the risk that the house will never be sold: it will simply be a rental proposition so the money does not have an investment return. Choice is affected in country areas. I am not talking just about people on rural properties; I am talking about small towns. In my electorate there are some 72 populated areas. When one considers that the electorate has some 78,000 voters it is easy to understand that many of the so-called populated areas are only small areas where there may be only 100 or 200 people. These people face great difficulties. They are confronted with isolation and a deterioration in their quality of life. They constantly see costs go up and their quality of life eroded. They face disadvantages in the social areas-education, recreation and culture. I note that the previous Minister for Sport, the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown), is in the chamber tonight. He did so much to try to improve the quality of life for young people in the sporting area. He certainly did a tremendous job. He was one of the few who understood something of the problems. People in country areas who want to play sport do not just go along to the local football club.

TALK.START.PARA: —Along with the member for Maribyrnong.
—Oh, yes, I would accept that. Young people in these areas do not have the chance just to go along to any club to play rugby league, the greatest game of all.
—Absolutely.

—I am glad to hear that the honourable member agrees with me on that. Nor do they have the chance to go along to join a local scouting group or girl guide group because the numbers are not there. There may be one or two and if they want to get involved in such activities they travel great distances. Families are disadvantaged because of educational problems, because of distance again. If they want to pursue higher education, it is a matter of travelling great distances. If they want to go on to higher learning they have to leave home and stay away and there are simply not the residential colleges available and, unfortunately, there are not the tax advantages or the assistance available to families to ensure that young people can go on to higher education.

SPEECH.PARA: It is no wonder that over many years we have had a problem with only 30 per cent of our young people going on to years 11 and 12. Under this Government the figure has been increased to 50 per cent but I suggest that a survey would show that the bulk of that increase has taken place in the cities, not in the country towns, not in rural areas. So we need a rural and provincial strategy to address the problems in country and rural Australia. There are so many disadvantages. One has only to look at the recreational and cultural problems that exist. I think it is time that the decision makers understood this.

Over a long period now I have discussed with Telecom Australia the inadequacy of its community access program. It has linked the Mackenzie River area in my electorate with a town called Blackwater. At the same time it has linked a place called Dingo with the city of Rockhampton, my own city. The strange part about it is that the people of Mackenzie River have to go through Dingo to get to Blackwater. I think those in Melbourne simply saw the townships as dots on maps and decided that as the crow flies they were closer so they were included in the community of access area. That has happened with the town of St Lawrence. Telecom has linked the people of St Lawrence with the small township of Sarina. The people of St Lawrence do not deal in Sarina, they deal in Mackay; but again the Solomons of the south have determined that Sarina will be the area of community access. The same thing has happened again in the small townships of Wowan and Baralaba. Instead of linking these people with the township of Biloela, where the local authority resides, or with Rockhampton, where they have all their business, medical and professional links, Telecom has linked these townships with the small town of Mount Morgan. There is a doctor in that town, but no lawyers and very few facilities to service the people of Wowan and Baralaba, which are country areas.

The same thing applied when the isolated patients allowance scheme was set up. For instance, if one lives on the Emerald side of Blackwater one is eligible for the isolated patients allowance. If one lives on the Rockhampton side of the post office in Blackwater one is not. Surely there is a need for a different approach. The same is true in every area we looked at, and I mentioned before the education field. Too often people talk about the advantages that governments give. I note that some $32m is being set aside to allow for the higher number of students qualifying for Austudy benefits. Young people in country areas not only need Austudy, they also need residential assistance. Their parents need some tax base to ensure that they can afford to send their children to higher education institutions.

I suggest that we need to consider new approaches across this nation. One such approach could be the establishment of a new zoning system, restructuring our tax rebate system to allow people in country areas some financial advantage for living there. I would advocate, as I did a couple of years ago, the restructuring of the zoning system based on local authorities. The greater the distance from capital cities of the local authority areas then the more the rebate should increase; the closer they are to capital cities the more the rebate should decrease. The present system whereby people receive a $90 tax rebate because they live within 250 kilometres of a populated area of 2,500 people is nonsense. If honourable members look at a map of Queensland they will see how ridiculous this is.

I have taken the opportunity to raise these issues. I believe there is a need for a new approach. I am concerned at the user pays principle that seems to be developing and permeating the halls of wisdom and power in this nation. It must be understood that if a user pays principle is introduced for Telecom alone people in my country areas will be paying four times the present price for a telephone call. We need to realise that the present rules in regard to sales tax might be inadequate and also unfair. For example, we have sales tax on freight. People in capital cities pay sales tax based on the wholesale price of a commodity. However, people who live in Mount Isa, the far north, or the far west also pay sales tax on the freight component. This should be a warning to those people who support a consumption tax. A consumption tax is a retail tax paid at the point of retail sale. If one were to be introduced people in country areas would pay a special tax on the freight as well. There is a need to redress the difficulties experienced in country areas. There is a need to arrest the deterioration in the purchasing power of people and in their quality of life. I urge that this Parliament act in the next few years to introduce a strategy based on rural and provincial Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 18 April 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to answers to questions Nos. 578 and 625 (Hansard, 16 March 1988, page 981), will the National Crime Authority (NCA) destroy the diaries and notebooks deposited with it by the private detective who was referred to in the previous questions.
(2) Is it a fact that those diaries and notebooks were recorded sequentially in terms of date and time of call, conversation or other entry.

(3) Is it also a fact that one of those entries recorded Sir Peter Abeles instructing or advising another person to transfer sums of money from Australian dollars to American dollars; if so, (a) what sum of Australian dollars was involved and (b) how many days after that conversation passed before there was a decline of several cents in the Australian dollar compared to the American dollar.
(4) Is he able to estimate what profit would have been made by someone making such a conversion when the money was re-converted to Australian dollars.
(5) What action did the NCA take on the facts revealed on the tapes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

(2) There are entries in the notebooks which are recorded sequentially in terms of date and time of call and conversation.
(3) One of those entries reads as follows:
(5) The National Crime Authority took no action on the English conversations recorded on the tapes, those tapes having been examined by the Royal Commission.
